webTitle: TV rights could go to auction

fields.headline: TV rights could go to auction
fields.trailText: The Premier League is considering auctioning off its television rights in a similar way to that by which the government secured a huge windfall from the sale of mobile phone licences.
fields.body:
The Premier League is considering auctioning off its television rights in a similar way to that by which the government secured a huge windfall from the sale of mobile phone licences.

Analysts believe England's leading clubs could achieve a financial bonanza worth up to £2bn from the three-year contract to broadcast top-flight football from the start of the 2001-02 season.

About 70 companies had requested copies of the tender document by yesterday's 5pm deadline for initial bids. The bids for the various rights packages, which will include highlights, delayed and internet rights, are traditionally made under strict confidentiality rules and presented in sealed envelopes.

However, the heavy interest and the success of the recent mobile phone licence auction, which generated £22.5bn, has led the league to consider alternatives.

"An auction is one of the options available to us but until the bids have been assessed in considerable detail over the next few weeks there is nothing further to say," a Premier League spokesman said last night.

Everton's chief executive Michael Dunford said the clubs were committed to securing the best deal available. "No one criticised the government for using this particular procedure when auctioning off new mobile phone channels," he said.

"No one is going to argue against doing whatever is required to secure the best possible commercial deal for Premiership clubs. Irrespective of what procedure we follow, in the end the only winners will be the clubs themselves."

If the clubs decide to go down the auction route they will hope to see broadcasters following the example of the heavyweight mobile phone operators like One2One and Vodafone who slugged it out until only one bidder was left for each licence.

Much will depend on whether BSkyB and the cable company NTL, the two favourites to win the main contract, are prepared to go head-to-head in a bidding war.

There is a growing feeling in the City that the two broadcasters could strike a deal giving each access to live football and effectively putting a cap on the price of the contract. City analysts say that in that case the live rights, which in 1996 cost BSkyB £670m for a five-year term, could go for about £1.2bn.

fields.headline: Ribbeck feels the Kaiser's pressure
fields.trailText: Franz Beckenbauer said he expected Erich Ribbeck to step down as Germany's coach after Euro 2000 and would like Jupp Heynckes to take over. But Ribbeck immediately hit back at the comments by Beckenbauer, who is vice-president of the German Football Federation, and insisted any decision to resign would be his alone.
fields.body:
Franz Beckenbauer said he expected Erich Ribbeck to step down as Germany's coach after Euro 2000 and would like Jupp Heynckes to take over. But Ribbeck immediately hit back at the comments by Beckenbauer, who is vice-president of the German Football Federation, and insisted any decision to resign would be his alone.

"Erich has said he will stop after Euro 2000," Beckenbauer told Sport Bild in an interview released yesterday.

But Ribbeck countered: "I can't stop Franz declaring that but it's pure speculation.

"I have always said the decision is mine to take. For the moment I am not thinking beyond the European Championship. Let's wait and see."

Ribbeck, 65, has been under pressure to resign after a series of uninspired performances by the reigning European champions.

"Jupp Heynckes would be the best solution," Beckenbauer said when asked who should succeed Ribbeck.

Heynckes was approached to replace Berti Vogts in 1998. He turned down the offer because his wife was ill and Ribbeck landed the job.

Ribbeck intimated there could be surprises in his final squad. "I will be very harsh. Perhaps one or two heads will roll," he added. "And there might be one or two selections who aren't even in the frame today."

webTitle: Pleat says Ginola not for sale despite rift with Spurs

fields.headline: Pleat says Ginola not for sale despite rift with Spurs
fields.trailText: Tottenham's director of football David Pleat said yesterday that David Ginola would not be sold despite his rift with the club after being dropped for Saturday's match against Manchester United.
fields.body:
Tottenham's director of football David Pleat said yesterday that David Ginola would not be sold despite his rift with the club after being dropped for Saturday's match against Manchester United.

Pleat said: "We have no intention of selling David and I have no knowledge of any offers. He is a great talent and difficult for any manager to have among his flock."

Spurs' assistant manager Stewart Houston, standing in for George Graham, omitted Ginola to give younger players experience of the big-match stage. Pleat added: "I thought it was a very good decision."

Joe Ashton, the former Sheffield Wednesday director and one of the four MPs who demanded Danny Wilson's sacking as manager months before he departed, has called for the club's chairman Howard Culley to step down.

He wants Culley and his fel low director Bob Grierson, both strongly associated with the regime of the former chairman Dave Richards, to go as part of "a restructuring of the club from top to bottom" following Wednesday's relegation from the Premiership.

Gordon Hill, the former Manchester United winger, has been offered his first crack at management by Chester City, who lost their Football League status on Saturday. He would replace Ian Atkins, who is not on contract and has been at bitter odds with the club's owner Terry Smith.

Carlisle United have sacked their general manager Martin Wilkinson and appointed Albert Doweck as chairman in place of Michael Knighton.

 The Football League has scrapped the away goals rule in favour of penalties to decide this season's play-off semi-finals in the event of a draw at the end of the two legs.

webTitle: Lib Dems set election sights higher

fields.headline: Lib Dems set election sights higher
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats have set their sights on winning at least another 50 Tory seats at the next general election following their surprise victory in the Romsey byelection, leader Charles Kennedy has disclosed.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats have set their sights on winning at least another 50 Tory seats at the next general election following their surprise victory in the Romsey byelection, leader Charles Kennedy has disclosed.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Kennedy said he believed his party could aim to more than double its present record total of 47 MPs by winning Conservative and Labour marginals, and holding all its existing seats.

The ambitious target, outlined to Lib Dem MPs in a private meeting last night, reflects a "revision" of the party's strategy in the aftermath of Romsey, where the Lib Dems overturned a Tory majority of 8,585 to gain the seat with a majority of 3,311.

Mr Kennedy, who has also been personally buoyed by the dramatic victory in the Hampshire seat, predicted the next general election would be "potentially volcanic".

William Hague has "boxed himself in" through recent hardline pronouncements on issues including crime and asylum, Mr Kennedy believes, and cannot now move back to the centre ground.

Lib Dems argue that justifies their belief that the Romsey pattern will be repeated on a national scale, with Labour voters continuing to vote tactically at the next election to keep Tories out, while a pro portion of moderate Conservative voters either stay away from the polls or switch to the Lib Dems.

It was "without being complacent, entirely realistic" to expect that his party would hold on to its existing Westminster seats, Mr Kennedy said. Tories, running hard on the heels of the Lib Dems in 19 constituencies, strongly contest that assumption.

The detail of the aggressive new Lib Dem strategy to target a further 50 Conservative seats, mainly in southern shires, will be unveiled to MPs at a strategy session in Bristol laster this month.

The seats range from Teignbridge in Devon, held by Patrick Nichols with a majority of just 281, to Devizes in Wiltshire, the party's 50th most winnable seat held by Tory chairman Michael Ancram with a majority of 9,782.

Other seats the Lib Dems are confident they can win include North Norfolk, where they are 1,200 votes behind, Cheadle, in Greater Manchester, and Bridgwater in Somerset, according to party campaigns supremo Lord Rennard.

Mr Kennedy denied there would be any kind of formal arrangement with Labour. However, as in 1997, resource limitations will inevitably mean that the parties are unable to fight every seat and ultimately allow each other a clear run to chase the Tories. "It's not rocket science to work out which are each other's targets," Mr Kennedy said.

webTitle: Liverpool eye Domi and plan clear-out

fields.headline: Liverpool eye Domi and plan clear-out
fields.trailText: The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier is willing to pay £4.5m to bring Newcastle defender Didier Domi to Anfield during the summer.
fields.body:
The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier hopes to add Newcastle United's Didier Domi to the Premiership's meanest defence during the summer recess.

Negotiations between the clubs have taken place, with Houllier indicating that he will be willing to pay around £4.5m for the France Under-21 left-back.

The Newcastle manager Bobby Robson believes the 21-year-old to be worth considerably more and would demand at least £5.5m should he decide that Domi can leave.

Although Robson has no desire to sell a player who has shown maturity beyond his years, he knows he will probably have to sell before he can upgrade the squad he inherited from Ruud Gullit.

Despite his obvious qualities, Domi is not a regular member of Robson's first team and in recent weeks he has been restricted to the bench after the return to fitness and favour of Alessandro Pistone.

In December 1998 Domi joined Newcastle from Paris St-Germain for £3.25m - rising to £4m dependent on appearances - and was Gullit's second major signing.

Having revamped the Liverpool defence since his managerial partnership with Roy Evans was dissolved, Houllier is still determined to tamper with his winning formula.

Though content with his central pairing of Sami Hyypia and Stéphane Henchoz, the Liverpool manager would like to begin next season with two new full-backs.

The 27-year-old German international Markus Babbel will arrive from Bayern Munich on a Bosman early next month and, despite a fondness for playing as a centre-back, will be asked to play at right-back.

Although the versatile Dominic Matteo has performed ably on the left side of Liverpool's defence over the past few months, Houllier believes he must introduce a specialist if his team are to launch a serious challenge next season.

Several senior players can be expected to leave Anfield in the weeks ahead, notably the Republic of Ireland defender Steve Staunton, the United States goalkeeper Brad Friedel and perhaps the Cameroon defender Rigobert Song.

Phil Babb, the most expensive defender in British football when he arrived for £3.6m in September 1994, is also out of contract and can expect to be informed he is surplus to requirements, something which will interest the Coventry manager Gordon Strachan.

If Babb does move back to Highfield Road he may pass the Coventry captain Gary McAllister on the M6. Should Liverpool qualify for the Champions League at Bradford on Sunday Houllier will resurrect his interest in the 35-year-old midfielder, who will shortly be available on a free transfer.

fields.headline: Dons fined £50,000 for brawl
fields.trailText: Wimbledon have been fined £50,000 for failing to control their players after a tunnel bust-up in the Premiership game against Chelsea in February.
fields.body:
Wimbledon have been fined £50,000 for failing to control their players after a tunnel bust-up in the Premiership game against Chelsea in February, the same punishment Chelsea received when their case was heard four weeks ago. The Wimbledon defender Kenny Cunningham was also fined £5,000 after admitting improper behaviour in response to severe provocation.

A row between the Republic of Ireland international and Chelsea's Dennis Wise started during the game, flared again on the way to the dressing rooms and triggered the violence in the tunnel. Wise was fined £7,500 at the first part of the hearing last month.

A further charge of misconduct against the Wimbledon coach Mick Harford will be heard at a future date.

Confusion surrounded the hearing, which initially opened at a Heathrow hotel. The Chelsea charges were dealt with but the Football Association then adjourned matters.

It insisted a new panel would have to hear the Dons' argument but the same three-man committee of Barry Bright, Frank Pattison and Alan Turvey reconvened yesterday at Loftus Road.

The FA spokesman Steve Double dismissed suggestions that evidence submitted by Wimbledon at the first hearing was mislaid. He said the delay was due to witnesses who had not been available.

According to the Wimbledon chief executive David Barnard: "We would have liked to have seen the back of the whole issue four weeks ago but circumstances were that we couldn't. However, I must reiterate it was no fault of the commission. Wimbledon submitted a full case. What happened to it then I can't answer."

Yesterday's FA commission decided Wimbledon were "equal aggressors" in the flare-up and were fined accordingly.

"The club cat will have to have semi-skimmed milk rather than full cream next week," said Barnard of the fine.

"We didn't fear points deduction. That was scaremongering by some people. This is a serious incident and therefore we take the matter seriously. We don't condone the action of our players." Wimbledon are deciding whether to appeal.

Double reaffirmed that the FA will take a tougher stance in future. "From next season, particularly for on-the-field confrontations, we've made it clear we will consider deducting points," he said.

webTitle: Blues in the dark over Zola move

fields.headline: Blues in the dark over Zola move
fields.trailText: Confusion surrounded the future of Gianfranco Zola yesterday after Chelsea played down reports that he has agreed to join Fenerbahce in the summer.
fields.body:
Confusion surrounded the future of Gianfranco Zola yesterday after Chelsea played down reports that he has agreed to join Fenerbahce in the summer. However, his fellow striker Tore Andre Flo wants to stay at Stamford Bridge despite recently being linked with a move.

Chelsea insist they have received no approaches from any Turkish club for Zola, even though the Turkish daily paper Sabah is reporting that Zola has persuaded his family to move to Istanbul.

Zola is being offered a £3m, two-year, tax-free deal and it is understood that Fenerbahce are also prepared to offer Chelsea £3m to release the 33-year-old from the remaining two years of his contract.

But Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson said: "We have received no approaches whatsoever from any club in Turkey or any club any where else for Gianfranco Zola."

Flo's agent says the Norwegian striker wants to stay and fight for his place. Although the player has been linked with several clubs, including Manchester United, Gunnar-Martin Kjenner said: "He signed a new contract just one year ago, and that was for five years, so that tells you something. His family is happy in London, and he is happy at Chelsea."

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink could be a Chelsea or Arsenal player next season after demanding a transfer from Atletico Madrid last night.

Atletico's 65-year stay in Spain's top flight ended at the weekend, and while Spurs and Middlesbrough have been monitoring Hasselbaink's situation the player's agent, Humphrey Nijman, said he had been contacted by "bigger English clubs" as well. "It is not Manchester United but they are big clubs," he added.

The French international defender Lilian Thuram, who has just agreed a lengthy extension to his contract with Parma in Italy, has welcomed reports that Manchester United are interested in signing him.

The 28-year-old, who has won over 50 caps for his country, said: "I have heard of Manchester United's interest and who would pass up the chance of going to play for them?

"I have just extended my contract and I didn't do so with the intention of changing my mind straight away. But if Parma are now willing to sell me that is an entirely different story."

webTitle: Unilever likens bid to 'marrying girl next door'

fields.headline: Unilever likens bid to 'marrying girl next door'
fields.trailText: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer group, moved to tighten its $18.4bn bear hug of Bestfoods, the US food company, yesterday by emphasising to investors the "significant synergy opportunities" from a takeover.
fields.body:
Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer group, moved to tighten its $18.4bn bear hug of Bestfoods, the US food company, yesterday by emphasising to investors the "significant synergy opportunities" from a takeover.

Bestfoods has indicated that while it had received several calls from large food and con sumer groups in the past week, it is not actively seeking a white knight.

Analysts believe that Pepsi, Nestlé and Gillette could all be interested, but Diageo declined to comment on reports that it had held preliminary talks with Bestfoods yesterday.

Unilever, which reportedfirst-quarter results yesterday, is relying on its target's shareholders to pressurise management into a meeting.

Several large shareholders are understood to be keen on the cash offer of $66, a 34 per cent premium to the pre-offer price. Bestfoods shares rose $1 to $64 as investors welcomed indications that its objections were largely over price rather than an outright rejection of the bid.

Unilever stressed that it wanted to talk to the company before it reconsidered its offer for the maker of Hellman's mayonnaise and Knorr soups. The company told investors that a merger would create the world's largest food and household products group, leading to cost savings of at least $500m. It described the bid as "like marrying the girl next door".

Bestfoods is protected by poison pill defences that make it difficult for shareholders to force a recommendation and make a hostile bid unlikely. Unilever's underlying operating profits rose 13 percent in the quarter. Sales grew one percent, while margins rose to 11.2 percent.

The group said its move to focus investment on its 400 top brands was beginning to bear fruit.

Operating profits rose to euro1.09bn but restructuring costs and interest charges trimmed the pre-tax performance to euro956m.

webTitle: Small shareholders press for Eurotunnel redress

fields.headline: Small shareholders press for Eurotunnel redress
fields.trailText: Small shareholders will press for compensation from Eurotunnel after moves began in France yesterday to prosecute the tunnel operator's chiefs and financiers, including the architect of the project, Sir Alastair Morton, over the controversial 1994 rights issue worth £858m .
fields.byline: Paul Webster  in Paris  and  Keith Harper
fields.body:
Small shareholders will press for compensation from Eurotunnel after moves began in France yesterday to prosecute the tunnel operator's chiefs and financiers, including the architect of the project, Sir Alastair Morton, over the controversial 1994 rights issue worth £858m .

Christian Cambier heads an association representing many of the 786,000 small shareholders, who lost a fortune when share prices collapsed. He envisaged an American-style class action for damages.

Senior politicians are likely to be questioned after the decision by an examining magistrate, Dominique de Talence, to initiate legal proceedings that could lead to the prosecution of the co-presidents of Eurotunnel until 1994, André Bernard and Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority.

Sir Alastair said last night: "I advise everyone not to expend too much time and energy on the latest news. A full response has already been given by Eurotunnel. The process has gone on for six years and may continue for years."

Sir Alastair said he understood the magistrate was making inquries on a number of fronts, including payment made to him while co-chairman and the possibility of insider dealing. "The inquiry into insider trading involves parties outside the company, not me."

Among charges being considered against the two men and chairman, Patrick Ponsolle, are publishing false information on company prospects and falsifying accounts to make the share issue more attractive.

If the judge decides there is a case to answer, they could be tried along with senior executives of Indosuez, Credit Lyonnais, Tiger Fund Management and SBC and three other Eurotunnel officials - Alain Bertrand, Georges Chazot and Graham Corbett.

The investigation arises from a report by two financial experts, André Dana and Michel Levasseur, into the circumstances of the 1994 increase of capital. Insiders were said to have sold their shares in the run-up, knowing that predictions on Eurotunnel's profitability and traffic were doctored.

The most misleading announcement concerned the opening of the Eurostar service. This was scheduled for summer 1994 in the prospectus but, immediately the share offer closed, French-state railways SNCF announced that the Eurotunnel link between London and Paris had been delayed for at least six months.

fields.headline: King Adora
fields.standfirst:
Rocket, Leeds
Rating: *
fields.trailText: Rocket, Leeds
fields.body:
The original goal of Radio 1's Evening Session programme was to play (mainly indie) music to inspire young bands; now it seems as if bands are designing music to appear on the programme. The formula is simple: tunes must be riff-heavy, influenced by Nirvana and feature shouted lyrics about favourite TV programmes or lager.

Birmingham's King Adora fulfil all these criteria and more. Their biography announces that Steve Lamacq, who fronts the Evening Session, heard their demos and immediately invited them down for a "session". To someone not indoctrinated in Lamacqrock, however, King Adora recall that famous Kit Kat ad: "They can't sing, they can't play, they look awful."

All awkward pouts and poses, they look "glam" in the way that only would-be bricklayers from Brum can. However, don't underestimate their potency. If you or I were 18 and amphetamine-addled, King Adora could - at a very big push - sound like the voice of God.

Presumably, such yoof marketability is what provoked an A&R scramble earlier this year. It couldn't be much else. King Adora are named after a vibrator and climax (no pun intended) with a ghastly piece of sweaty rock called Pseudo Muff Diver. All that I can find going for them is a dry humour (songs are dedicated to the "York massive") and the singer's sun glasses. However, with the support of the Evening Session, they'll go a long way. Preferably as far away as possible.

fields.headline: Susan Graham / Malcolm Martineau
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The art-song is alive and well and living mainly in the US, where a whole range of composers are busily setting their own literature from Whitman right up to the present. The mezzo-soprano Susan Graham's sometimes magical recital combined a cross-section of these home-grown products with Debussy and Reynaldo Hahn, pointing up the connection between the French and American traditions that has persisted since young composers began to make the trip across the Atlantic in the 20s to study with Nadia Boulanger in Paris.

Some of the American songs were French too: Samuel Barber's Mélodies passagères sets some of Rilke's Poèmes francaises in a style that would have not have surprised Ravel, and at one point even alludes to one of Debussy's piano preludes. Graham delivered these settings with seraphic poise, just as she and Malcom Martineau unfolded Debussy's three Verlaine settings of 1901 and the Hahn group with a consummate understanding of their every nuance.

Graham is one of those rare singers who can find musical depths in the most unpromising material. That alchemical ability was occasionally required in the American half of the programme - in four songs by John Musto, where it was sometimes difficult to decide whether or not the settings were ironic takes on some pretty indifferent texts. But two numbers from Leonard Bernstein's Songfest, the finest of all his concert works, needed no special pleading, while a pair of Lowell Liebermann's settings of poems by Randall Jarrell were a revelation, a wonderfully sensitive marriage of text and music that Graham made quite spellbinding.

Her ability as an interpreter of Ned Rorem's songs should be well known by now through her exceptional collection of them released on CD earlier this year, but it was even more impressive in the concert hall, from the opening ecstatic Alleluia, through settings of Paul Goodman, Elinor Wylie, and especially Whitman and Theodore Roethke. Rorem makes a jewel of out of the tiniest fragment of text, and every word acquires enormous significance. Graham understands that incomparably.
Andrew Clements

webTitle: Go online to buy your next car from a jamjar, says Direct Line

fields.headline: Go online to buy your next car from a jamjar, says Direct Line
fields.standfirst:
Internet robs salesmen of key tool: consumer ignorance

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Direct Line aims to make haggling with car salesmen an unpleasant feature of the past with its new online motoring site, Jamjar.com.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor  and  Mark Milner  in Brussels
fields.body:
Direct Line aims to make haggling with car salesmen an unpleasant feature of the past with its new online motoring site, Jamjar.com.

The "little red phone" insurance group, part of Royal Bank of Scotland, claims that Jamjar.com will offer the UK's most popular cars at "incredibly low prices" - up to 30% off the manufacturers' list prices.

Describing Jamjar.com as a "24-hour showroom selling almost 100% of UK road cars", its launch in the summer will coincide with moves by other financial firms to sell cars over the net, including Lloyds TSB which also unveiled its plans yesterday.

Direct Line forecast yesterday that 15% of car sales will be conducted over the internet by 2005 and it set out its stall to make Jamjar.com the most recognised car internet site in the country. It will spend £15m on marketing to try to achieve that goal.

Meanwhile in Brussels, a conference on car distribution in Europe was told that the internet had taken away one of the traditional tools in the car dealer's armoury - consumer ignorance.

"Car dealers are challenged by the internet," according to Paul Donaldson, business development and IT director of Autobytel UK.

Customers disliked impersonal salespeople, jargon and hassle - those who used the internet wanted best value, did not want to haggle and wanted to study a range of products, not just one manufacturer's.

Because of the internet, "consumers now know more about the product than most of us," he said.

Michael Bergmann, regional director of the e-commerce arm of General Motors, said he was often asked how many cars he had sold on the internet that day.

In the US some 2.7% of new car sales were carried out on the internet but 40% of buyers had used the internet as part of the process.

"While people may not be buying new cars online they are using the internet as part of the purchasing experience," he said.

Within GM the internet had become a means of building trust between the company and the customer.

The internet was bringing greater convenience and greater transparency, allowing customers to compare prices and increasing pressure for the harmonisation of both prices and taxes.

The web also affected related products, particularly finance and insurance - "low touch" services which people did not have to touch to buy.

Mr Bergmann said the internet was increasing customer confidence. "The consumer will be in the driver's seat. We hope that through our [on-line] strategy the seat they are sitting in will be one of ours."

webTitle: Egg shares go to customers only

fields.headline: Egg shares go to customers only
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Prudential is to limit share sales in its loss-making Egg subsidiary to its 1m banking customers to avoid the pitfalls of Lastminute.com's controversial flotation earlier this year.
fields.body:
Prudential is to limit share sales in its loss-making Egg subsidiary to its 1m banking customers to avoid the pitfalls of Lastminute.com's controversial flotation earlier this year.

Taking into account the criticism faced by Lastminute.com for misjudging demand for shares and setting its initial share price too high, Pru is restricting each customer of Egg and its Pru-branded banking products to a maximum £1,000 of shares.

Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of Pru, which will retain a majority stake in Egg, said subscribers to the issue would pay for the shares with their debit cards rather than being required to send in cheques and then wait for refunds for non-allocated shares.

Only customers who joined before February 22 will be eligible to apply for shares; Pru admitted that further eligibility criteria might also be applied for what it dubbed the first online share issue for retail investors.

While Egg, launched in October 1998, had been expected to attract a price tag of £4bn when the share sale was mooted earlier this year, the banking unit is now more likely to be worth between £1.5bn and £2bn.

Mr Bloomer insisted Pru had no regrets that it had not sold the stake, expected to be 20%, in Egg when dot.com share issues were attracting higher values. "I would rather be pricing in this market where a lot of froth has gone out," he said.

Pru refused to expand on estimates on when Egg, which lost £150m last year, might break even, saying that investors would have to wait for the prospectus for the share sale to be issued on May 22.

Analysts indicate that they expect Egg, which sent shockwaves through the banking industry when it started offering high interest rates on savings accounts, will start to make £100m of profits in three years' time.

The shares, which are mainly targeted at institutional investors, will be priced next month. Analysts said Egg will have to counter investor scepticism about whether it will ever make a profit.

In a move which analysts said boosted the credibility of the float, Egg named Roberto Mendoza as non-executive chairman. Formerly an investment banker at JP Morgan, he advised companies including Forte and NatWest on defending hostile takeovers.

Richard Delbridge, the former finance director of NatWest before its takeover by Royal Bank of Scotland, will also join the board of Egg after flotation.

In further management changes, Mike Harris, the founder of Egg and current chief executive, is to become executive vice chairman in January 2001 when Paul Gratton becomes chief executive.

Egg plans to open a current account later in the year as well as expanding into share dealing and extending online shopping. It also intends to look for partnerships to help it roll out Egg in Europe.

Mr Bloomer said the decision to sell the stake was intended to provide maximum value to Pru's shareholders as well as giving Egg shares with which to fund acquisitions.

He also made clear that it would be easier for Egg to reward staff and prevent them deserting to rival firms, but did not say whether the 1,400 employees would be allocated free shares.

Of Egg's £150m losses, £51m were due to staff costs with £21m being spent on brand marketing. Egg's quirky adverts feature broadcaster Zoe Ball.

Pru's shares gained 5p to 939.5p.

fields.headline: Mr Kolpert
fields.standfirst:
Royal Court, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Mr Kolpert

Royal Court, London
fields.body:
Comedy doesn't come much blacker or better than this. David Gieselmann's brilliant piece, translated by David Tushingham and opening the Royal Court's international playwrights season, not only satirises the appetite for violence that fuels a lot of modern film and theatre, but also, in a curious way, fulfils it.

The starting point is ingenious. Ralf and Sarah are a cool, smart, slightly odd young couple who occupy a fashionably spartan, all-white flat; its most conspicuous feature is a voluminous trunk that sits downstage and becomes the focus of the action. On this particular night Ralf and Sarah are entertaining an aggressive architect, Bastian, and his timorous-seeming wife, Edith. To rattle the guests and relieve their boredom, they claim that the trunk contains the body of Mr Kolpert, an office colleague of both Sarah and Edith, whom they have recently murdered. Are they heartless jokers or brutal killers?

To reveal more would be criminal. But what I love about the evening is the way it is both traditional and postmodern: it plays on narrative suspense while deploying a wide range of cultural references. The trunk is straight out of Hitchcock's Rope. Getting the guests is an idea borrowed from Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf. And, as the action develops, Tarantino's Pulp Fiction casts its inevitable bloodstained shadow. But Gieselmann strikes me as much more than a knowing hipster. He is really a perturbed moralist saying that in Germany, and elsewhere, there is an urban ennui and emotional deadness that drives people to ever greater extremes to discover lost feelings.

Richard Wilson's production in the Theatre Upstairs also dazzlingly unites the play's social comedy and darker purpose. Adam Godley's Ralf is a gimlet-eyed joker who turns telephoning a pizza order into a piece of performance art; but he is also, significantly, a chaos researcher who questions the idea of an underlying order to the universe. Amanda Drew is equally stunning as his voluptuous girlfriend, whose notion of hospitality is on a par with Lady Macbeth's. Darren Boyd as the bullying architect and Melanie Ramsay as his deceptively cowed wife also tread a fine line between the comic and the macabre, and Callum Dixon is hilarious as the pizza man who finds he has stepped into social mayhem.

The climax may be a bit strained but Gieselmann has written a wonderful 80-minute play, suggesting there is not just a weasel under the cocktail cabinet - as Pinter once implied - but a voracious panther.

Until May 20. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

fields.headline: Kensington Mortgage Company
fields.trailText: Sub-prime lending - mortgages aimed at individuals the high street banks will not touch - has been dogged by controversy over penal interest rates and lock-in terms. A rash of lenders, largely from the US, jumped into the market in the mid-1990s but soon quit. Yet the remaining players have enjoyed bumper business. The biggest, Kensington Mortgage Company, now hopes to float on the stock market with a price tag of up to £500m.
fields.body:
Sub-prime lending - mortgages aimed at individuals the high street banks will not touch - has been dogged by controversy over penal interest rates and lock-in terms. A rash of lenders, largely from the US, jumped into the market in the mid-1990s but soon quit. Yet the remaining players have enjoyed bumper business. The biggest, Kensington Mortgage Company, now hopes to float on the stock market with a price tag of up to £500m.

Kensington, which has lent more than £1.1bn to 20,000 homebuyers since it was founded in 1995, is expected to announce today that it has appointed Schroders and Salomon Smith Barney to handle its flotation; it is preparing to come to market by the end of the year.

Putting a price on companies in this market is difficult, but one pointer is the sale of a smaller sub-prime lender, the Money Store, which services 5,000 customers and £425m in loans. It was sold in August last year for £325m.

KMC has grown rapidly over the past 12 months, originating £600m in loans since March 1999 alone. The flotation is expected to result in a bonanza for its co-founder, chief executive Martin Finegold, who owns nearly 60% of the company. The other main shareholder is US sub-prime lender Ocwen, which owns 33%.

London-based KMC sells mostly through independent advisers, but it also has a direct lending operation in Newcastle. It focuses on customers such as the self-employed or the divorced who can suffer difficulties in obtaining a credit rating. It also targets "non-status" borrowers, many of whom have county court judgments which disqualify them from most standard home loans.

Sub-prime lenders typically charge mortgage rates at 2-2.5% above the Halifax rate of 7.74%, although some charge an excess as high as 4%.

KMC's mortgage book is entirely "securitised", which offloads the credit risk. Several other sub-prime lenders are believed to be up for sale.

fields.headline: Driven away
fields.standfirst: Take the money or walk?
fields.trailText: 11 May: When your boss offers you a cash replacement for your company car, should you take the money or walk?
fields.body:
The problem

I work in marketing and have always had a company car with my job but my is making noises about getting rid of it. The lease is up for renewal in July (When I hope to have another job) and my colleagues who have had wage negotiations say he will offer me £2-£3,000 instead. Can my boss legally take my car away?
Julie

The solution

This all depends on what your contract of employment says. If a company car is part of your contract of employment and your boss takes it away then he is breaching your contract. If you can argue that your car is necessary for the work you do and that the cash sum is insufficient to get a car with you are effectively unable to do the job and might have a case for constructive dismissal. You will need to seek legal advice if you wish to sue.

The cash sum you expect to be offered of £2-£3,000 does seem inadequate especially if you need a reliable and safe car for a lot of motoring (although you might get a healthy mileage allowance to make up for it). But, if the car is just a perk of your job and not mentioned in your contract, there may not be too much you can do about it.

The best solution might be to take the cash ... then take that other job! To do this, you will need to make sure there are no strings attached to the cash offer such as your having to stay with the company another year. At the end of the day a good car is worth more than £3,000 so if you get another job offer with a car go for it. Just make sure the car is written into your contract this time.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: ¡Hola! Evolvebank.com here, Jimmy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB yesterday launched its new internet bank into Europe and simultaneously guaranteed that there will be a corner of Glasgow that is forever Spanish
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB yesterday launched its new internet bank into Europe and simultaneously guaranteed that there will be a corner of Glasgow that is forever Spanish.

Spanish and Catalan speakers will be recruited to work in a call centre there for Evolvebank.com.

The venture, ambitiously heralded as the "most highly automated, flexible, lowest cost bank in the world", will be rolled out in Spain this summer before opening in the UK at the end of the year. The bank is also targeting France, Germany and Italy.

Jayne Almond, head of evolvebank.com, insisted she was was not worried by rival internet launches, including Halifax's Intelligent Finance or Abbey National.

Evolvebank.com was purely an internet bank, rather than an internet bank with a telephone operation of the kind being launched by competitors.

"People going down the telephone banking route will not be able to live with us," she said.

While it would have the Glasgow call centre, very few of a staff totalling around 100 would speak to customers.

Becoming the third bank this week to unveil details of its internet strategy, Lloyds TSB admitted it would spend a further £150m this year on development on top of £500m already spent.

In addition to evolvebank.com, Lloyds TSB is revamping its own-brand site to which 300,000 customers have signed up. It aims to have 1m customers on Lloyds TSB.com by the end of this year and a further 1.5m customers for Evolvebank.com by the end of 2003.

The bank's shares rose by 11p to 609p.

webTitle: Bank says economy in for bumpy ride

fields.headline: Bank says economy in for bumpy ride
fields.trailText: The Bank of England said yesterday that it was powerless to bring down the level of the pound but warned that a sharp fall in sterling from its current "unsustainable" level could bring higher interest rates.
fields.body:
The Bank of England said yesterday that it was powerless to bring down the level of the pound but warned that a sharp fall in sterling from its current "unsustainable" level could bring higher interest rates.

In its influential quarterly inflation report, the Bank said the recent strength of sterling against the euro had driven down inflation in the past three months and spared the UK from an increase in borrowing costs caused by expansion of the domestic economy.

Mervyn King, the Bank's deputy governor, ruled out intervention to bring down the level of the pound, saying that the nation lacked the firepower to take on the foreign exchange markets, He said it was the job of the monetary policy committee to target inflation not the exchange rate.

The inflation report, which gives a forecast of the prospects for inflation over the next two years, said the economy was on course to hit the government's 2.5% inflation target, but that interest-rate policy might well hinge on how the pound performed.

With Ford poised to announce another blow to manufacturing by ending car production at Dagenham, Mr King said that the economy could be in for a bumpy ride. "The imbalances in the economy - between strong domestic demand and weak net trade - remain. But if the exchange rate were to return to a more sustainable level, final domestic demand growth would have to fall to prevent excess pressure on capacity and rising inflation."

The inflation report said domestic demand was robust, with real incomes and bor rowing rising, share prices high and the tightness of the labour market leading to reports of skill shortages. However, despite the MPC's concerns about the risks to infla tion should the pound drop back, foreign exchange dealers took the view that interest rates may have peaked at 6%, leading to a fall in sterling.

The pound slid to four-year lows against the dollar and three-week lows against the euro, continuing a recent downtrend after the central bank surprisingly left borrowing costs unchanged last week. Sterling fell as far as 59.98p per euro, almost 5.5% below the record highs it was scaling only last week.

Mr King said that the key issue for the Bank was to how to set interest rates when confronted with "what is probably an unsustainable exchange rate", adding that the level of sterling reflected the continuing weakness of the euro.

The deputy-governor said that there remained differ ences of view on the MPC. "They stem from different judgments about the future path of the exchange rate, the likelihood of a further compression of retail margins, the extent of the pass-through from the recent rise in earnings growth to prices, and possible improvements in the supply side of the UK economy."

He said too much should not be expected of the interest-rate setting body. "The MPC cannot control the world. We have only one instrument and we can try to influence domestic demand conditions. But we have very little control over many of the factors crucial to determining the outcome...

"Final domestic demand growth will probably need to slow if cost pressures - especially in the labour market - are not to increase."

fields.headline: The Ultimate Man
fields.standfirst:
Bridewell Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Bridewell Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Paul Gambaccini's childhood love of comics inspired this cartoon strip musical, and there are times when you wish he'd left his obsession with his youth. Alastair King's likeable score plays with musical theatre styles of the 50s and 60s, and Gambaccini's lyrics have flashes of wit. But the story line makes Superman seem like an intellectual achievement.

Cartoonist Joe Barino has allowed money and his man-eating agent, Thrifty Bazaar, to persuade him to let the villains get the upper hand in the world of Ultimate Man. But the Lycra superhero thinks the villainous Rex Ringer has gone too far when the latter kidnaps his girl, Cathy Cookie. In an effort to save her, Ultimate Man smashes through to the real world where Joe, newly fallen in love, rediscovers his integrity and draws everyone out of trouble in time for the final number.

It is patchily entertaining, but Gambaccini and his team never get the balance between spoof and affectionate homage quite right. Then there is the problem that the cartoon characters are indeed two-dimensional. What it needs is a book that doesn't just celebrate the Marvel culture of 40 years ago, but brings to it a 21st-century irony.

 Until May 27. Box office: 020-7936 3456

fields.headline: The Cherry Orchard
fields.standfirst:
Oxford Playhouse
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Oxford Playhouse
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It is an attention to detail that lifts Stephen Unwin's production out of the ordinary. He may not have quite the same affinity for Chekhov as he does for Ibsen, whom he directs better than anyone else in Britain, but this is still a solidly satisfying evening.

At its heart is Prunella Scales's quietly pulsating Madame Ranevskaya, whose eternal girlishness is symptomatic of her reluctance to turn her back on the ghosts of the past and face up to the realities of the future. This is not the giddy creature that Ranevskaya is sometimes portrayed as, but a small, grave child who has never grown up and who is in constant need of protection from the truth. Her brother, Gaev, is even more infantile in an admirable performance from John Quentin that doesn't shirk from displaying all the character's most irritating aspects.

There are a string of effective, detailed characterisations here, from Frank Middlemass's exceptionally moving Firs, a piece of history left to die alone in the condemned house, and Simon Scardifield's Yasha, a boor with a polished veneer, to Amelda Brown's Charlotta, a lonely woman who cries the tears of the clown. Michael Feast's Lopakhin is terrific too, displaying his origins in every vowel and gauche movement of his hands and unable to resist marking his triumph when he buys the estate on which his father and grandfather were serfs. He has the sudden confidence of a man who knows he is the future, the coming thing.

Elsewhere, the production plays beautifully with light and shadow so each setting and rise of the sun feels like the end of one world and the start of the next, and it cleverly negotiates that tricky Chekhovian tightrope between the ridiculous and the sublime. Not a showy evening, but a true one.

 At the Lyceum, Crewe (01270 537333), until Saturday, then tours to the Cambridge Arts Theatre (01223 503333), May 16-20, Guildford, Salford, Bath, Richmond and Greenwich.

webTitle: No one likes them - and they care

fields.headline: No one likes them - and they care
fields.standfirst: Andy d'Urso is under pressure after producing a record number of cards
fields.trailText: Andy d'Urso might wonder if it is worth the few hundred pounds a time. At Leeds on Monday he set an unwanted Premiership record by dishing out nine yellow cards and three reds. In January he was pursued across Old Trafford by a pack of seething Manchester United players. The Essex official could be forgiven for wishing his first season in the top flight will be his last.
fields.body:
Andy d'Urso might wonder if it is worth the few hundred pounds a time. At Leeds on Monday he set an unwanted Premiership record by dishing out nine yellow cards and three reds. In January he was pursued across Old Trafford by a pack of seething Manchester United players. The Essex official could be forgiven for wishing his first season in the top flight will be his last.

Judging by the reaction of Everton's Walter Smith yesterday, several managers will be hoping as much. In sending off Don Hutchison and Richard Dunne, D'Urso took the number of Everton players he has dismissed this season to four in as many matches. Roy Keane and Co gave up chase after a few yards. Evertonians might pursue D'Urso as far as Lancashire given the chance.

"We had a poor disciplinary record last season which everyone here has worked very hard to try to improve," Smith said. "We have done that to very good effect this season except, it would seem, when Andy d'Urso has been in charge of our games ... He seems to have a major problem and it's difficult to understand why."

That was Smith in conciliatory mood. After seeing Dunne sent off and seven others booked at Derby in August, he described D'Urso's performance as "nothing short of diabolical". Other managers have joined in the abuse. Aston Villa's John Gregory, who admittedly suggested referees should have 50,000 volts run through their genitals after three mistakes, threatened to punch D'Urso's "lights out" when he was a fourth official.

The pack hunting and criticism may not be a coincidence. "The clubs do their homework," said Philip Don, the Premier League referees' officer. "They know who the first-year referees are and who's been around a long time. They know if a referee has any idiosyncrasies. They know what they can get away with because some referees are more tolerant than others. The clubs wouldn't be doing a professional job if they weren't looking into that. It's no different from them going to watch their opponents."

D'Urso, who is in his mid-30s, is one of five first-year referees. Critics say he is too inexperienced; that United's players would never have treated David Elleray in a similar way; that his tendency to brandish yellow cards early on inevitably leads to reds. He has sent off seven Premiership players this season, one fewer than Uriah Rennie, who tops the list. His average of 3.75 cards per Premiership match is the division's fifth highest.

But Don said yesterday he was pleased with the way D'Urso has conducted himself and has no concerns. He has already spoken to him about Monday's match. "I monitor [referees'] performances," Don added. "If I monitored how clubs view them there would be very few Premier League referees left."

Some have been sent back to the lower divisions, destroyed not only by poor performances but by repeated attacks from players, managers and the press. Paul Danson, referred to as Danson in the Dark, was the last to be struck off the top-flight list, in 1997.

That followed a series of controversies. The Coventry manager Ron Atkinson and his No2 Gordon Strachan were charged with misconduct for protesting at Danson's failure to spot a handball. Peter Reid was ordered to the stands after a touchline slanging match with the official, who had just sent off the first of two Sunderland players.

"At the moment if you are on the Premier League list at the beginning of the season you are on it until the end," Don said, "but we are reviewing that procedure for next season, discussing possibilities of reviewing the list mid-season."

Don will promote or demote largely on the basis of reports filed by the observers who watch every Premier League match. Around 90% of them are former referees.

As well as reading the reports and noting the marks, Don watches videos and speaks to referees every week. "I may make a more formal approach to them," he said, "asking them for their observations." Several meetings are held each year.

Before plunging a referee into the Premier League Don watches them closely. "They obviously need the experience and then you've got to look at whether they can handle the pressure. This year, having National List referees - that's both Football League and Premier League - as fourth officials at Premier League games has given them more experience of the pressure from the media, the crowd, the clubs."

That is mounting on D'Urso. The real test is now to come.

fields.headline: Romario returns for Brazil visit
fields.trailText: England and Wales face the daunting prospect of attempting to contain a rejuvenated Romario when they take on Brazil in friendlies this month.
fields.body:
England and Wales face the daunting prospect of attempting to contain a rejuvenated Romario when they take on Brazil in friendlies this month.

The 34-year-old striker has not played for his national side since April of last year, when Brazil took on Barcelona in a match to celebrate the Spanish club's centenary, but he has been recalled by Wanderley Luxemburgo after hitting a rich vein of form.

Romario, who plays for Vasco da Gama, leads the scoring in the Brazilian league with 15 goals. Brazil play Wales on May 23 and England four days later and the strong squad also includes the world player of the year Rivaldo.

Wimbledon's John Hartson and the Leeds midfielder Matthew Jones have returned after injury to the Wales squad for the Brazil match and for the friendly against Portugal in June.

The Malaysian businessman Jerry Lim has moved closer to sealing his takeover of Crystal Palace after contracts were exchanged on the £10.6m deal yesterday.

A consortium fronted by Lim should be in place by the end of the month although the club will remain in administration for the time being.

Jim Smith could face a heavy fine and a possible touchline ban after being charged with misconduct for a second time this season.

The charge follows comments made by Derby's manager to the referee Neale Barry during half-time of the draw against Tottenham Hotspur last month. Smith was also sent from the dugout during the match on April 29.

Smith, who was charged with misconduct in December after comments to the assistant referee at the match against Manchester United, was incensed after Barry sent off Stefan Schnoor and booked five other Derby players.

Tottenham, whose attempts to sign the Atletico Madrid striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink look doomed after the Dutchman said he wished to remain in Spain, could be set to lower their sights and bid for the Calais striker Mickael Gerard.

According to reports in France, the 27-year-old is due to hold talks with Spurs over a £1m move.

Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis has been appointed to Fifa's marketing and television advisory board. European sports ministers will meet in Lisbon today to discuss changes to the Bosman ruling.

Brazil squad: Dida, Carlos Germano; Cafu, Aldair, Antonio Carlos, Evanilson, Emerson, Silvinho, Roberto Carlos; Cesar Sampaio, Conceicao, Rivaldo, Emerson, Ze Roberto; Amoroso, Elber, Franca, Romario.

Wales squad: Crossley (Nottm For), Ward (Notts Co), Freestone (Swansea), Delaney (Aston Villa), Barnard (Barnsley), Giggs (Man Utd), Blake (Blackburn), Page (Watford), Coleman (Fulham), Pembridge (Everton), Melville (Fulham), Saunders (Bradford), Speed (Newcastle), J Robinson (Charlton), C Robinson (Wolves), Bellamy (Norwich), Jones (Leeds), Symons (Fulham), Savage (Leicester), Hartson (Wimbledon), I Roberts (Norwich), Johnson (Nottm For), G Roberts (Tranmere).

The charge follows comments made by Derby's manager to the referee Neale Barry during half-time of the draw against Tottenham Hotspur last month. Smith was also sent from the dugout during the match on April 29. Smith, who was charged with misconduct in December after comments to the assistant referee at the match against Manchester United, was incensed after Barry sent off Stefan Schnoor and booked five other Derby players. Tottenham, whose attempts to sign the Atletico Madrid striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink look doomed after the Dutchman said he wished to remain in Spain, could be set to lower their sights and bid for the Calais striker Mickael Gerard. According to reports in France, the 27-year-old is due to hold talks with Spurs over a £1m move. Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis has been appointed to Fifa's marketing and television advisory board. European sports ministers will meet in Lisbon today to discuss changes to the Bosman ruling. webTitle: Leeds set to sign Dacourt for record £8m

fields.headline: Leeds set to sign Dacourt for record £8m
fields.trailText: Olivier Dacourt will become Leeds United's record signing next week after provisionally agreeing personal terms at Elland Road.
fields.body:
Olivier Dacourt will become Leeds United's record signing next week after provisionally agreeing personal terms at Elland Road.

A year after leaving Everton for Lens, the French midfielder is set for a return to the Premiership for around £8m.

Dacourt was shown around the club on Monday and Leeds expect the deal to go through as soon as their season has come to a close.

"I always said I wanted to play in England again and things are moving in that direction," he said. "Leeds are a very big club and very ambitious."

The arrival of a player who has already proved himself an able competitor in the English game will herald the start of a busy summer of transfer activity for the Leeds manager David O'Leary.

Regardless of whether his team qualify for the Champions League or the Uefa Cup, he will be given at least £30m to strengthen his squad.

"We will be announcing new signings in the next two to three weeks, maybe sooner even, and they will all be top players," said Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds chairman.

Leeds's priority remains a proven international striker and O'Leary plans to make an improved bid for Manchester United's prolific striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer after having a £10m offer for the talismanic Norwegian turned down 24 hours before the transfer deadline day. The previous Leeds transfer record is held by Michael Bridges, who came from Sunderland for £5m last summer.

Leeds are arranging a memorial game at Elland Road, possibly against Barcelona, for the families of the two supporters who were killed in Istanbul prior to the Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray.

Proceeds from the game, planned to be played in early August, will go into a trust fund set up by the club for the relatives of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight.

Although details of the game are yet to be confirmed, Ridsdale has indicated that it will be against one of the top sides in Europe. "We've had hundreds of thousands of letters sent to the club containing donations for the two families," he said.

 The referee who controversially ruled out a late Parma equaliser against the Serie A leaders Juventus on Sunday has been summoned before the Italian football federation. Massimo de Santis's intervention ensured Juventus won 1-0 and means they go into the last round of matches this weekend with a two-point lead over Lazio, who were bitterly critical of the decision.

fields.headline: Anelka gives Real final impetus
fields.standfirst:
Jancker 12, Elber 54 | Anelka 31
Real Madrid win 3-2 on aggregate
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText:
Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Real Madrid
Real Madrid win 3-2 on aggregate. Goals from Carsten Jancker and Giovane Elber were not enough for Bayern Munich as Real Madrid booked their place in the final with a Nicolas Anelka away goal.
fields.body:
Real Madrid ensured that the Stade de France will host an all-Spanish final to the Champions League when they completed their semi-final win over Bayern Munich by 3-2 on aggregate after losing 2-1 in the Olympic Stadium. Valencia, leading 4-1, meet Barcelona tonight to decide who Real will meet on May 24.

Bayern, last year's losing finalists, had started the match with high hopes of overturning their two-goal deficit from the first leg, mainly stemming from the return of their talismanic midfielder Stefan Effenberg, who had missed the match at the Bernabeu with a calf strain.

He was at the heart of Bayern's rip-roaring start and was instrumental in the opening goal. From a free-kick on 12 minutes he released Jens Jeremies whose cross picked out Giovane Elber at the far post. The Brazilian striker's header fell slightly behind Carsten Jancker but he acrobatically volleyed home.

Jancker had earlier seen a close-range header cleared off the line, but he was at fault when Bayern's clearest chance of the half to level the tie was ruled out. Elber calmly finished after Iker Casillas had only parried a shot from Jeremies, but Jancker had strayed marginally offside and the goal was correctly disallowed.

This let-off served to galvanise Real. Raul headed on to the top of the net and shot narrowly wide from a rebound after Roberto Carlos had seen his swerving free-kick fumbled by Oliver Kahn. Their pressure finally told on the half-hour.

Savio manouevred himself space to cross and picked out Nicolas Anelka. The former Arsenal striker levelled the match with a terrific header from eight yards which left Kahn stranded.

Geremi twice stretched Kahn after that and Anelka showed his renewed confidence by beating three defenders and forcing Kahn to scramble the ball away from his top corner.

Real would have happily done without half-time such was their ascendancy and sure enough Bayern, needing three further goals, threw everything at Vicente del Bosque's side in the second half.

They got the breakthrough when Effenberg's free-kick was glanced in by Elber. The Brazilian then had a shot saved on the line by Steve McManaman after Casillas had parried Jancker's powerful header.

Despite some prolonged pressure Bayern could not narrow the advantage still further and Anelka almost sealed a more decisive win for the seven-time European champions when he shot over from close range after 71 minutes. For Bayern, once again it was a case of so near, yet so far.

Bayern Munich (4-4-2):Kahn; Babbel, Kuffour, Andersson, Lizarazu; Sergio, Scholl, Effenberg, Jeremies; Jancker (Santa Cruz, 79min), Elber.

Real Madrid (4-4-2): Casillas; Geremi, Campo, Julio Cesar, Carlos; Helguera, Redondo, McManaman (Balic, 90), Savio (Karembeu, 81); Raul, Anelka (Sanchis, 89).

Referee: G Poll (Tring).

webTitle: Stewart lays down a pair of gauntlets

fields.headline: Stewart lays down a pair of gauntlets
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 198-6
Yorkshire 191
Surrey win by seven runs
fields.trailText:
Surrey 198-6
Yorkshire 191
Surrey win by seven runs
fields.body:
Leeds is the city where sporting youth has been acclaimed ad nauseam all winter but, when it comes to habitual mention of "my splendid young team", David O'Leary and Leeds United plainly hold the copyright.

Across the city Yorkshire remain a youthful side perpetually found wanting when it really matters. This year's Benson & Hedges Cup will offer no release from a succession of cup near-misses and fading championship challenges after Surrey, the epitome of uncompromising county professionalism, held sway by seven runs in a quarter-final they had little right to survive.

Surrey's streetwise nature was exemplified, not for the first time, by Alec Stewart, who yearns to regain the England one-day role that he lost in South Africa last winter and, after making 97 from 142 balls, was not shy of advertising the fact. "I want my place back," he said. "I'm available either as a batsman or a wicketkeeper; it's entirely up to the selectors."

Stewart's unyielding professionalism was equally apparent in the field. Darren Lehmann, his half-century freshly secured, looked to be leading Yorkshire to victory, with seven wickets left to get the last 75 at only four an over, but the Australian was adjudged caught down the legside when the ball patently flicked a stray pad-strap. Noisy appeal from Stewart and Adam Hollioake was upheld.

For all that, Yorkshire should have won. They had won an influential toss under overcast skies and Matthew Hoggard, bowling splendidly to take four wickets in his first seven overs, tore through the top order. Surrey's recovery to 198 for six was more than they had hoped for.

Hoggard, with his No1 cut and stocky build, so much resembles a rugby league second-row forward that it was easy to imagine that he had wandered over from the other side of the football stand after a session barging aside tackle bags.

He passed the winter in South Africa, as Free State's overseas professional, and used the new ball shrewdly from the moment he swung his first ball between bat and pad to bowl Mark Butcher.

Ally Brown was bowled off his thigh pad in Hoggard's third over, with the bowler momentarily breaking off from his appeal to pick something out of his teeth, perhaps the remains of a youth team winger who had inadvisedly strayed into his path.

Graham Thorpe was leg-before for nought as he pushed hesitantly forward; if he is picked for the Lord's Test it will be on reputation rather than form. Adam Hollioake became Hoggard's final victim when he worked a straight ball to leg and fell at second slip.

An edge from Stewart, when two, grazed the hand of the diving David Byas at second slip. Had that stuck, for Surrey it might have been terminal. But Stewart, in crisp form, found an ally in Ben Hollioake and they added 96 in 21 overs.

If the young all-rounder can play a mature match, then no one is irretrievable. He needed a let-off when only two, when television replays suggested he was caught at the wicket off Gavin Hamilton. When, with overs running out, he upped the risk, he was caught off Craig White on the cover boundary after being dropped the ball before.

Ben Hollioake's impressive day did not end there. He clung to two rasping catches at gully to dismiss White and Richard Blakey in an early Yorkshire collapse; it was his wicket which ended Matthew Wood's prudent half-century, and it was his direct hit from cover which ran out Hamilton with 16 needed from 13 balls.

Stewart even found time to lay down an appropriate challenge. "He has come back from a winter in Perth more mature on and off the field," he said. "He has seen others take his England place. Let's see how long it lasts."

 The final day of West Indies' test against Pakistan in Guyana was washed out and the match abandoned as a draw.

webTitle: Harvey in a class of his own

fields.headline: Harvey in a class of his own
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 237-7
Sussex 208-9
Gloucestershire win by 29 runs
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 237-7
Sussex 208-9
Gloucestershire win by 29 runs
fields.body:
There are some Australians who take to county cricket like ducks to water - lead ducks. Mostly they have been giants but Derbyshire cannot fathom how Michael Slater failed them and Yorkshire are equally bewildered over Greg Blewett's dismal summer last year.

Some Gloucestershire members must have wondered whether they had signed an Australian pup when Ian Harvey, in his debut season last year, scored only 429 championship runs and took 31 wickets, even though his ability to bowl at the death was a sizeable factor in the county's double one-day success.

He had back trouble, at the start, and in chilly April he looked as cold as Captain Oates. But when he is fit and the sun shines, as it did yesterday, he is a fine cricketer.

The Victorian was the pick as this well-drilled one-day side beat Sussex, who look something of a one-man team these days, by 29 runs.

First he scored a violent 88 from 70 deliveries, thumping 11 fours and two sixes, pulling Robin Martin-Jenkins over square-leg and Umer Rashid over midwicket. Previously his best one-day score had been the 71 he made for Victoria against Queensland and, for Gloucestershire, 47 in the National League.

Yesterday he was their best bowler too, returning figures of 10-1-28-3 in the hazy heat. Sussex had no answer. Or rather they had one answer, as they have for most of this short season.

Michael Bevan, who had scored 333 for once out in the one-day game this season, batted with his usual fluent freedom and scored 71 from 85 balls, with eight fours, as Sussex pursued 239. But once again he looked like Horatio holding the bridge.

This is being a little unfair on Jamie Carpenter, who scored a decent and undefeated 50, his first in the competition. His stand of 61 in 14 overs with Bevan threatened to take the cup out of the holders' hands.

But once Bevan swept the ball to Mark Alleyne at midwicket Sussex and their long tail, who already needed eight an over, were out of it. They finished on 208 for nine.

Martin-Jenkins had got Sussex off to a firm start after Gloucestershire had chosen to bat, running out Tim Hancock with a direct throw from mid-off and then taking the next two wickets. He finished with two for 24.

When Kim Barnett was also run out the visitors were in trouble at 54 for four. But Chris Adams at slip dropped Alleyne off Martin-Jenkins at the start of Alleyne's innings and the recovery began. Gloucestershire's fifth-wicket partnership was the fulcrum of their innings. Harvey and Alleyne (42) added 132 in 21 overs.

It is in the field, however, that Gloucestershire are really impressive. Alleyne led with keen thoughtfulness. They also have two spinners in Martyn Ball and Jeremy Snape; Harvey and Alleyne himself, who are expert at mixing it up with the ball; and James Averis, a young fast bowler who went into the match with 20 one-day wickets in this embryonic summer.

fields.headline: Fairbrother restores the old order
fields.standfirst:
Durham 154
Lancashire 158-7
Lancashire win by three wickets
fields.trailText:
Durham 154
Lancashire 158-7
Lancashire win by three wickets
fields.body:
Chris Schofield and Steve Harmison may be two bright young bowlers earmarked to play a big part in England's future. But, while the spinner impressed with four wickets, suggestions that Harmison is ready for a test career looked literally wide of the mark yesterday.

However, Schofield did not have to bowl at Neil Fairbrother. At 36, the little left-hander remains the master of a one-day run chase and his 23rd B&H half-century not only destroyed Harmison, who bowled eight critical wides, but also steered Lancashire from 35 for five to a relatively comfortable three-wicket victory.

It is the first time they have reached the semi-finals of this competition since they last won it, in 1995 and 1996. But as Fairbrother, who won the gold award, and Lancashire have a remarkable unbeaten record in 10 semi-finals since 1984, Gloucestershire will not be relishing the prospect of facing them in two weeks' time, especially as their formidable batting line-up will surely not flop as badly as this.

A Lancashire landslide looked likely after Durham were dismissed for 154 in 46.5 overs, with nothing save the occasional spot of variable bounce and turn for Schofield in the pitch. It was good bowling first from Ian Austin, who trundled in as unfussily and effectively as ever to earn figures of 10-3-16-2, then Schofield which put the skids under Durham, for whom only the left-handed Australian Simon Katich batted with any authority.

However, Lancashire were in danger of squandering their good work as Mike Atherton lost his off stump trying to work Melvyn Betts through the leg-side - not a bad ball - then Jon Wood had John Crawley caught at second slip and bowled Andy Flintoff and Sourav Ganguly.

When Graham Lloyd chopped on, the four coachloads of Durham supporters had good reason to be hopeful of a first victory over Lancashire since their first Sunday League match in 1992.

But the sight of Warren Hegg was a warning not to count chickens, and Lancashire's reliable wicketkeeper joined Fairbrother in a sixth-wicket partnership of 73. Schofield fidgeted and fretted like a left-handed Derek Randall to no great effect, taking 20 balls to get off the mark, before edging Wood to second slip to give the seamer a deserved fourth wicket.

However, Austin defied the potential curse of having the size of his benefit collection, £889.25, announced on his way to the crease, nudging Lancashire to victory in the 45th over, with considerable assistance from Fairbrother and Harmison. The tall 21-year-old, who had conceded three wides in his first spell, returned in the 39th over to bowl five more.

Yet he had offered a brief glimpse of his potential in his dismissal of Hegg, who was bowled and hurt by a brute of a ball which clattered into the stumps off his ribs. If Harmison had been given a central contract, England's coach Duncan Fletcher would be entitled to wonder whether playing one-day cricket is doing him any good.

fields.headline: Pitch leaves Smith feeling flat
fields.standfirst:
Glamorgan 182-6
Hampshire 69
Glamorgan win by 113 runs
fields.trailText:
Glamorgan 182-6
Hampshire 69
Glamorgan win by 113 runs
fields.body:
Hampshire strengthened their bowling attack in the winter. Perhaps they should have given some thought to their batting line-up as well.

The arrival of Shane Warne and Alan Mullally demonstrated the county's intent - and the extent of the financial backing - but their batting here, in keeping with their season thus far, was so feeble that they look destined to fall short of their high expectations. Money does not yet guarantee success in cricket.

In defence of Hampshire the Sophia Gardens pitch was poor. It was slow and void of bounce. Hampshire's captain Robin Smith gave it the sort of pummelling he normally reserves for wayward bowling. "I sympathise with the Glamorgan players if they're going to go playing on pitches like this all summer," he said. "It's certainly not a place I would like to play my cricket. For people wanting to go on and play test cricket it's not a place to learn. It's a non-cricket wicket."

It would be unfair, however, to blame the groundsman Len Smith. Hospitality tents covered the entire ground during last autumn's rugby World Cup. He has been left to repair the damage to the square.

Even so, contrast Hampshire's batting failures with Glamorgan's resilience. The home side batted when the pitch was damp and the weather overcast. Peter Hartley and Dmitri Mascarenhas used the conditions so well that the first 20 overs yielded 48 runs as well as the importunate wickets of Matthew Elliott, Robert Croft and Matthew Maynard.

These games often throw up unlikely match winners, however. Keith Newell, who arrived from Sussex last season, made his most telling contribution for the county. His innings of 49 from 66 balls looks no more than worthy on paper but psychologically it was the difference between a winning and losing total. Adrian Dale gave him sensible stability with 63 not out, and together they put on 99 in 18 overs.

Robin Smith's strange decision to allow the off-spinner Shaun Udal eight overs and restrict the medium pace of John Stephenson to two overs also helped their cause.

Glamorgan have lost seven of their eight previous Benson & Hedges Cup quarter-finals so it was easy to understand the pessimism of their supporters at the change of innings. They need not have worried. Within 12 overs Hampshire were 16 for five.

Owen Parkin, who from a distance resembles Glenn McGrath, bowled a bit like him as well. He took the first three wickets, all leg-before. He also found a reliable ally in Graham Burgess, who is not from the Steve Bucknor school of umpiring. Burgess's finger goes up with the appeal.

Steve Watkin, one of a quartet of Glamorgan thirtysomethings who are desperate to reach a first Lord's final, ensured there would be no recovery. He had Smith caught low down in the gully and Stephenson leg-before next ball.

The rest came and went as if they were resigned to their fate, beaten by the pitch as much as by their determined opponents.
