fields.headline: Barcelona 2 - 1 Valencia
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Barcelona: Hesp, Reiziger, Guardiola, Abelardo, Figo, Cocu, Kluivert, Rivaldo, F. de Boer, Zenden, Xavi. Subs: Arnau, Dehu, Litmanen, Sergi, Garcia Lara, Simao, Mario.

Valencia: Canizares, Pellegrino, Djukic, G. Mendieta, Lopez, Farinos, Angulo, Gerard, Carboni, Gonzalez, Angloma. Subs: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Sanchez, Albelda, Gerardo.

Referee: Vitor Manuel Melo Pereira (Portugal)

Luis Figo could return for Barcelona as they look to recover from a three-goal deficit at the Nou Camp. The Portugese international missed the first leg with a thigh injury but has now been passed fit.

Ronlad de Roer, Luis Enrique Martinez, Winston Bogarde and Carles Putol are injured and Gabri Barcia suspended.

Valencia are set to field the same 11 who played the first leg, with six of those carrying yellow cards.

1 Valencia kick-off with a punt back into their own half and immediately spray the ball out to the right.
2 Both teams happy to treat the opening minutes as a warm-up.
3 Rivaldo makes a run through midfield but is brought down on the edge of the Valencia area.
4 Rivaldo works himself into space again on the edge of the area, plays the ball back for Guardiola to release Figo on the right. His cross is easy for Canizares.
6 Predictably, it is Barcelona who are make the early running while Valencia show reluctance to commit forward in numbers. Nevertheless, Barcelona are unable to force the pace they way they did against Chelsea.
8 Valencia begin to work their way upfield but Barcelona keep them well away from the penalty area.
10 Barcelona indulge in a bout of passing back to the 'keeper as they play a waiting game and attempt to force errors.
12 Kluivert picks up possession on the edge of the area but fails to find Figo who is making a run ahead of him.
14 First clear chance of the match. Figo dodges and shimmies his way into space near the right corner flag, but Rivaldo is unable to make the most of the hard-fought cross.
15 Valencia err when they allow Rivaldo the space to turn and shoot from the edge of the area but Canizares gets down well to save.
17 Kluivert blows a chance to score for Barcelona. A deep, looping ball finds him running, onside, into the 18-yard box but Djukic blocks well as the Dutchman attempts to improve his position.The ball comes out to Rivaldo, his back heel finds Figo in space but Canizares saves.
21 Zenden and Guardiola exchange passes around the edge of the area as Barcelona step up pressure on the Valencia goal. Figo looking a constant menace out on the right for Barcelona.
23 Barcelona win a corner, but Abelardo fails to get his header on target.
24 Zenden, not to be outdone by Figo, makes a surging run on the left, crosses but Djukic again is the man who snuffs out the threat.
25 Gonzalez wastes a good chance for Valencia when he shoots wildly with his left foot instead of looking around him.
26 Reiziger finds Kluivert running into the Valencia area, but the ball runs behind him and Valencia clear.
29 Valencia win a free-kick 30 yards out; Gonzalez takes but hits the wall.
30 Valencia making inroads into the Barcelona half as Angloma and 'keeper Hesp collide trying to reach a looping centre.
32 Lopez comes close to sealing the tie for Valencia when his turn-and-shot from 20 yards flies just wide of the far post.
34 Booking Lopez, bringing total number of Valencia players on yellow up to seven.
36 Booking Carboni. The resulting free-kick is rifled into the Valencia six-yard box towards Frank de Boer but he is unable to get in a shot.
38 Booking Guardiola for a foul on Pellegrino.
39 Mendieta lets rip with a 20-yard shot for Valencia but fails to miss 'keeper Hesp.
41 Angloma looking dangerous for Valencia with his runs down the right and consistently accurate crosses.
43 Figo weaves his way to the edge of the area but a one-two with Rivaldo fails to create the space for a shot.
45 Both teams play out the half with end-to-end action but no concrete chances. Half-time. So far so good for Valencia, but Barcelona will wish they had done more with the possession they enjoyed in the first 45.

webTitle: Last-ditch deal gives Wembley go-ahead at last

fields.headline: Last-ditch deal gives Wembley go-ahead at last
fields.trailText: The building of the new Wembley stadium has been virtually assured by an agreement between developers and the local authority over how much they should pay to improve transport facilities around the state-of-the-art venue planned.
fields.body:
The building of the new Wembley stadium has been virtually assured by an agreement between developers and the local authority over how much they should pay to improve transport facilities around the state-of-the-art venue planned.

The deal between Wembley National Stadium Ltd (WNSL), the FA subsidiary set up to oversee construction, and Brent borough council will come as a huge relief for the organisers of England's 2006 World Cup bid, who have been using the new stadium as one of their campaign's main selling points.

The company has been at loggerheads with Brent officials over the past few months over the level of contribution to the upgrading of links for the new stadium. Brent was demanding £30m towards redeveloping roads, railway and underground stations around Wembley while WNSL initially refused to pay anything. A later offer of less than £2m was rejected by the council.

The deadlock threatened to scupper England's 2006 chances given that the future of Wembley would have been in question when Fifa came to make its decision on July 6.

WNSL, led by Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates, has now offered £17m, with the government also agreeing to chip in. Brent council could now end up with as much as £25m for work that will focus on roads and the two overground and one underground rail stations for spectators.

Councillors are now likely to give planning permission for the new stadium at a meeting on May 30. Planning officials were about to publish a controversial report today criticising the design and urging councillors to reject the application because of the financial row.

That report will now be revised to recommend that councillors should give the go-ahead to the £475m project.

The council is also seeking written guarantees over when and how the contribution will be paid.

Once permission is granted, the stadium will be completed in 2003 with demolition work due to begin later this year.

Paul Daisley, leader of Brent council, said: "I am increasingly confident that my officers will soon be in a position to recommend approval for the planning application. After several months of negotiations we now believe there's enough money on the table to provide a safe and effective transport system for visitors and to minimise the negative impact the stadium will have upon residents and businesses."

A spokesman for England's 2006 World Cup bid welcomed news of the deal, saying: "Wembley is the jewel in the crown of the bid. It's good to have the issue settled; we are very optimistic."

fields.headline: Day one: a period stinker
fields.standfirst: In the first our exclusive reports direct from Cannes, Fiachra Gibbons is unimpressed by Vatel, and looks to Depardieu for the real day's entertainment
fields.trailText: In the first our exclusive reports direct from Cannes, Fiachra Gibbons is unimpressed by Vatel, and looks to Depardieu for the real day's entertainment
fields.body:
Tradition indicates that the Cannes Film Festival should start with a stinker and so it proved this year, as British director Roland Joffe obliged with Vatel - a steaming pile of period powdered wigs. Not even star names like Gerard Depardieu and Uma Thurman, nor a supporting cast thick with Brits (including Tim Roth, Timothy Spall, Julian Sands and performance poet Murray Lachlan Young making his film debut) could salvage a fumbled enterprise. While Tom Stoppard allegedly had a hand in the script, the result lacks the populist dash and expertise of last year's Shakespeare in Love.

In the event we had to wait until the press conference for any real entertainment. Depardieu totally out-shone a nervous and bored-looking Thurman, treating the press to his views on group sex, philosophy, food and what he termed "the ecclesiastical joys".

Starring Depardieu as the titular cook, Vatel revolves around a visit of the Sun King, Louis XIV, to one of his courtiers, and was shot in English but financed by French money. Yet Depardieu brushed aside suggestions that the picture was an example of how French cinema was finally selling out to the all-powerful English-language industry. "No, no, no - English frees me up," the actor insisted. "Even if I don't always understand what I'm saying."

Vatel may have been a trial for its audience, but the cast appear to have enjoyed the experience of making it. Julian Sands (co-starring as Louis's gay brother who - believe it or not - makes a pass at Depardieu) said that he relished dressing up in the 18th century wigs and high heels. "I loved it," Sands told the press. "Some days I got to wear two wigs. And the shoes - it's wonderful what a few inches can do.. This part has given me the liberty to explore behaviour that is not a part of my domestic life, but soon might be."

This afternoon Cannes returns to less frivolous business with a screening of Things You Can Tell, the directorial debut of Rodrigo Garcia - the son of revered novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

webTitle: Taming of PMQs starts Commons reform

fields.headline: Taming of PMQs starts Commons reform
fields.trailText: The twice-weekly slanging match of Prime Minister's Question Time is to be scrapped by Tony            Blair, who confessed to hating the ordeal when he was leader of the opposition.
fields.body:
The twice-weekly slanging match of Prime Minister's Question Time is to be scrapped by Tony Blair, who confessed to hating the ordeal when he was leader of the opposition.

Downing Street confirmed yesterday that it will be replaced by a half-hour session each Wednesday and that some of the ritual and antiquated language attached to it will be abandoned.

Questioning of the Prime Minister began 270 years ago but it was only in 1961 that it settled into the twice-weekly formula.

The first session of PMQs under the new rules - and the first with Mr Blair as Prime Minister - will be a week on Wednesday.

Ann Taylor, Leader of the House, said: 'The Government is committed to reforming and modernising the House of Commons to make Parliament fit for the 21st century.'

PMQs were popular with journalists and television viewers, abroad as well as at home, because of the bear-pit atmosphere. They also had an impact on backbenchers, whose morale could rise or fall according to how their leader performed.

A Downing Street spokesman said the aim was to replace entertainment politics with good politics.

Mr Blair telephoned John Major, the Leader of the Opposition, and Paddy Ashdown, the Liberal Democrat leader, to inform them of the change.

Mr Major criticised Mr Blair for imposing the change without consulation. He said question time was a burden to any prime minister 'but that is the point of it'.

He added: 'It makes the prime minister directly accountable to parliament. The size of the Government's majority in the House at present makes that accountability more important and not less.'

Time-wasting responses, which often confused the public, will be scrapped. Until now, after the Prime Minister set out his engagements for the day, each questioner had to ask again what the engagements were and the Prime Minister replied: 'I refer the honourable member to the reply I gave some moments ago.'

Henceforth, the MP will be able to go straight into a supplementary question.

Labour will also look at whether the questions should continue to be 'open' as at present, able to raise almost any issue, or 'closed', in which case MPs would have to give notice of the question, which would benefit the Prime Minister.

Labour will argue that closed questions allow the Prime Minister to give detailed and considered replies but the Conservatives will argue that it makes it difficult to catch the Prime Minister off guard.

Mr Blair, on Desert Island Discs, admitted he disliked intensely the two days on which PMQs were held. Mr Ashdown also found it difficult.

fields.headline: Al Purdy
fields.standfirst: Poetic voice for the loneliness and majesty of Canada's open spaces
fields.trailText: The Canadian poet Al Purdy, who has died of lung cancer aged 81, observed that he wrote poems like spiders spin webs, and for much the same reason - to support his existence. He published more than 30 volumes of poetry, a novel, A Splinter In The Heart (1990), nine collections of essays and correspondence and an autobiography, Reaching For The Beaufort Sea (1993).
fields.body:
The Canadian poet Al Purdy, who has died of lung cancer aged 81, observed that he wrote poems like spiders spin webs, and for much the same reason - to support his existence. He published more than 30 volumes of poetry, a novel, A Splinter In The Heart (1990), nine collections of essays and correspondence and an autobiography, Reaching For The Beaufort Sea (1993).

He wrote of farmers and lumberjacks, drinkers and brawlers, and captured the loneliness and majesty of Ontario, the tundra of the far north and the rain forests of Haida Gwaii. In one of his most famous poems, The Country North Of Belleville, Purdy wrote: "And this is a country where the young leave quickly/ unwilling to know what their fathers know/ or think the words their mothers do not say."

As the late critic George Woodcock observed, he "evokes, as few other writers have done so vividly, the sense of Canada as an old country resonant with echoes."

Purdy was born at Wooler, near Kingston, Ontario, "of degenerate loyalist stock," as he put it. Largely self-educated, he earned his first royalty at the age of 13, when he was paid $1 for a poem in his high school magazine. He didn't write seriously for another 30 years.

Dropping out of school to ride the railways during the depression, he eventually reached Vancouver, where he took a series of manual jobs. During the second world war he served in the Royal Canadian Air Force, and his first collection of poems, The Enchanted Echo, was published in 1944, while he was still in uniform. The collection, he recalled, "was so bad that I would blush to look at it now, if I was given to blushing, which I'm not."

After that, Purdy mostly roamed the country, stopping wherever he could find work, until he settled in Ameliasburgh, a farming community first settled after the American revolution by displaced British loyalists. The area is celebrated in many of his most famous poems.

By the early 1960s, he was able to earn enough money from poetry and freelance journalism to support his family. Brash, hard-drinking and belligerent, he once described himself as "six foot three of indolence, two hundred pounds of weed,/ my better judgment voted me least likely to succeed."

Purdy learned his craft through practice and experimentation. "Your first way," he told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation last year, "is to admit that you're not so good." His own transformation from "writing doggerel" came when he began composing completely free verse that did not depend on rhyme. In his 1974 collection, In Search Of Owen Roblin, Purdy explained: "All the things I write about I've done myself/ if not with hands, but with my mind/ I am a screen thru which the world passes/ a thermometer registering pain and sorrow."

Purdy came from an era of Canadian poets - such as Irving Layton, Alden Nowlan, Earle Birney and Milton Acorn - celebrated in the heady nationalist ambience of the 1960s and 1970s. Generous with his time and encouragement, he inspired younger poets, such as Dennis Lee, for whom Purdy's poetry tapped into "an amazing range of emotions and facets of people's lives. He created an English Canadian voice that could range from everyday vernacular to soaring eloquence."

"The only thing that equals writing what you think is a good poem is to write another just as good," Purdy wrote in his autobiography. "It is like coming home after a long absence, and knowing the trees and water and land are yours, your land; or waking up with the woman you have known all your life, and knowing she is your life; to feel the boundaries of yourself widen and expand in the sober drunkenness of your brain."

When Collected Poems was published in 1986, it had to be set in small type so that the poems could be crammed into 400 pages. Yet the book was only a selection of his work, and not the last volume of a man still writing and arguing about Yeats on his deathbed. A final collection of poems, Beyond Remembering, will be published in September.

Purdy won Canada's highest literary honour, the Governor-General's Award, for The Cariboo Hunters (1965) and later for the Collected Poems. He was a member of both the Order of Canada and of Ontario.

He is is survived by his wife, Eurithe Mary Jane Parkhurst, whom he married in 1941, and their son.

"It is like coming home after a long absence, and knowing the trees and water and land are yours, your land; or waking up with the woman you have known all your life, and knowing she is your life; to feel the boundaries of yourself widen and expand in the sober drunkenness of your brain." When Collected Poems was published in 1986, it had to be set in small type so that the poems could be crammed into 400 pages. Yet the book was only a selection of his work, and not the last volume of a man still writing and arguing about Yeats on his deathbed. A final collection of poems, Beyond Remembering, will be published in September. Purdy won Canada's highest literary honour, the Governor-General's Award, for The Cariboo Hunters (1965) and later for the Collected Poems. He was a member of both the Order of Canada and of Ontario. He is is survived by his wife, Eurithe Mary Jane Parkhurst, whom he married in 1941, and their son. Alfred 'Al' Wellington Purdy, poet, born December 30 1918; died April 21 2000

fields.headline: Tory peers in ethics row
fields.trailText: May 10 2000: Lord Strathclyde defends peers business interests
fields.body:
Tories yesterday accused Labour of trying to set a political agenda for the ethics watchdog Lord Neill's forthcoming inquiry into peers' business interests.

The attack, led by Tory opposition leader Lord Strathclyde , comes as Conservative peer Lord Rees Mogg will try today to pre-empt an inquiry by the committee of standards into public life by pressing for a rival inquiry run by peers themselves.

Lord Neill has cancelled an appearance before the Commons public administration committee so he can explain to peers how he intends to have a wide-ranging impartial inquiry into the need for high standards of probity in the upper house.

Lord Strathclyde said yesterday that "it is becoming increasingly obvious that this whole process has been politicised". He claimed that central to the inquiry was a proposal that opposition spokesman should divest themselves of their business interests, and that this idea had been put to the committee by Fraser Kemp, MP for Houghton and Washington East. Mr Kemp is one of Labour's election co-ordinators.

Last night the Tory attack was criticised by Lord Neill's committee, who said the idea was neither central to the investigation, nor had it originated from the government.

It is likely that the committee, which includes prominent Conservatives such as former cabinet minister John Macgregor as well as Labour stalwarts like Lord Shore, will examine the issue as part of a much wider examination of House of Lords procedures.

The committee will also investigate whether the Lords register of interests should be tightened, making it compulsory to declare all interests, and whether to introduce an "advocacy rule" which bans peers promoting private bills and sponsoring motions where they have business interests. This was introduced in the Commons.

Lord Neill is said to have been influenced by Tory peer Lord Wakeham's observation that the Lords was now more a target for lobbyists than the Commons.

fields.headline: They spy strangers
fields.standfirst: The Lords must not bar Lord Neill
fields.trailText: May 20 2000, leader: The Lords must not bar Lord Neill
fields.body:
In the House of Lords today the crossbencher Lord Rees-Mogg will be telling Lord Neill of Bladen, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, to keep his prying nose out of House of Lords business. Not in those terms of course: altercations in the Lords are invariably conducted in terms of exquisite courtesy.

But that is the essential message of a motion tabled by Lord Rees-Mogg and supported by the former Tory leader of the House, Lord Cranborne, which asserts that any inquiry into the conduct of peers is a matter for peers themselves. Rees-Mogg and chums claim the intrusion of Lord Neill and his colleagues into the affairs of the Lords affronts its independence. If Lord Neill had arrived with a set of regulations and tried to impose them unilaterally on an unwilling house, that objection might carry some weight. But as he made clear in announcing his intentions, the most he is seeking to do is to compile a report which the Lords will be free to accept, amend or reject. It is true that peers have less scope to misbehave than MPs, but they have the right to speak and to vote on legislation and privileged access to ministers, which makes them an entirely proper subject for investigation by any inquiry into standards in public life.

There breathes through Lord Rees-Mogg and his motion the continuing conviction that the Lords is a private club which ought to be spared the vulgar intrusions of meddlers, even those inspired by the public interest. As Lord Neill has mordantly pointed out, Lord Cranborne, when still a Conservative minister, told the house in October 1994: "So far as I am aware, your lordships are members of parliament. I therefore have to conclude that your lordships are indeed within the scope of the investigations of the committee. I am sure that your lordships would not wish it to be any other way." Nor should they. They should tell Lord Rees-Mogg today to get lost. In terms of exquisite courtesy, naturally.

fields.headline: Labour deputy for mayor Livingstone
fields.standfirst: Agreement between Livingstone and his former party over tube modernisation panel paves way for Nicky Gavron
fields.trailText: Labour's Nicky Gavron has accepted Ken Livingstone's offer to become his deputy, in another sign that the independent mayor and his former party may be moving towards a more harmonious relationship than the antagonistic election campaign suggested.
fields.body:
Labour's Nicky Gavron has accepted Ken Livingstone's offer to become his deputy, in another sign that the independent mayor and his former party may be moving towards a more harmonious relationship than the antagonistic election campaign suggested.

But Ms Gavron warned that she would quit the job if the independent mayor became too openly hostile towards the government.

"Ken was elected as an independent. I was elected on Labour's manifesto. I could not be deputy mayor unless Ken agreed to avoid constant conflict with the government," she said.

Ms Gavron said she was only agreeing to undertake the job for the next year, under a rotating system devised by Mr Livingstone, "following written clarification of undertakings given yesterday by the mayor".

She also warned that her party "does not see the mayoralty as a platform from which to assert political views on issues not relevant to his role."

Mr Livingstone and Labour's agreement yesterday that the options for tube modernisation should be studied by an independent panel of experts eased the way for Ms Gavron to accept the deputy mayor position.

The agreement, which Labour Party headquarters claimed as a concession by Mr Livingstone, means that an independent body will examine both the government's part-privatisation proposals and Mr Livingstone's bond scheme for financing improvements in the London Underground. The journalist Simon Jenkins, a critic of tube privatisation, is in the running to become chairman of the panel.

Labour peer and assembly member Lord Harris is likely to accept the chair of the Metropolitan police committee. The Green party's Darren Johnson, once tipped to become Mr Livingstone's deputy, has announced he will accept the environment portfolio. But Mr Livingstone's appeal for other assembly members to discard party loyalties and join his coalition has gone unheeded by the Tories, with the party's assembly group leader, Bob Neill, pledging "constructive opposition" to the mayor.

"Ken Livingstone's offered a job to everyone bar the cleaning lady as far as I can see," said Mr Neill. "What I've said to Ken is that if there is a sensible and genuine offer that's on the table, we will consider it.

"At the moment the offer of a job without portfolio in what really is a Labour and Green-dominated cabinet is not attractive."

Meanwhile, Tory leader William Hague, who earlier today held meetings with his new assembly members, challenged Labour to join the Conservatives and block any attempt by Mr Livingstone to introduce congestion taxes for drivers.

webTitle: Blair promises to protect Dagenham workers

fields.headline: Blair promises to protect Dagenham workers
fields.standfirst: Formal announcement of job losses expected by Friday
fields.trailText: Tony Blair promised that the government would do all it could to protect jobs at Dagenham as Ford announced the phasing out of car assembly at its Essex plant today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair promised that the government would do all it could to protect jobs at Dagenham as Ford announced the phasing out of car assembly at its Essex plant today.

Around 2,000 jobs are expected to go at the factory with the car manufacturer offering voluntary redundancies at other plants in a bid to avoid compulsory lay-offs.

"We will, of course, do all we can to protect those jobs that can be protected," the prime minister said. "We will be there ready to help with money, investment, help and advice for anyone that does lose their job."

Mr Blair was forced to defend his government's record on manufacturing industry in the first question time since Labour's losses in the local election. Tory leader William Hague said 206,000 manufacturing jobs had been lost while Mr Blair was in office compared to a net rise of 70,000 in employment under the last Conservative administration. He said taxes and regulation were squeezing British industry

The prime minister acknowledged the problem for manufacturers lay with the strength of the pound but said this was not helped by the opposition leader attempting to exploit it. "Your opportunism knows no bounds at all. No sooner have you had to conceal your disappointment at the Rover deal, than you leap on Ford."

Workers at Dagenham where the Fiesta is built, will receive letters on Friday before an official announcement of the cutback. Ford hopes to avoid compulsory redundancies by seeking volunteers at some of its other UK factories. The company refused to confirm details of the redundancies or expected job losses ahead of its formal meeting with union leaders on Friday in London.

The company is expected to recruit an extra 200 workers at its diesel engine plant in Dagenham under moves to lessen the impact of the announcement. Some workers at Dagenham may be able to move to other plants but those who decide to go will be eligible for redundancy payments of up to almost £40,000.

The ending of car production, although widely expected, will still come as a shock to the industry and will affect the Dagenham region, which is heavily dependent on the factory for employment.

Despite the moves to seek volunteers and create some new jobs, morale at Dagenham is said to be very low following weeks of speculation that car assembly was likely to end. Some workers have pinned posters to walls reading: "Closing down sale - everything must go."

The company employs around 26,000 workers in the UK including 8,000 at Dagenham. Ford announced earlier this year it was axing 1,300 jobs at Dagenham, which will bring the total left in employment to just over 4,000 workers after the fresh job losses.

fields.headline: Paddington inquiry
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText:
Why is there an inquiry?
31 people died when a commuter service run by Thames Trains passed a red signal on track near Ladbroke Grove station, west London, at 8am on October 5 1999, and collided with a Great Western Intercity travelling in the opposite direction. It came just two years after seven died in the Southall rail crash. Many said that a culture of profit in the privatised railways had pushed passenger safety into second place.
fields.body:
Why is there an inquiry?
31 people died when a commuter service run by Thames Trains passed a red signal on track near Ladbroke Grove station, west London, at 8am on October 5 1999, and collided with a Great Western Intercity travelling in the opposite direction. It came just two years after seven died in the Southall rail crash. Many said that a culture of profit in the privatised railways had pushed passenger safety into second place.

What will the inquiry try to find out?
Three accident reports since the crash have all concluded that the Thames train went through a signal on a red light. The inquiry's job is to establish why. The reasons are likely to be complex: some have suggested that signal 109 (which had been passed at red eight previous times) has a poor sight line and the inquiry will be investigating the signalling system as a whole. Of the companies involved, Railtrack blames the Thames train driver Michael Hodder and Thames trains blames Railtrack for the layout of the tracks outside Paddington and the siting of the signals. The last accident report said that "any action or omission on the part of the driver was only one such factor in a failure involving many contributory factors". Scottish judge Lord Cullen will chair the inquiry and submit his recommendations to the government.

What can it do?
The inquiry is not a trial. Its only concern is take evidence and establish what happened.

Have previous public inquiries been successful?
Lord Cullen chaired the inquiry into the Piper Alpha North Sea oil platform disaster in 1988 and is widely credited with changing the safety culture in that industry. However the success of any inquiry depends on what happens next. The Paddington survivors' spokesperson says the collision could have been avoided if the government had listened to the Clapham rail crash inquiry. It recommended the installation of automatic train protection (ATP) for the whole rail network after 35 people died in the rush hour collision. The government ruled it out as the £750m price tag was too high immediately prior to privatisation.

Who will be giving evidence?
Passengers, employees, corporate bodies and companies at the heart of the Paddington crash, including Railtrack, Thames Trains, First Great Western and the railway inspectorate. The two drivers involved died.

Can anyone be prosecuted after the inquiry ?
The crown prosecution service has already ruled that there is "insufficient evidence" to convict either a company or individual over the crash. The government's health and safety executive says however that it may be able to bring criminal charges against the rail companies under health and safety legislation.

How does the law work in these cases?
To secure a manslaughter conviction the law requires proof that a company director is guilty of gross negligence. In practice this means only small companies or individuals can be prosecuted for manslaughter, as it would be impossible to prove that the head of a large company employing thousands was personally responsible for a disaster. To remedy this, the Home Office wants to introduce a new crime of corporate killing.

What about Southall?
No one was prosecuted. The case went to court but the prosecutors failed to establish that Great Western Trains could be tried for manslaughter.

When will it end?
The first part of the inquiry ends in July and will be followed in September by a joint inquiry into the Paddington and Southall crashes. Lord Cullen will chair a third inquiry in November into all matters of rail safety.

webTitle: New detention centres for failed asylum seekers

fields.headline: New detention centres for failed asylum seekers
fields.trailText: The government is planning to set up two new detention centres to house failed asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The government is planning to set up two new detention centres to house failed asylum seekers.

Immigration minister Barbara Roche said that any new centres would be used to house those people who had sought asylum, had their application turned down and had exhausted the appeal procedure. "We are making many more decisions, therefore we need to remove many more people, therefore we will need more detention space," she said.

One centre could be established at Manston, Kent, and another at Thurleigh, Bedfordshire. Plans are also in the pipeline to expand existing centres near Heathrow and at Aldington, Kent.

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe welcomed confirmation of the government's plans. "But I have to say I do it with a raised eyebrow in as much as when we put forward these ideas we were accused of being racist," she said.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has received a letter from Thanet council, in Kent, protesting that the Manston centre will be built on an eight-acre site currently earmarked as a business park. "There is a clear need for a high-security detention centre to house thousands of asylum seekers awaiting the result of appeals to stay in the UK," said council leader Richard Nicholson.

"But to force the solution on a prestige business park makes no sense. We certainly can't concede prime development land, for which we have fought so hard, for an intrusive activity which creates no end product and brings no real added wealth to the area."

A Home Office spokesman said: "We have not even applied for planning permission for either of these two centres, although we have been in discussion with Bedfordshire council."

webTitle: 10 May: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: 10 May: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Ben Elton just can't get enough of Andrew Lloyd-Webber, Schwarzennger on Stallone collaboration, and, on the casting couch, Daniel Day-Lewis, Kate Beckinsale, Wes Bentley, Susan Lynch, and Denise Richards in another improbable-sounding plot.
fields.body:
TV comic Ben Elton will script the much-delayed adaptation of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Phantom Of The Opera. To the dismay of Michael Crawford fans, the film is to star Antonio Banderas, and will be directed by Elizabeth's Shekhar Kapur. Elton is currently writing a stage musical with the Tory peer Lloyd-Webber, and his directorial debut, Maybe Baby, opens in the UK at the end of the month.

Arnold Schwarzenegger, responding to rumours that he and fellow beefcake Sly Stallone are set to co-star: "It's true that Sly and I have talked about the possibility of doing a film together. It would have to be the right project and currently there's nothing on the horizon.. Sly is also a very busy guy. We'll keep looking and hopefully one day the right project will turn up."

Casting couch

 Daniel Day-Lewis is in negotiations for the co-lead role, alongside Leonardo DiCaprio and Cameron Diaz, in Martin Scorsese's Gangs of New York. The project would be the first that the idiosyncratic star has undertaken since 1997's The Boxer. Gangs centres around the attempt by a gangster (DiCaprio) to unite ethnic street gangs during a time of corruption in New York City in the 19th century.

 John Cusack and Kate Beckinsale will team up for the romantic comedy Serendipity, about two college sweethearts who reunite 10 years later - when each is on the verge of marrying someone else. Peter Chelsom will direct.

 American Beauty's Wes Bentley will star as legendary actor Montgomery Clift in the indie feature Monty. Monty follows Clift's career from 1947 up until his death in 1966, and focuses on the contrast between Clift's artistic integrity and the chaos of his personal life.

 Susan Lynch will play an alcoholic lesbian opposite Johnny Depp and Heather Graham in a new Jack the Ripper biopic. The star of the imminent James Joyce biopic Nora says of her new role: "I play Liz Stride and I'm an alcoholic - I get killed when I'm pissed. She's a prostitute who happens to be a lesbian. It's a very interesting character." Quite.

 Denise Richards will star in the romantic comedy Good Advice, opposite Charlie Sheen. The indie pic involves an investment banker who loses everything and must rediscover what's important in life - which sounds almost as convincing as Richard's Bond role as an, em, nuclear physicist.

fields.headline: Lovejoy, Match of the Day and Walking with Dinosaurs
fields.trailText: MONEY FOR NOTHING
fields.body:
MONEY FOR NOTHING

The Fiver stayed up all night last night. And not to watch highlights of the Uruguayan Cup on Channel 5. No, we were putting the final touches to our multi-million squid bid for Premiership TV rights. The proposal had to be in by 5pm this afternoon, so as you can imagine there was a lot of scampering about organising camera angles, creating a broadcast company out of nothing, etc. But we got it in, along with 75 other "bona fide" bids, and that's what counts. Isn't it?

Not quite, it seems, as the Premier League are believed to have hit on a new idea which, gasp, could net them even more money. Once the current round of closed bids has been assessed and sorted by type - ie: bids for live rights, bids for highlights and bids for footage of the boys in the team bath (that's us!) - rumours suggest that the Prem will then adopt tactics used by the government during the recent mobile-phone bandwidth auctions and have a second round of open bidding between competing companies.

If the mobile precedent is anything to go by (the government raked in £22bn when they had expected to take just £2bn) then the Prem's estimate of a £1bn bonanza might be a little under. It also raises the possibility of ITV adopting a cheeky Lovejoy approach - raising its bids higher and higher before dropping out to leave Rupert Murdoch with a huge bill for the televisual equivalent of a chipped teapot. Then again it might just mean that David Beckham gets more money to spend on tattoos. All will be revealed in June, we suppose.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SOFT, STRONG, AND STARTING ON JUNE 5

The Euro, the Fiver's cute Euro 2000 puppy, needs housetraining. It's brought to you in association with breathe, and will sit in your intray each morning next to a puddle of its own urine, keeping you up to date with everything that goes on in the lowlands this summer. To train it by issuing tactical beatings, send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line.

By the way, if you get a incomprehensible mail back, blame our software. As long as the word 'succeeded' appears on it, you're fine.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FLOYD ON TEES

Bryan Robson doesn't back losers. Apart from Paul Gascoigne. And Paul Ince. Oh, and Juninho. Nevertheless, the Fiver isn't surprised to hear that top talent-spotter Robbo is ready to pull £18m out of the long leather wallet in his long leather coat to buy Atletico Madrid success story Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Who missed a penalty which saw his team relegated last weekend.

Actually, Hasselbaink (who left Leeds last summer for Spanish glory only to experience abject failure while his old club challenged for both Premiership and Euro-Vase) is really rather good. He scored a goal every two games with Leeds, and has taken the Spanish league - which, let's face it, is ever-so-slightly better than ours - by storm, scoring 24 goals in 36 games. You can hardly blame Atletico's demise on one scuffed hoof.

So perhaps Bryan isn't as stupid as he looks (when parading a new signing at the Riverside). The only potential hitch is that Hasselbaink doesn't actually want a return to England ("I would like to stay with a Spanish club" he said today) and that Real Madrid and Valencia are both after his signature. Not that that bothers Robbo. "If you don't ask, you don't get!" he told the Journal as he flew out to Spain on a pig.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTES OF THE DAY

"I can honestly guarantee you that if Rangers joined the English Premiership they would win it within three years" - Astute football analyst Paul Gascoigne talking to the wholly-objective Rangers News.

"Lorenzo Amoruso is not a great player - he thinks he's a great player. He'd make even the slowest striker look half decent. Somebody compared him to Billy McNeill but I don't remember Billy being crap" - The equally astute Tommy Docherty offers a different view on the Scottish giants.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S WORST PLAYER OF THE SEASON 1999-2000

Who will wear John Hartson's shiny crown? Chris Sutton, Mickael Silvestre, Dagenham Davor Suker, Wim Jonk or Steffen Freund? Send your vote to the.boss@theguardian.com and wait for the result on Friday. If you're bored, set up a free email account with an amusing name and use that address to vote.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

AH, HOW WE LAUGHED

Can there be a soul in the land who hasn't raised a wry smile at the Crazy Gang's hilarious antics? Like the time Vinnie Jones gave Gazza a cheeky tug down below? Or when John 'Fash the Baptist' pushed terrified new players into a puddle to initiate them into the Wimbledon way? Now that was funny in any language - even Norwegian.

But those days are now officially over - the Dons new Puma kit (worn for the first time in their 2-2 draw with Aston Villa) has been stripped of their famous nickname. Even more sinisterly, the new kit was originally designed with the Crazy Gang logo on it before Christmas - but was later suspiciously changed. Now you don't have to eat Whiskers to smell a rather large rat... but who could have killed off the Crazy Gang?

The Fiver's chief suspect is new chairman Bjorn Rune Gjelsten. Not only does he look like the Hooded Claw from Penelope Pitstop, but he's also recently bought Sam Hammam's final 20 percent stake in the club. Furthermore he's Norwegian. But he's not the only man in our frame. Last week new manager Terry Burton claimed the players could have spirit and commitment without resorting to the "dinosaur" age - a reference, no doubt, to when Wiseodocus stalked the left wing looking for flesh, and Fashosauras Rex used its spiky elbows to make mincemeat of central defenders.

But a spokesman for Puma thinks we're talking fossilised faeces. "Simpler designs are the trend for football kits now. We talked to the fans as well as the club and they just want a cleaner product," he explained. In that case why not just sell Ben Thatcher?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Coventry's Gary McAllister and Phil Babb of Liverpool are tipped to swap clubs this summer. The 35-year-old Sky Blue captain has been tipped for a move to Anfield for some time and Babb, who was signed from Highfield Road for £3.25m some six years ago, could be used as bait.

Spurs will not be buying Calais striker Mickael Gerard, as reported in this morning's Mirror. George Graham said this afternoon in a club statement: "There is absolutely no truth in this article that can only be described as mischievous garbage designed to incite and mislead our fans. The editor of this newspaper seriously needs to review his sports department which are either under pressure to write something and make up trash or are totally lacking in any understanding of football."

Spurs look set to clinch a £7m move for tall Southampton defender Claus Lundekvam.

After they've bought Rivaldo for £2.46.

And Emile Heskey for £11m.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Former Sheffield Wednesday director Joe Ashton fears "a bloody battle" with the club's shareholders this summer if Howard Culley does not quit as chairman. "I think out of self respect our existing directors should stand down - just like John Major did after they lost the election," he said.

Uefa will not implement any increased security measures in Copenhagen for the Euro-Vase final between Arsenal and Galatasaray.

Chelsea have insisted they have received no approaches for Gianfranco Zola following reports in Turkey that the striker has agreed to join Fenerbahce next season.

The Football League have announced that the away goals rule will be scrapped in favour of penalties for this season's play-off semi-finals. If the aggregate scores are level after two legs, extra time will still be played but will be followed by a penalty shoot-out if necessary.

Blackburn Rovers have signed a four-year sponsorship deal with Time Computers.

Rangers have confirmed that captain Lorenzo Amoruso will miss the Scottish Cup final against Aberdeen on May 27. The Italian underwent surgery today on his ankle injury and will miss the final games of the season.

David Pleat today insisted David Ginola would not be sold following his bust-up with the club after being dropped against Manchester United. Pleat said: "We have no intention of selling David and I have no knowledge of any offers for him. Ginola is a great talent and a difficult one for any manager to have among his flock. But if we had two or three better players his brilliance wouldn't be so shining."

Carlisle United have sacked general manager Martin Wilkinson four days after they preserved their Football League status.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live (7.30pm)

Des Lynam tries to quips furiously but nothing is left in the tank marked 'smooth'. Meanwhile, Barcelona waste everybody's time as they try to peg back Valencia.

Whittle some more of your life away.

Goals, stars and a bad sax solo.

Tony Dunne. Right. And he is...?

The game football, brought to you by the television channel British Eurosport, the televisual home of the sport football.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

The internet's Click On Alan Green does a quick commentary before getting back to a good old barney on www.voiceoffootball.com. Look, he's having a pop at Joe "big baby" Royle. Dear me.

webTitle: Juror's racist jokes denied Asian defendant a fair trial

fields.headline: Juror's racist jokes denied Asian defendant a fair trial
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: An Asian man accused of fraud was denied a fair trial when the judge refused to discharge the jury after a juror admitted making racist jokes, the European court of human rights ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
An Asian man accused of fraud was denied a fair trial when the judge refused to discharge the jury after a juror admitted making racist jokes, the European court of human rights ruled yesterday.

The court in Strasbourg held by a majority of four-three that Kudlip Sander's right to be tried by an impartial tribunal was violated in March 1995 when the judge at Birmingham crown court allowed the jury to continue hearing the case after a juror complained of racist comments by fellow jurors.

But the court rejected Mr Sander's claim for compensation for three years in prison, lost earnings, property he had had to sell, his divorce and damage to his reputation caused by his conviction.

He claimed £458,000 for lost earnings and the forced property sale alone, but the judges said they were not satisfied that the denial of a fair trial had caused his losses - implying that they believed a substitute jury might well have convicted him on the evidence.

Mr Sander, British born but of Asian origin, stood trial with two other Asians on charges of conspiracy to defraud. During the trial a juror sent a note to the judge saying he was concerned that at least two other jurors were making racist remarks and jokes and "I fear they are going to convict the defendants not on the evidence but because they are Asian".

The judge kept the juror who sent the note apart from the others while he investigated. He called the jurors into court and told them the trial had cost "an enormous amount of money" and he did not want to halt it but would do so "if the situation demands".

He told the jurors that they had taken a solemn oath to decide the case according to the evidence and should examine their consciences overnight.

The next day all the jurors, including the one who had complained, sent the judge a letter strongly disputing the allegations of racism and assuring him they would decide according to the evidence. One juror wrote a separate letter admitting that he "might have" made some jokes, but insisting that he was not racist and had many connections among the ethnic minority communities. The judge decided not to discharge the jury.

The majority of the Strasbourg judges said the admission by one juror that he had made racist jokes and the fact that the other juror, similarly accused, had stayed silent should have alerted the judge to the fact "that there was something fundamentally wrong with the jury" and he should have discharged them.

"It is a fundamental importance in a democratic society that the courts inspire confidence in the public and, above all, as far as criminal proceedings are concerned, in the accused."

There were "clear and precise allegations that racist comments had been made by jurors called upon to try an Asian accused," the judges said.

"The court considers this to be a very serious matter given that in today's multicultural European societies, the eradication of racism has become a common goal for all contracting states."

The fact that the collective letter had been signed by the juror who made the original complaint cast doubt on the credibility of the letter. The court considered the original note was more reliable than the letter.

The trial judge's admonition to the jury was not a sufficient safeguard, said the Strasbourg judges. "Generally speaking, an admonition or direction by the judge, however clear, detailed and forceful, would not change racist views overnight."

The British judge, Sir Nicolas Bratza, delivered a dissenting judgment backed by two other judges. Sir Nicolas said he believed the trial judge had taken enough steps to dispel any risk of bias.

He could not accept that there was any inconsistency between the collective letter and the original note. The fact that the complaining juror signed the letter could mean he had had his fears dispelled.

fields.headline: Let Ken in
fields.trailText: It is to be hoped that Ken Livingstone will succeed in creating a cabinet from Labour and other political groups on the new GLA (Letters, May 8). It is possible for politicians to work well together, as Labour and Liberal Democrats have done in Bromley since 1998. If it had been possible in the early 80s, we could have backed the GLC's radical Fair Fares policy, rather than destroy it.
fields.body:
It is to be hoped that Ken Livingstone will succeed in creating a cabinet from Labour and other political groups on the new GLA (Letters, May 8). It is possible for politicians to work well together, as Labour and Liberal Democrats have done in Bromley since 1998. If it had been possible in the early 80s, we could have backed the GLC's radical Fair Fares policy, rather than destroy it.

London's electorate has also effectively said that the one member one vote system is the democratic way to elect leaders. Never again should Labour use the discredited electoral college/trade union "block vote". Livingstone was not my first choice but, like most Londoners, I believe him to be a "Labour" mayor. I would welcome him rejoining us as soon as possible.
Cllr John Holbrook
Co-leader, Bromley council
john.holbrook@bromley.gov.uk

webTitle: The end of the production line

fields.headline: The end of the production line
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas Bannister, chief business correspondent, explains Ford's decision to cease car production at Dagenham
Blair pledges to protect Dagenham
fields.trailText: Nicholas Bannister, chief business correspondent, explains Ford's decision to cease car production at Dagenham.
fields.body:
The writing was on the wall for car production at Dagenham once Ford said it would build the new version of the Fiesta at its Cologne plant in Germany.

The news that Ford is to cease building cars at its biggest UK factory, with an expected loss of around 2,000 jobs, came as a shock to union leaders. They claimed that Ford had promised to build the new model at Dagenham, where the old Fiesta was still being built.

With Fiesta production removed, Dagenham was left making just the Courier van, the Mazda 121 and diesel engines. It needed a new car to be viable as a car assembly plant.

The timing could not have been worse. Ford bosses had ordered a radical overhaul of the company's European operations to stem "unacceptable" losses.

Ford, like other car manufacturers, is burdened by overcapacity in Europe. It was a foregone conclusion that one of its European car plants would cease production.

The Dagenham plant was regarded as having an old fashioned workforce, unreceptive to modern working practices. Allegations of racism at the plant had led to unofficial walk-outs. Jac Nasser, Ford's boss, had had to fly in from the US to help revolve the problem.

None of this helped Dagenham's case for getting the contract to build a new model. In addition, the strong pound damaged the prospects of selling British-built Ford cars at competitive prices overseas.

The government, already alarmed at the prospect of thousands of Rover jobs being lost as BMW offloads the loss-making British manufacturer, has struggled to persuade Ford to change its mind. But it had nothing to offer the global company.

The severity of the problem at Dagenham was underlined in February when it switched to one-shift production, with the loss of 1,350 jobs. There was not sufficient overseas demand for its output.

By November 2001 car assembly at Dagenham will have come to a halt, and a further 3,000 jobs will have gone. Although Dagenham will continue to produce diesel engines for the Ford group, the once proud plant will have become little more than a group component supplier.

The timing could not have been worse. Ford bosses had ordered a radical overhaul of the company's European operations to stem "unacceptable" losses. Ford, like other car manufacturers, is burdened by overcapacity in Europe. It was a foregone conclusion that one of its European car plants would cease production. The Dagenham plant was regarded as having an old fashioned workforce, unreceptive to modern working practices. Allegations of racism at the plant had led to unofficial walk-outs. Jac Nasser, Ford's boss, had had to fly in from the US to help revolve the problem. None of this helped Dagenham's case for getting the contract to build a new model. In addition, the strong pound damaged the prospects of selling British-built Ford cars at competitive prices overseas. The government, already alarmed at the prospect of thousands of Rover jobs being lost as BMW offloads the loss-making British manufacturer, has struggled to persuade Ford to change its mind. But it had nothing to offer the global company. The severity of the problem at Dagenham was underlined in February when it switched to one-shift production, with the loss of 1,350 jobs. There was not sufficient overseas demand for its output. By November 2001 car assembly at Dagenham will have come to a halt, and a further 3,000 jobs will have gone. Although Dagenham will continue to produce diesel engines for the Ford group, the once proud plant will have become little more than a group component supplier.

webTitle: Sierra Leone appeals to Britain as rebels advance

fields.headline: Sierra Leone appeals to Britain as rebels advance
fields.standfirst: UN troops prepare to defend Freetown against expected RUF attack
fields.trailText: Truckloads of soldiers and militiamen, including UN troops, today rushed to defend the Sierra Leone capital of Freetown amid reports of rebel advances.
fields.body:
Truckloads of soldiers and militiamen, including UN troops, today rushed to defend the Sierra Leone capital of Freetown amid reports of rebel advances.

UN peacekeepers, the Sierra Leone army and pro-government militia fighters were heavily reinforcing the road into the capital from Waterloo, 15 miles away.

Sierra Leone had earlier today appealed to Britain to protect Freetown and stop it falling to the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF).

The country's information minister, Julius Spencer, said: "The British government has been very helpful to Sierra Leone, but we are in a crisis situation now and we believe that the British can play a very leading role and...redeem the image of the United Nations."

The arrival of British paratroopers to evacuate British nationals has restored some sense of calm to Freetown after the inept performance of UN troops, 500 of whom are being held hostage by RUF rebels. British military intervention would bring a swift end to the crisis in the former British colony, Mr Spencer asserted. "If the British government and British military provide significant support with men and materials to the UN force, the whole situation will change very quickly," he said. But Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has ruled out a combat role for British forces, although he has left open a back-up role for the paratroopers in support of the UN mission. British paratroopers have secured Freetown's Lungi airport and airlifted out some 300 people.

"(The paratroopers) are now moving from a peacekeeping mode firmly into one of defence of wherever is considered most vital and certainly if any Briton is fired on there will be a most robust response," said Brigadier David Richards, commander of British forces in Sierra Leone.

As Sierra Leone urged Britain to play a more active role, West African states warned Sierra Leone's rebel leader Foday Sankoh to stop fighting or face military action. A statement from Ecowas, the 15-member economic community of west African states, yesterday said: "Heads of state expressed their determination to use all means at their disposal, including the military option, to foil any attempt to take over power through the use of force."

The UN has requested that Nigeria assembles a rapid reaction force to bolster its beleaguered troops. But the west African states seem more inclined to send in a joint force similar to that which restored President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah to power in 1998.

Many Sierra Leoneans are terrified of Mr Sankoh's rebels and their allies, notorious for hacking limbs off civilians at the height of the civil war. The whereabouts of Sankoh remained unclear. He went missing on Monday when rival forces stormed his home after his bodyguards opened fire on a crowd of several thousand peace protesters. At least 16 people died in the incident, seven of them civilians.

webTitle: Napster in dock over online music

fields.headline: Napster in dock over online music
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A US judge has dealt a blow to Napster by ruling that the upstart song-swapping company should stand trial for alleged copyright infringement.
fields.body:
A US judge has dealt a blow to Napster by ruling that the upstart song-swapping company should stand trial for alleged copyright infringement.

If found liable, the firm, which employs only 18 people, could be liable for millions of dollars in damages.

The decision against Napster, brought by the Recording Industry Association of America, comes as a further blow to the online music business after a legal ruling against MP3.com last month.

Napster had argued that it acts as a service provider to its users and is therefore not liable for their actions. Thousands of users are able to download software provided by the California-based company to access music stored on other personal computers.

The company acts as a kind of co-op, allowing users to swap the music they own. In its defence, Napster said it warns its customers to comply with all copyright laws. It has offered to block any consumer that is found to have illegally downloaded hits covered by copyright protection.

But US District Court Judge Marilyn Patel denied Napster's claim for protection under the 1998 Digital Millennium Copyright Act late on Friday night.

She rejected the company's argument that it should be covered by the same copyright protection as an internet service provider, which is not liable for many of the actions of its users.

The case is expected to set a benchmark for copyright protection in the internet age. The recording industry association, which represents all the main record labels, welcomed the ruling yesterday, which is expected to lead to a trial within the coming weeks.

In a statement after the ruling was delivered, Hillary Rosen, president of the association said: "Napster just lost its last delaying tactic.

"This hearing was Napster's attempt to escape responsibility for aiding and abetting wide-scale piracy and, not surprisingly, they lost.

"Napster is about facilitating piracy, and trying to build a business on the backs of artists and copyright owners," she added.

Individual artists, including heavy metal group Metallica and rapper Dr Dre, have also brought lawsuits against Napster which allege copyright infringement.

Analysts believe that the fledgling company could face bankruptcy if the industry's demands for damages worth $100,000 per infringement are agreed by the courts.

However, the recording industry faces an uphill struggle against online companies that have taken advantage of the increasing popularity of MP3, which allows users to download music from the web.

Other companies to offer an MP3 service include Wrapster, Spinfrenzy and Gnutella.

fields.headline: Caught in the act
fields.standfirst: The new act due to become law is being viewed gleefully by prisoners, yet the service is burying its head in the sand, claims Frank Michael
fields.trailText: The new act due to become law is being viewed gleefully by prisoners, yet the service is burying its head in the sand, claims Frank Michael
fields.body:
On October 2, the Human Rights Act, which brings the European Convention on Human Rights into our law, comes fully into force. Prisoners and their lawyers are preparing to challenge prison service policies and practices right across the board - yet the prison service has published an astonishing document advising its 41,000 or so employees that the best thing they can do is to stick their heads in the sand.

Governors and their staff - and, indeed, the courts - are anticipating a rash of litigation come this autumn. Jane Kennedy, junior minister in the Lord Chancellor's department, forecasts a doubling in the number of applications for judicial review. Many of those applications, as at present, will be from serving prisoners. They tend to be litigious for, as Sir Stephen Tumim, former chief inspector of prisons, once wrote: "A prisoner, as a result of being in prison, is particularly vulnerable to arbitrary and unlawful action."

The prison service, however, states: "We believe that none of our policies need to be changed... Existing instructions accord with the act and must continue to be followed. In this sense, the Human Rights Act does not change our operating framework in any way."

The family of Zahid Mubarek, who died in March following an attack while he was in Feltham young offenders institution, or those of the dozens of suicide victims from within the prison population every year, might think that the positive duty to ensure the right to life, under the act, had in some way been infringed.

Those allegedly assaulted by the 27 Wormwood Scrubs staff presently suspended, or those handcuffed while giving birth or while in a hospice bed, might argue that they had been subjected to "inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment", which is prohibited by the act.

Prisoners located hundreds of miles from their homes, or denied conjugal visits or artificial insemination, or those in mother and baby units eventually separated from their children, might assert an infringement of their right to family life. Those whose letters are routinely read by prison staff might perceive a lack of respect for correspondence and seek the act's protection.

Prisoners who face internal disciplinary proceedings, without legal representation, before a governor who can impose up to 42 additional days' imprisonment, will contend that such hearings are not before "an independent and impartial tribunal". The same might be said by staff about their disciplinary hearings.

Prisoners like Ian Simms and Michael O'Brien, who maintain that they were wrongly convicted of murder and who took their cases to the House of Lords since their access to journalists was inhibited or forbidden, will challenge the curtailment of their right to freedom of expression.

The act affords the right to elections "which will ensure the free expression of the opinion of the people". But convicted prisoners are disenfranchised - a prohibition which may itself be declared incompatible with convention rights under section 4 of the act. Lord Bassam, Home Office minister in the Lords, recently told the House that such prisoners had forfeited "the moral right" to vote - a view unlikely to hold sway with the courts after October. And there will be many more challenges.

There are some people - prison service officials among them - who find reassurance in the historically conservative attitude of the judges when dealing with prisoners' rights.

But they ignore the words of Lord Leigh in the 1998 debate on the act at bill stage. He asserted that "this is a new bill of rights, based on the Convention. United Kingdom judges can, and I believe will, go much further than the Convention." Likewise, writing in the Guardian on April 20, Hugo Young predicted a judiciary required "to go beyond the letter of the arid statute and investigate its connection with larger principles."

If prisons are unprepared for the act, they are certainly unprepared for judges who might go further than it requires. The prison service advice is that: "If changes are thought necessary, new prison service instructions will be issued."

Anxious governors will, no doubt, hope that such instructions will be issued well before prisoners' claims start to pile up on their desks in less than six months' time.

 Frank Michael worked in prisons for 20 years and is now a freelance writer.

webTitle: Time to lock up your sons?

fields.headline: Time to lock up your sons?
fields.standfirst: What message does the stabbing of a young boy in a crowded street send to parents?  Angela Phillips  says that however much we fear for them, we still have to allow children out alone
fields.trailText: What message does the stabbing of a young boy in a crowded street send to parents? Angela Phillips says that however much we fear for them, we still have to allow children out alone
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy is stabbed to death on a crowded London street, yards away from his home. His 15-year-old brother is lying, injured, in hospital. Every parent reading this story sees a picture of their own son lying there in a pool of blood. We read the facts, checking for any details which might have rendered our own children equally vulnerable. We check our own actions and wonder whether there is anything that we are doing/not doing which might place our own children at similar risk. Only then, when we feel sure that our children are safe, do we stop and think about the parents for whom this occurrence is a real and devastating event, one which will change their lives utterly and forever.

In reality the murder of Diego Pineiro-Villar in Covent Garden on Sunday night, is an extraordinarily rare event. Last year there were only five murders of children between the age of 5 and 14 in England and Wales. Even if you add the 14 who died of injuries which may have been purposely inflicted, our children are 40 times more likely to die on the roads. And yet there is something about this murder which cuts straight to that primitive fear of the sinister Pied Piper lurking at the school gates ready to take our children away.

It is this reflex, this shiver of fear for our own children, which takes this murder off the crime pages and onto the parents page. Our instinct is to use this as some kind of object lesson, something for which policy should be developed. We look for scapegoats outside the realms of crime and punishment. Questions will be asked about where the parents were at that precise time; the police will be quizzed about why such a crime was allowed to happen; the school will be provided with money to build higher security gates - all of it in an attempt to quieten our own beating hearts, our fear that our children could be next.

The details of the case will be poured over when it finally comes to court. On the basis of what we know now it seems clear that the Diego's school had already taken precautions to safeguard him from the attentions of an older man who had struck up some sort of relationship with him. The police had been informed of the man's presence and his interest in the child. Indeed that interest was published all over walls in the area where he had written; "I'll always love you Diego. Please forgive me for everything." And yet in spite of all this surveillance, and the obvious concern of his mother, Diego died on a crowded street on a balmy Sunday evening. For once we cannot even blame passers by for failing to intervene. Diego's assailant was in his turn set upon by two waiters from an Indian restaurant. The police were on the scene within minutes but it was all too late.

So what can we do with our need to take action? The most obvious channel for our outrage will be against the strangers lurking in our midst. According to some press reports, a man, who lives locally in a hostel, was seen regularly in the local park playing with children. He apparently focussed on Diego because the child, described by neighbours as "always charming, helpful and polite", was kind to him while the other children were not. What lesson do we learn from this?

According to Michelle Elliott of Kidscape, an organisation which specialises in teaching children how to deal with danger we should tell children that most people are nice but you can't always tell by looking at people what they are like. "We teach children to shout 'no!' and get away if threatened. Children have to be taught that they have to look after themselves as there is no alternative."

Bleak advice, and in this particular case pretty useless. The boys were already shouting and running away. They would probably have done better to have run into a restaurant and asked for protection from the adults within - but then I expect they had been taught to be wary of strangers, particularly people who look different, as do those who actually came to their aid.

But pretty bad advice in general. Do we really want a society in which children are brought up to regard all adults as potential risks? How would we go about teaching such advice? Children learn by example. My own children have witnessed me talking to strangers (no matter what they look like) ever since they were born. Should I stop chatting to the Big Issue seller with the missing front teeth, sad eyes and dog on a string? Should I abandon my practice of getting to know new people when they move into the street - just in case I am sending out the wrong message?

By bringing up our children to fear adults, and to hesitate before intervening to help another person, are we not merely adding to the alienation and isolation which makes our children vulnerable in the first place?

For the NSPCC's director of child protection, Neil Hunt, the lesson to be learned is the importance of vigilance. "Children thrive emotionally in the outdoors so we must ensure that all open spaces are child-friendly, supervised and safe." Sound advice for policy makers and something which every parent would be grateful for on a summer afternoon when their 12 year olds are playing, unsupervised, in a local park.

There was a time when parks had keepers to care for the plants and for the children. In these days of contracting out, park maintenance goes to the lowest bidder who may only arrive to mow the grass once a week on a Monday. More adults employed in open spaces would almost certainly make them safer for children - but in this sad case such advice is meaningless. Diego was close to home, with an elder brother, in a crowded street.

So where does this leave us? As parents we have to accept the unacceptable: that we can't control everything in our children's lives. Occasionally terrible things do happen. This boy was just at the age when most of our children will be taking their first tentative steps into the adult world. Something as terrible as this makes us want to hug them close, bar the door and keep the world at bay. We can't do it. We have to allow them to step outside however much we fear for them. And we have to reassure them that, in most cases, the world is not a fearful place and a stranger is a friend you don't yet know - because that, thank God, is what the statistics really tell us.

webTitle: 'If you don't eat your ice cream, you can't have your broccoli'

fields.headline: 'If you don't eat your ice cream, you can't have your broccoli'
fields.standfirst: Rachel Shabi on how to make greens tempting
fields.trailText: "If you don't eat your greens, you can't have pudding." Your parents said it to you; now you say it to your own children, and still they spit their spinach out. Now one man is suggesting that we turn this dinner table threat on its head. If we don't want kids to develop negative and unhealthy associations over food, it's better to encourage them to eat dessert in order to earn the greens. So says Dr Joachim Westenhöfer, professor of nutrition at the University of Applied Sciences, Hamburg.
fields.body:
"If you don't eat your greens, you can't have pudding." Your parents said it to you; now you say it to your own children, and still they spit their spinach out. Now one man is suggesting that we turn this dinner table threat on its head. If we don't want kids to develop negative and unhealthy associations over food, it's better to encourage them to eat dessert in order to earn the greens. So says Dr Joachim Westenhöfer, professor of nutrition at the University of Applied Sciences, Hamburg.

Speaking at the Kellogg's European seminar on child nutrition and health in Rome last week, Dr Westenhöfer explained. "It's a basic problem that food considered not nutritionally valuable is offered to children as reward," he says. "Children learn from this that chocolate and ice-cream are very valuable."

Effectively, this sets up skewed neural pathways of association, and teaches that unhealthy eating is enjoyable.

Not only that, adds Dr Wynnie Chan, a scientist at the British Nutrition Foundation, but such a reward system creates a lifelong aversion to healthy food; many adults won't touch sprouts and broccoli.

Westenhöfer holds that children are naturally capable of making healthy food choices. In experiments where kindergarten pupils were offered a breakfast buffet with fruit, vegetables and cereal laid out alongside junk food, the children chose the former instead of fizzy drinks and crisps. "If you offer a variety of foods, and give them opportunities to taste new foods, they will develop good eating habits," says Westenhöfer. His own children are given vegetables every day. Sometimes they eat them, sometimes not.

Nutritionists are certain that the important thing is for parents not to be anxious. "You can't force kids to eat," says Chan, "and if you react negatively kids will know that food is a way of winding you up and gaining control."

Fretting over food is not healthy for parent or child. "Kids pick up on stress, and the natural bodily response to stress is loss of appetite," says Westenhöfer. Excessive health-consciousness is not much use either. Indeed, Chan describes instances where it can be detrimental. "Over-zealous parents are giving children low-fat, high-fibre diets, which are totally inappropriate, nutritionally, for growing children," she says.

It's common for parents to worry about children's eating habits but, Westenhöfer says, it is unnecessary. "Parents should be confident that kids bring have a very good internal biological food monitor. The prime concern is that kids don't eat enough and won't be getting the nutrition that they need, but if you leave kids to eat what they want, they won't end up malnourished."

He describes this process as "sensory specific satiety" - the biological need to be satisfied by a specific taste before moving on to something else. It explains why kids are faddy, clamouring for spaghetti hoops for days on end and then refusing them point blank, insisting that they have always hated pasta - hooped or otherwise.

"If you just let them eat spaghetti, you'll find that their preferences will shift on to something else," says Westenhöfer. "but if you prohibit their current preference, this will strengthen the desire for it."

* Celebrate the seasonality of food; eg, the first strawberries, new potatoes, sugar snap peas.

* Eat with your children.

* Remember that there are no good or bad foods. Food itself is not unhealthy; it's simply a matter of quantity.
