fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Cherie Blair is said to see Ayurveda specialist Bharti Vyas, and Madonna has daily yoga sessions. So what can such complementary therapies offer pregnant women?
fields.trailText: The Question: Cherie Blair is said to see Ayurveda specialist Bharti Vyas, and Madonna has daily yoga sessions. So what can such complementary therapies offer pregnant women?
fields.body:
Bharti Vyas Ayurveda specialist

Ayurveda means the body and spirit work together - during pregnancy that's especially important, because there are so many changes in the body and it makes all the difference if you know what's happening and why. It can help with many problems - such as when the circulatory system is put under a lot of strain in pregnancy. That's one reason why so many pregnant women suffer from swollen legs and feet. Leg massage can help a lot, and so can using "flowtron" boots - they inflate and deflate at 30-second intervals, massaging the legs and aiding circulation and lymphatic drainage. Bharti Vyas is on 020 7486 7910
Verdict: Better circulation

David Needleman Homeopath, runs homeopath helpline

Homeopathy is particularly good if you're one of the many women who suffers from morning sickness. There are various remedies - sepia can help with nausea, particularly if it's the second, third or fourth pregnancy; nux vomica is for that total exhaustion feeling; and colchicum helps where even the sight of food makes you feel like throwing up. Homeopathic remedies are very safe, and so are ideal during pregnancy - you can buy them over the counter, but if your sickness continues after 12 weeks I'd advise consulting a therapist for tailored remedies.
Homeopathic helpline 09065 343404 (charged at a higher rate )
Verdict: Less sickness

Zita West Midwife and acupuncturist

An awful lot of women suffer from backache and from unspecific aches and pains during pregnancy. Conventional medicine doesn't seem to have much to offer, but acupuncture does. Depending on the pain, I'd use points on the lower limbs to help. Acupuncture releases endorphins, which are the body's natural painkillers - so it's a brilliant therapy in pregnancy where you don't want to take anything unnatural. It is also good for improving energy levels, especially in late pregnancy when you feel it's all a bit too much to cope with. It can be good for insomnia, too.
British Acupuncture Council 0208 735 0400
Verdict: Help for backache

Fenella Lindsell Founder of the Art of Health and Yoga in south London

I teach yoga to pregnant women and women who've just had babies, and it's a marvellous preparation. I'm expecting a baby any day, I've done yoga right through my pregnancy, and right now I'm feeling fantastic, full of energy, supple, and ready for the birth. I'd say the best benefit yoga gives is to tone the pelvic floor. Several yoga positions help the pelvic floor, but the best one is called the fetuband, it's a kind of back arch. The pelvic floor is important because it supports the womb, helps support the lower back and ensures your body goes back to normal again after the birth.
British Wheel of Yoga 01529 303233
Verdict: A toned pelvic floor

Adrian Audsley Reflexologist

Like all complementary therapies, what reflexology seeks to do is use the body's own healing and coping systems - which is one reason why they are so very suitable during pregnancy. Because of the extra weight they are carrying, many women get a lot of muscle pain in pregnancy - backache, shoulder pains, pelvic pain. Reflexology can deal with these pains through points in the feet, and it's a very relaxing therapy to have - some women say it's more relaxing as a treatment than a body massage. It can also reduce swelling in the legs, improve the circulation, and improve sleep.
Association of Reflexologists 0870 5673320
Verdict: Banishes aches

Denise Tiran Midwife, aromatherapist and lecturer

Aromatherapy oils have to be treated with the same respect as drugs, as they're absorbed into the skin. But in qualified hands, aromatherapy can be a big plus during pregnancy. Lavender is one of the safest oils, and that makes it particularly useful - if a woman's blood pressure is starting to go up, lavender either in the bath or used in massage or even inhaled can be good. It's also good for insomnia. The citrus oils are also very safe - particularly helpful if a mother-to-be is suffering from constipation, when I'd also combine their use with a gentle clockwise abdominal massage. International Federation of Aromatherapists 020 8742 2605
Verdict: Low blood pressure

fields.headline: The cost of leaving
fields.standfirst: Once upon a time decent ex-husbands coughed up and ex-wives cared for the kids. But now the rules are changing.  Maureen Freely  examines the etiquette of modern marriage breakdown
fields.trailText: Once upon a time decent ex-husbands coughed up and ex-wives cared for the kids. But now the rules are changing. Maureen Freely examines the etiquette of modern marriage breakdown
fields.body:
There's this woman I know - a doctor, with three children. She's been the sole breadwinner for the past eight years, ever since her husband, who once did something in business, was made redundant and became clinically depressed. He was so low he couldn't be trusted with the children, so she had to pay for a nanny, too. Well, eventually, it got so bad she couldn't take it anymore. She suggested a trial separation. Off he went, and before she had finished paying that month's bills, he had set up house down the road with one of her children's playmates' mothers. His depression disappeared, just like that! He told my friend that proved beyond doubt that she was the cause of it. And then, get ready for it, he told her that it was only fair if she did something to make up for it. He had an idea for a new business. And according to this poor excuse for a husband, it was up to my friend to find the start-up money.

That's not the worst story I've ever heard. I know someone else, a mother of two, who's having to sell the marital home she got in her divorce settlement to put herself through a three-year training course. Her aim is to become financially independent, but it will be 10 years, she thinks, before she gets back to her pre-motherhood salary level. Or maybe it will take longer - because now it emerges that her ex is going to stop maintenance the moment she starts drawing any salary at all. Why should he bankrupt himself to support an independent woman?

And here's another one - about a man, this time. He's been paying the mother of his only child double the maintenance required by the courts for 12 years without missing a payment. Round about the time this girl finished her exams and left home, this man had to take early medical retirement. That same month, he got a letter from a solicitor, to tell him that his wife did not just want child maintenance payments to continue ad infinitum. She wanted them to be doubled. Her reason? Simple: she needed the money. She also deserved it. If it hadn't been for his bad behaviour, they'd never have had to get divorced in the first place.

Everyone who knows them would say that she's more or less right on this count. But how does that translate into pounds and pence? This woman has a job, for goodness sake. A job with a pension. That's what his friends say. What her friends say is that one salary is just not enough to keep a household going. This is also true. So what's fair?

It used to be so simple. A good ex-husband was a man who supported his wife until such a time as she remarried. And a good ex-wife was someone who used that support to carry on being a good mother to their children. This is not to say that all or even most divorcing couples managed to hold to the ideal. Still we were fairly clear about how to assign blame when they didn't. But now, with so many women working, and some men becoming primary carers, the rules of this game have blurred. Our ideas of fair play have gone out the window. No one seems to know exactly who is responsible for what. One thing is clear, though: some people suffer greater losses post divorce than do others.

It's long been known in policy circles that women are more likely to suffer a drop in income immediately following a divorce. This is usually because they have care of the children, and so cannot easily jump into full-time work. Most courts in this country take a "rehabilitative" approach in such cases. In other words, they encourage settlements that offer mothers with care of their children stability in the short-term, while encouraging them to become self-supporting in the long term. This is more or less in line with what most of us would think of as fair. But a new study of 66 recently divorced parents (written by Alison Perry and Gillian Douglas and commissioned by the Family Policy Studies Centre and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation) gives us a rather stark view of what happens next.

Two years after divorce, the incomes of most of the 31 men in the study were the same as they had been when they were married. But nearly half of the women had not returned to their pre-separation income levels. Many were having to scramble and borrow money from their families, and they were twice as likely as the men to say they were having trouble making ends meet. While there was strong agreement about how important it was to give children stability by keeping them in their original home, half of the parents had not had the resources to see this fine idea through. For many, the question defining the divorce settlement had not been how to share the assets, but how to share the debts.

The most disturbing finding in the study was the haphazard way in which most couples made these settlements. Only a few had been able to get good professional advice early on. Most did not retain solicitors until very late in the day: often this was to avoid "antagonising" the other party. There was a tendency, perhaps related, to go for informal arrangements. Thus, only a quarter of the mothers with care of children had maintenance in the form of a court order. While 29% received "voluntary" maintenance on a regular basis, and non-resident fathers often helped out with mortgage payments, clothes, holidays, school fees and so on, dependence of such goodwill arrangements meant that many women were financially insecure. The very worst news in this report is that most had not thought carefully about how they were going to support themselves in old age.

This must be partly due to the fact that most of the mothers in the study were in their 30s and 40s - and so were more concerned about keeping shoes on their children's feet and roofs over their heads. But life goes on, and divorce is forever. A fair divorce settlement, according to John Cornwell, senior partner at Dawson Cornwell should be not just about income and assets and maintenance, but also about pensions and long-term security. Indeed, pension sharing is becoming a reality. But it is still the accepted norm for the man to walk away with his pension, and for the woman to go for arrangements that allow her to keep her head above water in the short-term.

Often this is not because the wicked man is hoodwinking her, but because she herself is not fully aware of the issues. In other words, a lot of women are losing out in their divorce settlements because they do not get good advice. But they could, if they and their husbands went into mediation.

According to Sheena Adam, chief executive of National Family Mediation, most people go into mediation with highly unrealistic ideas about how much the other party earns or how much they need to make ends meet. One of the jobs of the mediator is to go for full disclosure. The mediator then puts the facts on a flip chart, so that both parties can see the gap between appearance and reality. Often a woman will have not been involved with finances up until this point. If this is the case, the mediator will try to give her a clear idea about how the finances work. Once there has been a balancing of power in the negotiations, the aim then is to come to an agreement about how to share out the money and the responsibilities. Here, again, the key word is balance. There's no winning or losing. The aim is to come up with an arrangement that's fair.

There are not nearly enough mediators out there to give advice to divorcing parents when they need it. If there were, we wouldn't be having to spend so much time fretting about fairness, and we wouldn't have so many stories about friends who are shafted by their money-grabbing exes. The questions of etiquette and proper conduct would remain.

It will probably be decades before we have a clear idea about what a fair settlement looks like in a world where both men and women work and both men and women also care for their children. But most of the horror stories you hear of come about because people are naïve about money, or don't anticipate problems, or make vague arrangements based on unarticulated assumptions, and leave too much too goodwill. It's because they fail to protect themselves in the beginning, that so many people find themselves being treated unfairly later on. With proper assistance at the right time, they can reach fair solutions that last.

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: 14: A brief guide to garden games
fields.trailText:
Supasplat
£19.99
Woolworths, TRU, Index, Argos. Additional pellets £3.99
fields.body:
Supasplat
£19.99
Woolworths, TRU, Index, Argos. Additional pellets £3.99

My children fell on this giant peashooter like pirates discovering treasure. With 80 paint pellets and a fast-action pump, they were soon splatting everything in sight. The flimsy target sheet was quickly discarded in favour of a bullseye drawn with chalk on the garden wall. The paints are non-toxic, water-based and, importantly, wash off clothes and skin with soap and water. The instruction leaflet advises on safety measures, and the shooter has been carefully designed to avoid injury. The mouthpiece is formed to prevent inhalation of pellets, and protective goggles are included (only one set, however). The biggest disadvantage is that the pellets run out quickly. Refills are essential.

Rating: 5/10

Garden Chess Set
Matting £225, pieces £325 ,£2.99 p&p.
Available from www.mailorderexpress.com or tel 08700 129090

Horrified at the size of the packages that arrived on my doorstep, I was certain that this wouldn't fit into the garden. However, on opening the elegant plastic chess pieces and laying out the latticed squares - which don't inhibit grass growth - I was won over. The children loved it, too, and friend after friend was invited around to take part in some epic game. In scenes reminiscent of The Draughtsman's Contract, there was much deep thinking and silent wandering by secretly competitive parents. The idea of mental exercise and gently physical movement is appealing. Obvious negatives are the whopping price, and the cumbersome pieces, which are a devil to put away.

Rating: 5/10

Rocket Zoomer
£15
Early Learning Centres, or tel 08705 352 352. £2.95 p&p

This updated swingball game differs from the 70s original only in colour and material - purple, yellow, orange and blue plastic. For anyone who has ever struggled with a self-assembly item, this one- to two-player game is a breath of fresh air, ready to play in less than a minute. It's also durable and sturdy. Although it is marketed as suitable for ages three and over, good hand-eye coordination is necessary if the game is not to become tedious. The two plastic racquets are small and have a poor grip, and were soon ditched for proper short tennis racquets. While the ball is soft, being on the receiving end of a hard hit can sting. Croquet
£59.95
At Dawson & Son; 01799 520333 mail order. £3.25 p&p

A popular Victorian game that offers a host of opportunities for players to show their nasty sides. This miniature wooden set is well crafted, and arrives in a beautiful crate, although the too-thin,white wire hoops seem out of step with the quality of the other pieces. The marvellous thing about croquet is that it appeals to the very young through to the very old, and all have an equal chance of winning. The mallets aren't quite long enough for comfortable adult play, but suit children well. Rating: 9/10

Boules
£9.99
From the Great Little Trading Company (08700 768696), or www.gltc.co.uk. £3.95 p&p

Boules can be a gorgeously slow and contemplative activity. Though best played in sand under a leafy palm tree, it can be almost good on a cloudy afternoon in the back yard. The object is to throw the larger wooden balls as near to the small plastic jack as possible. You may displace other players' boules by knocking them, but the bottom line is, the nearest to the jack wins. Whether played one on one, or in two pairs, this is an extremely versatile game - you can play on any surface - and the rules are easily understood by all ages. The tough plastic packaging of the carry case makes the set easily portable for the beach or a picnic. The balls are lacquered for extra durability and are a good size for small hands.

Rating: 6/10

Garden Games Set
£39.95
TP Activity Toys. 0800 0681870 for stockists, or see www.tptoys.com for full listing

Comprising two steel tube uprights, a full-size adjustable badminton net (20ft) and a jumping pole, this is an extremely versatile toy; it can be adapted for volleyball, short tennis, badminton or high jumping. The pole is lightweight to ensure that little legs will not end up covered in bruises. In keeping with TP's reputation for toys that last, it carries a lifetime guarantee against rust, and also meets their high safety standards. The set is too large to take easily to the beach, and the size of the net means it is not suitable for small gardens. However, the variety of activities means the potential for school holiday energy-burning is high. Unfortunately, racquets and balls are not included.

Rating: 7/10

fields.headline: Can he play football?
fields.trailText: A local mother who has never thought to invite Alex over to play with her boys of the same age, (heaven forbid, he might need the loo!), assures me "We do collect for Scope." Well, great, but what Alex really needs is friends, and what I need is the odd break.
fields.body:
A local mother who has never thought to invite Alex over to play with her boys of the same age, (heaven forbid, he might need the loo!), assures me "We do collect for Scope." Well, great, but what Alex really needs is friends, and what I need is the odd break.

Much to my chagrin, we are expected to rely on charity for many of our needs. When Alex was 3, local residents raised £2,000 for him to go to the Peto Institute in Hungary. It was lovely of all of them, but the experience made me cringe. I felt I had to walk around looking terribly grateful for ever after and smile at everybody - and I'm more naturally grumpy than gracious.

Now, to avoid the embarrassment factor, I tend to only approach larger, more anonymous charities. To get a walking frame from Whizz-Kidz is a sort of lottery - one used to have to phone on the first Monday of every month just to get put on the waiting list. After four consecutive Mondays of engaged signals, I was at my wit's end when someone at last answered and told me they weren't using that system any more.

Recently I applied for a concession to do an evening course at Oxford University. The application form required me to analyse my budget - cinema, haircuts, toys, childcare, software, tampons - it all went in, and very toffee-nosed they were when I complained. Having been granted the concession I was advised to write a thank you letter to my benefactor, so as not to jeopardise my chances for the following year.

Now, a local pub fund-raising committee have offered to pay for Alex's new trike (£600). At first I declined the offer - but they promised no publicity, so I accepted. A friend tells me I'm too proud - maybe so. Sometimes I do feel a little bit like Perks in The Railway Children.

fields.headline: Seedy tale
fields.standfirst: A new form of GM maize has been added to the national seed list. Alan Simpson MP tries to object
fields.trailText: A new form of GM maize has been added to the national seed list. Alan Simpson MP tries to object
fields.body:
The latest twist in the genetically modified food debate lurches between the serious and the surreal. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) has decided it wants to approve a form of GM maize (known as Chardon LL), though the rest of the government has called a halt to such approvals until all GM farm trials are completed. As far as Maff is concerned, this may simply be evidence of its commitment to the enterprise culture. But for everyone else it is deeply confusing.

Maff had advertised its intention to place Chardon LL on the national seed list in the widely read Plant Variety and Seeds Gazette. It also held out a public invitation to object. Maff obviously didn't expect much of a response, because there appear to be no formal rules for the appeal process and no specific rights of objectors. In fact, it is here that everything becomes a little surreal, with different "pay as you go" objection options, a ministerial veto on who can be heard and no objectors' rights to cross-examine or challenge those making other claims.

Unlike a planning inquiry, where citizens' rights to object are a free part of the democratic process, challenges to national seed listings cost you. For £30 you can object in writing to Maff, while £60 buys you a slot at a public hearing, and the £90 all-singing all-dancing version allows you to do both.

This is a novel "cash for questions" version of democracy in which the payment of cash doesn't guarantee the right to ask your question. To get to that stage, the minister must first decide whether you have a valid interest or not. The rules of the 1982 seed regulations are no clearer than that the minister must be convinced you have "sufficient interest in the matter", and/or are "representative of a class of persons likely to be affected by the decision". It is not enough to say that, since the disaster of BSE/CJD every one of us will be affected by agricultural decisions that charge across nature's frontiers in pursuit of short-term commercial gain. The minister will expect you to demonstrate a more specific claim.

My own supplications have tried to move from soft-focus cynicism to hard-edged objection. The tests done on Chardon LL have been partial, superficial and (because its EU approval was granted under 1998 rules) do not meet the test requirements that apply today. There has been no testing of its consequences or effects on the animal (and human) feed chain. There has been no study of its impact on soil fertility and the soil nutrient cycle. And Maff has failed to address evidence of horizontal gene transfers from GM crops to non-GM varieties and the wider environment. Have I strutted my stuff enough? I hope so minister, because I would really like to make it to stage two of the democratic labyrinth. For it is here that we move from the arbitrary to the obscure.

A public hearing is not like a public inquiry. You get to express your views to "a government appointed person", whoever that may be - the cleaner, a temp from the nearest call-centre, or an off-duty 0898 operator? How will it be for me? Should I talk dirty about soil fertility, cross-pollination and the like? Will they encourage me, breathing "yes, yes" across the table until I've had my £90 worth, only to be summarily disconnected from the ministerial chat-line to make way for the next hopeful punter? I don't know what will make the earth move from under the absurdity of Maff's proposal.

When he announced the farm scale trials of GM crops in October 1998, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said: "It is extremely important that we do not travel further down the road to commercialisation of GM crops before we have this information." The farm scale trials will not be completed until 2003 and Chardon LL is one of the crops being trialled. No one in their right mind should be jumping the gun on such approvals before this date.

Meacher has given the government some public credibility on the GM debate. Before this, we were seen as selling ourselves cheaply to any biotech company promising to be the Christopher Columbus of the 21st century. But saving Labour from public ridicule and consumer rejection doesn't necessarily bring plaudits from Downing Street or cabinet colleagues. Doubtless there are gremlins in government who would love to see the DETR policy in tatters and a GM free-for-all given its head.

For all I know, Maff may be gung-ho behind this strategy. If it is, then wiser heads must point out where the casualties and the blame are likely to turn up: non-GM farmers (in arguably Maff's most successful policy initiative to date - the organic farming conversion programme) whose livelihoods disappear as crops suffer from cross-pollination; the consequences of killing off between 20% and 40% of helpful soil bacteria in the GM crop/herbicide spray cocktail on offer; the knock-on effects of GM maize forming up to 50% of the diet of dairy cows.

We have been here before, and more is at stake than political reputations.

 Alan Simpson is Labour MP for Nottingham South.

fields.headline: Streets of shame
fields.standfirst: A movement that once produced the best political theatre in Europe appears to have lost the plot - failing to get across any real message at the May Day protest, then refusing to condemn the violence. George Monbiot argues that Reclaim the Streets is killing the credibility of direct action
fields.trailText: A movement that once produced the best political theatre in Europe appears to have lost the plot - failing to get across any real message at the May Day protest, then refusing to condemn the violence. George Monbiot argues that Reclaim the Streets is killing the credibility of direct action
fields.body:
Non-violent direct action is a misnomer. It is not a direct attempt to change the world through physical action, but a graphic and symbolic means of drawing attention to neglected issues, capturing hearts and minds through political theatre.

It might slow down the building of a road or an airport, but it will succeed in preventing others from being built only when it is part of a wider democratic assault on the policies which gave rise to them. When physical force becomes the sole means of preventing something from taking place, then the ethics of political activism become indistinguishable from the ethics which encouraged Tony Martin to shoot the burglars in his house.

This is just one of the lessons which Reclaim the Streets has spectacularly unlearnt. The movement which once produced the best political theatre in Europe, winning public sympathy and galvanising debate about the environment and social justice, has lost the plot. It has turned into an association of incoherent vigilantes, simultaneously frivolous and menacing - and has also managed to forget that activism is useless unless focused.

It might have been able to sustain an attack on global capitalism if it had identified a workable alternative. But without clear proposals for political change, the protests on both June 18 last year and on May Day this year were unmitigated disasters.

Floundering in huge and sticky issues, aping the language and actions of revolutionaries but without a revolutionary programme, the organisers left the press and the public dumbfounded as to their aims and intentions.

Reclaim the Streets has failed to draw boundaries not only around its political objectives, but also around the means by which they might be pursued. By refusing to condemn violent protest, the organisers issued an open invitation to every psycho in London to come for a ruck with the police.

While incapable of deciding what it wants to achieve, the movement has become all too adept at deciding who it will talk to. It has flatly refused to explain itself to the mainstream media or, indeed, to forge strong links with anyone outside the protest community. Criticism has come to be regarded as a capitalist conspiracy.

Instead of trying to persuade the unconverted of the virtues of their arguments in terms they can easily grasp and appreciate, the organisers have pictured instead a miraculous transformation of society, whereby the public abandons its use of the mass media, logs on to the Reclaim the Streets website and immediately agrees that "it is in the streets that power must be dissolved".

These problems are compounded by the myth of consensus. The direct action movement insists that it is non-hierarchical - but this has never been true. Some people, inevitably, work harder than others, making things happen whether or not everyone else in the movement agrees. Consensus, often unwittingly, is manipulated or overridden, as people with a burning vision, with time and energy, drive the rest of the movement forward.

But by convincing themselves that there is no hierarchy, that the protests they start are spontaneous uprisings of the people, the organisers shed responsibility for their actions. The harsh truth is that Reclaim the Streets is less accountable than many of the institutions it seeks to overthrow.

The violence on May Day was the direct and predictable result of both the absence of boundaries and the abdication of responsibility. Digging up Parliament Square to stop global capitalism is so futile, so utterly frustrating and disempowering that the more hotheaded protesters could almost be excused for wanting to do something more spectacular. As the nutters in the crowd smashed up shops and defaced the Cenotaph, they must have believed they were precipitating the assault on the entire world order which Reclaim the Streets had promised but had wholly failed to deliver.

The result is that the protest, three days before the local elections, managed to jeopardise the best electoral chances radical politics has had in Britain for 15 years. It achieved the otherwise impossible feat of making the government's anti-terrorism bill appear sane. It made the police look like society's guardian angels, and it allowed every reactionary in Britain to feel that he or she had been justified in dismissing the direct action movement as an inarticulate threat to human life. Tony Blair couldn't have hoped for a better result if he had organised this protest himself.

Their failure to understand other people's feelings, their refusal to learn how to deal with the media and to build support in the outside world, led the organisers to compound the damage.

The press statement that they released on May 2 was perhaps the most morally supine and intellectually bankrupt document I have ever read. It disclaimed all responsibility for unforeseen events and failed to condemn outright either the violence or the desecration of the Cenotaph. Both, it argued, were dwarfed - and, by implication, justified - by the violence of capitalism and imperialism. Had you read only this account of the demonstration, you might have imagined that it was a great success.

Its incapacity, even now, to learn from its mistakes suggests to me that Reclaim the Streets can never again be anything but a threat to the environment and social justice movements. Far from winning fresh support, it has managed to alienate even those people who would otherwise be sympathetic. It has closed off avenues for political dissent, as the police and government clamp down on mass action and peaceful people keep away.

Reclaim the Streets, in other words, is no longer part of the solution. It is now part of the problem.

fields.headline: Rubble trouble
fields.standfirst: Matthew Carr on the threat to the Peak District national park from plans to reopen dormant quarries
fields.trailText: Matthew Carr on the threat to the Peak District national park from plans to reopen dormant quarries
fields.body:
Rising up in a plateau between Bakewell and Matlock, the former Bronze Age burial ground of Stanton Moor offers one of the most haunting landscapes in the Peak District national park. The combination of birch woodlands, open heather and spectacular views have always been popular with walkers, while the Nine Ladies stone circle and some 70-odd neolithic burial chambers have made Stanton a scheduled ancient monument.

Unfortunately for conservationists, this little jewel in the Peak is also rich in minerals, and the surrounding area is scored with active and dormant quarries. In recent months the future of Stanton Moor has been called into question, following a controversial proposal to re-open a dormant quarry on the edge of the moor.

Since last winter, local residents protesting against the proposal have been joined by an encampment of eco-protesters, and a minor planning dispute has become a major headache for the park authority.

The controversy began in January last year, when the Stancliffe Stone Company submitted a scheme to the Peak Park Authority to work two dormant gritstone quarries at Lees Cross and Endcliffe. To the horror of residents of nearby Stanton Lees, the company proposed to cut a 30-acre strip from the side of the moor, excavating 60m tonnes of gritstone annually for the next 42 years.

"I really couldn't believe it," said Leslie Wilson, who moved to Stanton Lees in search of rural tranquility two years ago, "because it is such a beautiful place and it's within the national park. I felt it was impossible that it would be spoilt in such a way."

For the Peak park authority, the Stancliffe proposal was one more round in an ongoing battle between conservationists and the quarrying industry over dormant quarries.

The 1995 Environment Act attempted to address the problem by stipulating that dormant quarries could only be worked in accordance with "full modern planning conditions," but proving whether or not these conditions are being met can be a tortuous and expensive process on both sides.

"There's a tremendous amount of negotiation that's involved and the act is laborious to implement," said councillor John Bull, chairman of the Peak Park Planning Commission. "There have been a number of cases where because of legal challenges we've almost had to go right back to the beginning and start again."

Stancliffe refused to comment on the controversy it had created, beyond a press release claiming that its original scheme contains "modern conditions, based on a detailed environmental assessment".

The company's environmental assessment failed to calm the fears of local residents on a range of issues, including the prospect of heavy lorries on inappropriate roads, noise and dust pollution, tipping and waste removal, environmental damage and the possible blockage of the village's natural water supply.

The villagers fears seemed to be borne out by the Peak park's officers report which showed that initial borehole surveys suggested the overall stone quality was likely to be poor, and recommended that gritstone extraction be limited to one tonne a year.

The Stanton Moor encampment is now the largest ongoing eco-protest in England. For the protesters, the residents and the Council for the Protection of Rural England, who are supporting the protest, the quarry proposal has become a test of the Peak park authority's will to protect the land from environmentally-damaging exploitation.

"We recognise that quarrying is part of the culture and tradition of the Peak District," says David Bradley, of the Sheffield CPRE. "However we feel there is a need to move towards a more sustainable approach to winning and working minerals. fields.headline: Trying time
fields.standfirst: Andrew Cunningham puts forward the scary case of being a prosecution witness
fields.trailText: Andrew Cunningham puts forward the scary case of being a prosecution witness
fields.body:
It's 9.15 on a Wednesday morning, and a far from normal day. I was sitting in the waiting room of Guildford magistrates court. Middle-aged, married with kids, safely suburban, I'd never been in trouble in my life. Now, for the first time, I was to appear in court. The prospect frightened me - and had done so ever since the envelope arrived, summoning me to appear as prosecution witness.

Six months ago, I had been bitten by a dog, while jogging on the school playing fields where I teach. The police had been helpful and keen to take up the case. No lasting damage had been done, but it was still a scary experience, with the same sense of "personal space violation" as a minor assault. Any child would have been scarred for life; I considered it my "duty" to press charges.

But, as the date loomed larger, I felt increasingly as if it was me on trial: my word against that of the dog-owner. The information I'd received in advance actually fostered this sense of dread. Offers of a witness support service may be well-intended, but the effect is undoubtedly to cause concern. Why should anyone need "support?" Is it really so frightening?

The Witness in Court leaflet, too, while seeking to smooth away concerns, accomplishes the reverse. When you read the advice on going to court - the magistrates, oath, witness-room: all sketched out in remorseless detail - you start to feel like a criminal yourself. The more the procedure is explained, the more you regret the case coming to court in the first place.

Now here I was: plucked from the reassuring routines of school, plonked in a strange world of serious faces. A clear "us" and "them" was evident in this waiting-area: the lawyers, with sleek looks, sharp suits and mobiles; the "villains", with studied unconcern and full Nike finest. Few were smiling; few, presumably, had much reason to. There were magazines on the tables (firmly bolted to the floor), but most lay untouched. It was like the dentist's - only worse.

And the waiting took longer. An hour passed and I despaired of being called. I only had half a day off school; so, if things didn't start moving, a lot of kids were going to be left teacher-less later on.

Most cases seemed to be driving offences - no insurance, no MoT - or "drunk and disorderly". I briefly envied one carefree bloke who breezed in and said: "Just let me plead guilty and get on with it, so I can get back to work." But there was no hurrying justice.

Nearly two hours, and the prosecutor at last appeared for a briefing. He said it was "rare" for a dog-bite to come to court; this itself alarmed me (what was so special about my case?). But he brought good news. At least I was being spared the biggest worry of all: bumping into the dog-owner again. (I'd been watching the stairwell anxiously, waiting for her to appear.) She'd pleaded guilty by letter, so wouldn't be appearing in person.

In the nick of time, just before I needed to head back to school, I was called to give evidence. By now I'd been fretting for two-and-a-half hours; but nothing prepared me for how nervous I felt mounting that witness box. As an experienced teacher, I was used to standing up in front of strange faces. But I was shaking when I took the oath; my confident "teacher voice" quavered. If ever an experience underlined the full immensity and power of the legal system - what our rule of law actually means - this was it.

Yet this was a trivial offence, tried in an empty courtroom. For something serious, in a tense, crowded court, with prison hanging in the balance, the experience must be terrifying.

For the next five minutes, I weighed each word carefully: with the clerk taking notes, it was impossible not to. It was also impossible not to try "reading" the expressions of the three magistrates on the bench above me.

And then I was free to go. After waiting so long, I wanted to listen to the rest of the case in the gallery; but my GCSE class could wait no longer. Later, I discovered that, although the owner had pleaded guilty, the case had been adjourned for another month so she could appear in person. Yet more uncertainty.

It's no wonder that, despite Jack Straw's encouragement, so many people are reluctant to "get involved". The lesson I learned was that courts are places to stay well clear of.

fields.headline: Suffering silences
fields.standfirst: Alastair Hilton and John Roberts praise the TV soaps for lifting sexual abuse of men off the 'hidden' list of crimes
fields.trailText: Alastair Hilton and John Roberts praise the TV soaps for lifting sexual abuse of men off the 'hidden' list of crimes
fields.body:
A few weeks ago we probably wouldn't have written this. Two things bothered us: first, there is the sophisticated backlash towards the sexual abuse survivor movement; and, second, even Guardian readers wouldn't want to read about this particular aspect of it. Then the BBC TV series Casualty featured male rape in its storyline, followed by Channel 4's Hollyoaks depicting it graphically on the screen. The sexual abuse of males was on the agenda and here was an opportunity to stand up to those who deny the existence of the problem or resist the creation of male survivor services.

"They asked me why I didn't fight back" and "They thought I was gay and so it was my fault" are comments often heard at First Step, a Leicester-based telephone and face-to-face counselling service for adult male victims of sexual abuse and for their supporters. These men are not interested in how often it happens. They know it does, far more than is realised. Anyway, being sidetracked by estimates of how often it occurs is all too easy when avoiding the truth.

Professional practice and research suggests that many victims fear for their lives during the attack and that the use of weapons such as knives is common. Society's response is caught up in what we mean by masculinity: men tend to be regarded as perpetrators, not victims. Trapped in a media-maintained stereotype, being tough is the price men pay for being male.

So where does this leave male survivors, those effectively mute members of society confined to a prison of isolation and secrecy?

Faced with traditional expectations of being male, it's little wonder they are virtually silent when it comes to disclosing even so-called minor forms of abuse. As few as 10% of male victims report incidents, and many remain invisible, lacking in confidence and often depressed, their determination to be detached compounded by homophobia. Some turn their rage upon themselves. Others use more active behaviour, resulting in violence and criminality, behaviour which is unlikely to be interpreted by the police, social workers or the courts as anger resulting from abuse. When their behaviour expresses their powerlessness, terror and pain, they are often punished.

Given encouragement and opportunity, male survivors are able to identify anger, guilt, confusion and shame as feelings they want to explore. They are the experts in their own recovery, but they are also at the centre of two of society's main misconceptions about male victims: that they invariably abuse others and that they are gay.

Reports that some sex offenders experience sexual abuse in childhood are complicated by the general under-reporting and minimising of the sexual abuse of males and by the lack of available research concerning abused men who do not go on to abuse others.

Male survivors often have to struggle with professionals acting out of ignorance. Adverse experiences of disclosure include questions about why victims didn't protect themselves, interrogation about lifestyle and assumptions that the sexual abuse of males was about gay sex. One openly gay social services manager told us: "There's always a danger of speaking about child sexual abuse and gay men in the same sentence. Social prejudices and ignorance have never really made the distinction between what is commonly called homosexuality and paedophile behaviour. Being gay sometimes means not being allowed to be your full self, living in a shadow land of secrecy. The aftermath of sexual abuse can have a similar feel."

Despite the fact that male rape was recognised as a specific offence in 1994, what child and adult service providers know about the sexual abuse of males is still fairly limited - leading to poor planning, lack of training and poor coordination of services.

We have found that many male survivors convey an inability to trust and a sense of low self-esteem. Also evident is a lack of emotional language - except initially in expressing anger - and confusion about sexual identity. Again and again we find ourselves emphasising to survivors that the abuse is not about being gay and that heterosexual males who abuse power are overwhelmingly responsible for the abuse of boys and girls.

We have learned from our work with adult male survivors that there are a number of ways in which they prefer to access services, something which is reflected by research. Anonymity is important, as is an out-of-hours services, organised separately from premises suited primarily to women and children. Choice of worker is also vital. We are determined to halt the roundabout most male survivors end up on in their endless search for appropriate services. Survivors themselves are involved in the development of services and those caught in the ripple of the abuse - including parents, family and friends - are also offered help.

Taking their lead from women's rape crisis services, independent survivor organisations have emerged in Sheffield and London, as well as Leicester. This is as a result of the failure of statutory organisations to provide a range of safe, sensitive and appropriate services. A national association for male survivors and supporters has been proposed and quality training for health and social welfare professionals is becoming more readily available, usually from specially selected and committed volunteers.

There needs to be more discussion about the sexual abuse of males, support for men to speak out about their abuse and for professionals to harness the courage, optimism and strength demonstrated by many male survivors. Only then can we destroy the myths, prejudices and secrecy, and see services for male survivors of sexual abuse and their supporters grow and prosper.

Hopefully, despite criticism of too much "message telly", the two soaps have started something.

 Alastair Hilton is project co-ordinator of First Step; John Roberts is a social worker with male service users at Leicester Family Service Unit.

fields.headline: Mind on the job
fields.standfirst: People who have suffered mental health problems are being employed by an NHS trust to share their expertise. Eileen Fursland reports
fields.trailText: People who have suffered mental health problems are being employed by an NHS trust to share their expertise. Eileen Fursland reports
fields.body:
We've all seen that sign on the wall in shops and offices, "You don't have to be mad to work here, but it helps." Though it would certainly object to the use of the word "mad", there is an NHS trust in London which fully endorses the sentiment.

South West London and St George's Mental Health NHS trust actively seeks to recruit people with personal experience of mental health problems and sees it as a desirable attribute in job applicants.

The Pathfinder User Employment Programme, set up in 1995, aims to help these people get jobs - and keep them - at Springfield University hospital, south-west London. Project workers support people with a history of mental illness including schizophrenia, manic depression and depression, many of whom have been psychiatric in-patients at some time.

There is also a volunteer programme. At any one time, up to 30 users and ex-users of psychiatric services - many of whom have been unemployed for a long time - work at the hospital on a voluntary basis, learning new skills and gaining experience, confidence and access to up-to-date references, all of which help their chances in the job market.

Project worker Shareen Lucas, who has a history of severe depression, says: "The reason I applied to work at the trust was that the ad said, 'We seek to actively recruit people with mental health difficulties.'

"It was the first time I'd ever seen anything like that, and the first time I'd ever applied for a job where I didn't have to think about whether to cover up my periods of unemployment and the fact that I had been hospitalised. I could actually say what had happened, what I'd learned from it and how I thought that had contributed to my being a better employee."

In previous jobs, she says, she had lived in fear of being "found out". But with an enlightened employer, depression is simply seen as an illness like any other. "I can be Shareen the person who works and occasionally suffers from depression, rather than Shareen the depressive," she says.

She is thus in the unusual position of being a person with experience of mental health problems whose job it is to help others who have had mental health problems to gain jobs in which, often, they will be looking after people with mental health problems. Seven other trusts have been sufficiently impressed to launch similar schemes, and at least a dozen more are considering it.

Shareen and her colleagues on the project support people both during the recruitment process and once they have got the job, for as long as they need it. This can be practical help, such as interview practice for shortlisted applicants and, for employees, help with transport, budgeting and even getting up in the morning. They provide moral and emotional support and there is an open door policy so that anyone having a difficult time can come and talk things over.

The project supports 26 employees in a variety of jobs, including nursing and medical, health care assistants, secretarial, gardening and kitchen staff. Some choose to tell their colleagues about their history, others keep it to themselves because some staff still feel uncomfortable about the idea of working alongside people who have themselves used mental health services.

The support workers also work with the managers to ensure that someone's mental health problems are not affecting their work. "If I said the managers didn't need reassurance I'd be lying," says Daisy Choy, who manages the project. "But they are soon convinced by the evidence, when they realise that these people are doing their jobs successfully and trying even harder than everyone else not to be off sick. Mental illness is just like physical illness - you can be unwell once, and function perfectly well afterwards."

In 1997, the trust launched a charter, setting a target of at least 10% of the workforce being people who have experienced mental health problems. The signs are that the charter is having an effect, with increasing numbers of such people shortlisted and recruited for jobs.

The philosophy behind all this is that it would be hypocritical for a mental health trust to urge employers to take on people who have had mental health problems, and not to do so itself. Also, recruiting ex-users of mental health services could make for better care of patients. Who better to help people with mental health problems, the argument goes, than those who themselves have experience of living and coping with such problems?

 Copies of a leaflet called Depression in the Workplace are available, on receipt of an SAE, from The Royal College of Psychiatrists, 17 Belgrave Square, London SW1X 8PG.

Who better to help people with mental health problems, the argument goes, than those who themselves have experience of living and coping with such problems?  Copies of a leaflet called Depression in the Workplace are available, on receipt of an SAE, from The Royal College of Psychiatrists, 17 Belgrave Square, London SW1X 8PG.

fields.headline: Here to stay
fields.standfirst: Melanie Henwood on NHS plans to put elderly patients in private nursing homes
fields.trailText: Melanie Henwood on NHS plans to put elderly patients in private nursing homes
fields.body:
The Department of Health has confirmed that it is considering the option of using spare capacity in private nursing homes in order to free-up acute NHS capacity and solve the problem of so-called "blocked beds" - for which, read "beds occupied by elderly people".

The major response to this news to date has reflected on the apparent ideological u-turn that the government has performed in accepting the role of the private sector.

This is nonsense. There has long been acceptance of the independent sector as major providers of long-term care; the only difference is a shift towards seeing this as care which might be purchased in bulk by the NHS, rather than (as is often the case at present) by local authority social services departments.

It is important that the proposal to use nursing home beds is scrutinised in detail, and issues explored which go way beyond those of ideological dogma. Does it really offer a solution, or would it merely offer a short-term answer while storing up further problems in the long run?

The appeal of the idea lies in its simplicity. The argument goes that there is a problem in the NHS because of all of these old people. Most of them don't actually need the facilities of an acute hospital, but they are not well enough to go home. If they can be moved, temporarily, to a nursing home environment, then they can get the care they need and can continue their recovery at their own pace.

So far, so good. But it's not that simple. The issue with care of older people is not merely a technical one of insufficient beds. In recent years, there has been increasing emphasis on the need to recognise that older patients frequently need longer to recover from trauma or surgery. The blocked beds phenomenon is primarily the result of two factors: first the emphasis on efficiency (and hence of rapid hospital throughput, and shorter lengths of stay), and second it reflects the often disputed responsibilities between health and social services authorities, and consequent delayed discharges.

The proposal could further muddy these already murky waters by introducing a new group of patients who will remain the responsibility of the NHS (in financial and care terms), even though they are being cared for in a private nursing home, alongside other elderly people (whose medical and social condition will often be indistinguishable from this first group) but who are either being funded by social services, or who are paying for their own care (and typically, a combination of these two).

In other words, this solution would merely intensify the difficulties and anomalies which surround paying for long-term care which a royal commission reported on more than 14 months ago, and to which the government has still not fully responded (albeit that a white paper is expected this summer).

There are other concerns about the capacity of the nursing home sector to deliver. At present there is very little short-term use of nursing home care in the sense that is now being envisaged. The vast majority of such homes have neither the facilities, the staff or the skills to offer the type of rehabilitation which would be required. As David Hinchliffe (chair of the health select committee) has also cautioned, many such homes encourage dependence rather than independence. Indeed, the system has failed to provide any financial incentives for nursing homes to do anything other than maintain high occupancy levels.

Developing the role of the nursing home to provide sub-acute level care is not a new idea, and various models exist. However, these are characterised by a range of features including investment in appropriate staff, and the provision of facilities which enable the home to operate in a genuinely rehabilitative mode (such as self-contained flatlets which people can move into in preparation for more independence and a return home). These features cannot simply be bolted on to homes which happen to have spare beds. Moreover, it is a matter of some uncertainty whether, even if it were possible to develop this capacity, the approach could co-exist within homes where the major business remains that of long-term (that is, permanent) care.

In anticipation of the white paper on long-term care, it seems that speculation about likely developments continues unabated. This latest proposal for the use of nursing homes as an overflow valve for the acute sector comes hard on the heels of a story that the government is moving towards a position in which nursing care would be free - in part, but certainly not in whole, addressing the recommendations of the royal commission on long-term care.

It is hard to avoid the conclusion that leaks and rumours are being used to test response to ideas without going through the usual democratic processes of formal consultation on policy proposals.

It is undeniable that many elderly people currently occupying hospital beds need not be there. It is equally clear that for them to return to a level of acceptable independence and to go home can only happen with sufficient investment in rehabilitation and preventative support.

Indeed, this has been precisely the focus of activity which the Department of Health has been encouraging through a programme of grants to local authorities aimed at promoting independence. The short-term answer offered by this new overflow initiative not only ignores the valuable work which is already under way, but risks introducing a slick political solution which overlooks the very real practical impediments to changing the ethos and motivation of nursing home providers. More significantly, it is a solution which appears essentially to be born out of a perspective which views older people as a burden to the NHS, and a commodity to be shunted elsewhere.

Without considerable development, and real investment, this proposal is not an answer to how best to care for older people needing sub-acute care, but to the quite separate issue of how to deliver on the continuing spectre of the waiting list pledge.

 Melanie Henwood is an independent health and social care analyst.

fields.headline: Health hazards
fields.standfirst: The government's cash injection has solved the NHS funding crisis. Or has it? Steve Brown looks at the figures that reveal a different story
fields.trailText: The government's cash injection has solved the NHS funding crisis. Or has it? Steve Brown looks at the figures that reveal a different story
fields.body:
Finance is no longer an issue in the NHS. The recent massive injection of cash - an additional £2bn on top of the existing allocation for 2000/2001 and real growth of 5.6% for each of the three following years - has brought an end to the NHS financial crisis. Or at least that is what ministers would have us believe.

The government has clearly scored huge political points with what it describes as the biggest ever, sustained investment in the health service. Ministers talk of the health service now having a sound financial footing. But does it?

The words "financial crisis" may be bandied around too freely, but last year the NHS came close. Unfunded pay increases, which reached 10% for some nurses, the full year effect of the previous year's staggered pay award, the soaring costs of generic drugs, the flu "epidemic" - all of these conspired to make a mockery of the service's original target to reach financial balance in 1999/2000. Instead, despite additional funding of £135m announced in December, the service in England is expected to show a deficit of some £200m for the year.

Clearly the new resources announced in the Budget for 2000/2001, of which the English health service's share is £1.4bn, dwarf this deficit. Hence ministers' apparent confidence that they have dealt with the whole money issue, leaving them to concentrate on their modernisation agenda and performance issues.

Unfortunately, neat as this appears, it is far from the whole story. So far, ministers have allocated just £600m to English health authorities with no strings attached. (A further £60m has been used to create a special fund to reward good performers.) Again, this may seem more than ample compared to last year's £200m deficit. But a survey by the Healthcare Financial Management Association looking at early, pre-Budget versions of the service and financial frameworks (the post-internal market name for contracts) indicated a deficit in 2000/2001 of around £500m, if targets on waiting lists and coping with winter pressures were to be met.

The extra £600m should wipe this out at a stroke, enabling the service to manage within its means this year, and perhaps enable some small new developments from the fledgling primary care groups and trusts. But it does not make much of a dent in the service's historical deficit. It is a point hammered home by Barry Elliott, chairman of the Healthcare Financial Management Association. "Even if the whole of the £600m were allocated to address financial pressures, at best it is going to avoid the NHS going into further deficit in 2000/01 or having to make even more unpalatable reductions to services," he says. "It is, however, unlikely to be sufficient to recover accumulated deficits or improve the overall liquidity position."

But just how much debt has the service accumulated? Press reports vary wildly on this issue, with some talking of a £200m deficit while others put the NHS debt teetering on £1bn.

The confusion is understandable. At various times, ministers and health managers talk of in-year, accumulated and underlying deficits. But even when you know which deficit you are talking about, there are problems.

According to the National Audit Office's report on the NHS's most recently published accounts for 1998/99, by the end of March last year the accumulated deficit stood at some £500m, made up of a £700m deficit for health authorities and a £200m surplus for trusts. And this is before taking account of the expected £200m in-year deficit in 1999/2000.

Even this figure demands further investigation. According to the NAO, health authorities' accumulated deficit in March last year included £385m for long-term creditors and "provisions" for pension and clinical negligence costs. Commercial style accounting practice in the NHS requires health bodies to record an estimate, for instance, for the future settlement of a clinical negligence claim in the year in which the incident occurs, even though the payment may not be made for several years. The increase in provisions for clinical negligence is a major concern, implying major expenditure downstream. But eliminating this part of the deficit now would actually be poor use of public funds, as it would mean stockpiling cash to cover the future settlement rather than spending the funds up front on patient care.

Ministers and health department civil servants can rightly claim that this amounts to an almost technical deficit. But there are other figures within the accounts that appear more alarming. For instance, adding together the net current liabilities for both health authorities and trusts at the end of 1998/99 - that is, debts falling due within one year - gives a massive £750m. To some, this is the crucial figure and one health service manager told the Guardian this was now reaching a "dangerous level". And there are even more bewildering figures lurking in the background. The NHS liquidity position, or level of external debt, is causing concern, standing at some £640m at the end of 1998/99. Managers say this figure has risen dramatically over the last 12 months.

One way of managing these short-term debts is to delay payment to creditors. And the NHS performance on timely payments is woeful. The public sector payment performance target dictates that health bodies should aim to pay 95% of non-NHS invoices within 30 days. The NAO's recent report found that in 1998/99 just 13% of health authorities and 17% of trusts achieved this target.

It is not immediately clear what level of deficit is "real" and a cause for concern. But the money so far allocated from the new resources is not enough to give the service the firm financial footing the government wants. The funds are there in the amount still unallocated, but eliminating accumulated deficits is not as sexy as promising to recruit more medical staff or ramp up activity levels.

The government recently decided to use all the £22.5bn (windfall from the mobile phone licence auction) to pay off government debt. But will it be so prudent in the health service and clear its debts before starting its modernisation spending spree? According to Elliott, the success of the modernisation programme depends upon it. He says: "Unless we do address this honestly and openly and use the generous funding that has been made available to restore financial stability then the rest of the agenda is doomed."

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
In his 1979 book, The View in Winter, Ronald Blythe memorably observed that "one of the fearful developments in the consciousness of many old people is that, in the eyes of society, they have become another species". In recent times nothing can have done more to reinforce that sad and alarming sense of difference than the amount of space that has been devoted to the ageing population as a "social problem". By now most of us are familiar enough with the various statistical predictions: by the year 2008 the number of pensioners in this country will pass the number of children under 16; in five years' time over a third of the labour force will be over 45; by 2021, 12.2m people out of a population of 62.2m will be pensioners.

But these statistics rarely appear in a neutral context. At worst they are presented in a doomsday scenario which invites us to imagine what it will be like to live in a country where the state can no longer afford to provide a proper pension and a shrinking young workforce is required to slave away at the coal-face to provide even the most basic level of subsistence for a shambling mass of largely unemployable wrinklies.

The absurdity of treating everyone over the age of 55 as belonging to a homogeneous group labelled "old" was vigorously exposed years ago in Mary Stott's inspiring Ageing for Beginners but we can now welcome another fine antidote to received wisdom about the likely consequences of our ageing population.

In The Imaginary Time Bomb: Why an Ageing Population is not a Social Problem, economist Phil Mullan tackles some of the "myths" that inform the doomsday scenario: the assumption that there will be an inevitable slowdown in economic growth and the anti-welfarist agenda that uses the statistics on ageing as an argument for moving away from state pension provision. Even if we believe all the population forecasts - and it's worth remembering that the 1949 royal commission on population completely failed to foresee the baby boom of the sixties - we should recognise that so-called "population pro-blems" have frequently had more to do with ideology than analysis.

"Problems" are social creations. It wasn't long ago, Mullan observes, that society's humanity was judged by the way it looked after its old people. How on earth have we managed to change that view into one that sees the elderly as a positive menace to our future?

 Laurie Taylor talks to Phil Mullan and Polly Toynbee about the myths and the realities of the demographic time bomb in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Kent police have been criticised for sending DIY fingerprint kits to victims of crime because they don't have the resources to do the job themselves
fields.body:
Dab hands: Kent police have been criticised for sending DIY fingerprint kits to victims of crime because they don't have the resources to do the job themselves.

Handy excuse: A thief caught with two steaks down his trousers at a shop near Haslingden, Lancashire, told police he was just keeping his hands free for other shopping.

Lock-up cock-up: Security rules meant that more than 200 cell locks had to be changed at Long Lartin prison, Hereford and Worcester, after an officer mistakenly took home a master key.

Slippery customer: An engineer working on a washing machine sent for repair by a man from Ramsgate, Kent, discovered that the problem was caused by a python trapped inside.

Loud acclaim: A solicitor's clerk from Edmonton, north London, has been credited with the world's loudest belch at 118.5 decibels, equivalent to the sound of a pneumatic drill.

End of the line: When a lawyer in Leeds rang his client to find out why he hadn't turned up in court, the mobile phone was answered by an attendant at the mortuary where the man was lying dead.

Run, rabbit: Bales of straw, a load of cow muck and an evening's rabbit shooting were among the prizes auctioned at a village cricket club's fundraising event in Allendale, Northumberland.

Bark concerto: A Brighton firm offering a home dog washing service has found that playing classical music calms the pets while they are in the spa bath.

Let us spray: The vicar of a church in Plymouth called in the fire brigade to help when he discovered that someone had forgotten to the fill the tank to be used for a total immersion baptism service.

Site gag: The sacked manager of a pet food company in Lincoln was found guilty of sabotaging his employer's website so that potential customers would be taken to a rival firm's page.

Dead sure: Wildlife experts claim that the body of an otter hit by a car on a road near Southam, Warwickshire, is proof that the creatures are returning to the county's rivers after an absence of nearly 50 years.

Telling mistake: A firm of estate agents was embarrassed when a customer pointed out that an upmarket flat for sale in the City of London was advertised as being located in a 'thieving business community'.

Sky's the limit: A Star Wars fan who changed his name to Luke Skywalker has upset his wife by paying £9,000 for a full-sized model of the Snowspeeder vehicle from The Empire Strikes Back and installing it on the lawn of their semi in Swindon, Wiltshire.

fields.headline: Cash and carry
fields.standfirst: Where you live determines what you must pay for home help, reports Andrew Foster
fields.trailText: Where you live determines what you must pay for home help, reports Andrew Foster
fields.body:
When thinking about where we would like to live when we get older, most of us would hope to retain our independence as long as possible. Fundamental to such aspirations are the home help services provided by local councils - ranging from help with domestic activities like cooking and cleaning, to more intensive "personal care", such as helping people get up, washed and dressed.

In a report published today, the audit commission has found wide variations in what people are asked to pay for home help services and in how councils manage charges. Charging policies in some areas leave some people with less to live on than the level of income support appropriate to people of their age. There are examples of inefficient and insensitive management of charges adding to the anxiety charges cause.

The report shows how financial arrangements can create incentives for managers to move people into residential homes when they could remain in their own homes.

"Charging with Care" paints a picture of wide variation. Charges for people in similar circumstances (similar incomes and similar services) can vary from nothing to over £100 per week. While one in 20 councils provide home care services free, two-thirds only exempt people on the lowest incomes.

Over a quarter of councils expect all users to make some contribution to the services they get. While some would take up-front account of other costs related to someone's disability, others would expect a person to enter an appeal before they consider such costs.

Charging for care is a difficult and sensitive subject. In the face of a range of financial pressures, but with little guidance to help them, councils have had to ask themselves searching questions. These same questions have been considered by the royal commission on long-term care.

Councils have had to balance the amount they charge vulnerable people with the amount of service they provide. They must decide what constitutes a fair and reasonable charge. Not surprisingly, there are almost as many answers as there are councils. The report looks behind these variations to see what lessons can be learned.

It raises particular concerns over the treatment of the most vulnerable users of home care. People on income support of £78.45 can face charges of £10 per week for three hours of care. The most disabled can also be disadvantaged, particularly by policies based on hourly charges that do not take proper account of the extra costs such users face because they are disabled.

Insensitive or inefficient management of charges can add to these problems. Poor communication with users can increase anxiety. Bills can be sent over three months late, within which time they can build up considerably. People unable to understand their charges do not know if their costs have been properly taken into account and can worry about being able to afford services should their needs increase.

Those councils able to provide figures typically reported that between 1% and 4% of people cut down on their services or dropped out altogether because of charges. Some reported that as many as 10% built up significant arrears.

The most effective councils build their charges around people's needs. For example, Bradford council monitors arrears in order to offer help before problems get serious. Active and expert advice on benefits was a common feature of many good councils - providing extra resources both for users and the council, while helping the council to build an understanding of people's circumstances. Such an approach enabled Torbay council to increase the total care it delivered by over a quarter. But several improvements can also be made at the national level.

Charging with Care introduces a simple framework, based on the split of needs between care, living and housing as proposed by the royal commission. A look at the role of different national benefits and other aspects of users' resources in paying for different types of need allows inconsistencies between councils to be highlighted, demonstrating where there is a need for national guidance.

It goes on to show how this framework can be extended to address wider issues of the funding of long-term care. It describes how moving to a system of funding better aligned to needs and less dependent of the setting in which care takes place (residential home, nursing home or own home), can reduce the "perverse incentives" which social services managers face to make premature use of residential care.

Best value provides an opportunity for councils to rethink and improve their management of charges. Clear national guidance will protect the most vulnerable users of home help care, while at the same time enabling councils to use charges to extend access and improve services.

 Andrew Foster is controller of the audit commission.
