fields.headline: Farewell to the sixties
fields.standfirst: As the bulldozers prepare to move in on Birmingham's much-maligned Bull Ring, Chris Arnot looks in on an exhibition that puts the city's transformation in perspective
fields.trailText: As the bulldozers prepare to move in on Birmingham's much-maligned Bull Ring, Chris Arnot looks in on an exhibition that puts the city's transformation in perspective
fields.body:
When Tom Merilion first clapped eyes on Birmingham's Bull Ring, it was love at first sight. "I was seeing it through the eyes of a child," he recalls. "There were lots of people and shops and that was enough for me." By 1980, the markets complex and shopping centre had long been regarded as a national joke, a byword for bad planning. But young Tom didn't care about that. He was 12 or 13, out with his mates, hanging around record stalls, eyeing up giggly girls and listening to the raucous cries of stallholders.

Twenty years on, Merilion feels a little torn as the bulldozers prepare to move in on the Bull Ring and Brummies brace themselves for another round of redevelopment. "It deserves to be swept away because it's been allowed to become so tatty, but nostalgia stops me from seeing the buildings as totally awful," he admits between mouth-fuls of sausage, beans and chips, heavily laced with ketchup.

He is used to more refined lunches in the cafes and brasseries of Soho, where he makes television ads and rock videos for RSA (Ridley Scott Associates). Only for his more personal photographic work does he gravitate back to his home city. Hence his appearance today in the cafeteria at the Midlands Arts Centre - better known as MAC - where he's taking a brief break from overseeing the hanging of his latest exhibition, Concrete Dreams. Many of the pictures on show are aerial shots of Birmingham, for which he hired a Piper Seneca airplane "at £260 an hour, plus VAT".

Ironically, he felt that he needed to climb to 4,000 feet to get beneath the skin of the city. He wanted to see what the post-war planners saw when they peered down on their scale models.

"From up there you feel as though you could pick pieces up and move them around to make the place look more tidy," he says. "It's like looking down on a toy model."

The exhibition, due to be shown early next year at the Royal Institute of British Architects in London, would have resonances in Glasgow, Sheffield and other cities which suffered from over-zealous redevelopment in the 1960s.

It has certainly struck a chord with architect and urban designer Joe Holyoak, a reader at the Birmingham School of Architecture and founder of the pressure group Birmingham for People. "Tom's photographs have managed to reproduce the newness of these buildings 30 or 40 years after they were built," he says. "It's as though you're seeing them for the first time and you're not sure if you're looking at the real thing or a model."

In a thoughtful introduction to Merilion's exhibition, Holyoak reflects on how the centres of industrial British cities came to be transformed in the postwar years. How the blitz by the Luftwaffe created the conditions. How the war created a psychological desire for a fresh start. How radical town planning ideas had been developed in the 1930s by unfamiliar Europeans such as Le Corbusier, Ludwig Hilbersheimer and Walter Gropius. And how the past came to be seen as an obstruction on the road to the future.

"The intoxicating rhetoric about progress," Holyoak writes, "seems to have caused a collective amnesia in architects and planners about the timeless principles about what makes good places for people. Part of the reason for this was the enlargement of the scale on which area planning was done - a plan for an inner ring road or an estate for 10,000 tenants was like a military operation, with no time or inclination for a concern for the quality of a sociable street corner or a sunlit pub courtyard. . ."

For all that, Holyoak admits to a certain ambivalence in his response to the urban design of the 1960s. "Generally, we're much more cautious and conservative in our approach today," he says. "And that's not a bad thing. After all, it's the result of disillusionment with the unhappy results of the 1950s and 1960s. Yet you can't help but admire the gung-ho approach of that generation. There was so much undiluted confidence in their ability to build a totally new kind of urban future. Anything was possible.

"An awful lot of junk was built in the 1960s and 1970s, but also some outstanding pieces of work which have since been listed and incor-porated, however awkwardly, into the heritage culture."

A concrete signal box in New Street station and the elegant Alpha Tower, wedged on to the edge of Birmingham's Broad Street, are two examples featured in Merilion's exhibition.

Holyoak is well aware that his sneaking admiration, after years of outright opposition, is part of a well-worn pattern. "Every generation dismisses the work of the previous one," he says. "Then, a few decades later, it comes out of the shade. It happened to the Georgians and to the Victorians."

Indeed, it was the destruction of so much of Birmingham's Victorian heritage during the city's neo-brutalist phase which first made Holyoak, 54, such an active protester. He has been a thorn in the side of successive city planners for three decades or more.

In recent times, his criticism has been more muted, and he has even been known to praise the planning department. He heartily approved of the lowering of the "concrete corset" of the inner ring road, for instance. He likes the leisure, homes and office development around the canals at pedestrian-friendly Brindleyplace. And he couldn't help but applaud efforts to conserve the city's remaining Victorian buildings, however belated.

"In the 1960s," he says, "part of the start-again-from-scratch philosophy was the belief that you could dispense with streets and urban blocks. Now everyone - from Richard Rogers' urban taskforce downwards - is advocating going back to tried and tested patterns. It's part of the post-modern revisionism we're going through."

Today's planners and architects have access to what he calls "the computer fly-through" - the ability to look into a screen and take a virtual route through any proposed new development. They can see how it will look from ground level, rather than the distant, god-like perspective of 1960s planners so effectively reflected in Merilion's photographs. "It ought to mean that we get it right," says Holyoak.

But he still has doubts about the proposed £400m replacement for the 1960s' Bull Ring. He's concerned about the size of the "fortress-like" malls colonising more and more public space, the moving of market stalls further away from the city centre, and the absence of much provision beyond shopping. There are no plans for any homes, for instance. "The city council's policy is to encourage mixed-use developments," Holyoak says, "but it doesn't seem to be enforcing it in this case."

All the same, Holyoak knows that the new development is bound to be seen as a vast improvement on the dank passageways, the litter-strewn walkways and the grey, rain-stained concrete which so mocks the faded dreams of those god-like postwar planners.

Even Tom Merilion knows it, too.

 Tom Merilion's photographs, Concrete Dreams, are on show at the Midlands Arts Centre (0121-440 4221) in the city's Cannon Hill Park until June 4.

fields.headline: Back in the picture
fields.standfirst: After hospitalisation many older people feel unable to cope. Judy Hirst on a scheme that helps them regain independence
fields.trailText: After hospitalisation many older people feel unable to cope. Judy Hirst on a scheme that helps them regain independence
fields.body:
Ralph French used to produce beautiful, handmade cards for his family each birthday and Christmas. He has an album with them all carefully mounted inside. Now, after suffering a severe stroke, he has had to relearn how to write his name. He gropes for the words to express the frustration he feels.

At 78, Ralph could have easily ended up in residential care before his time, or as a hospital "bed-blocker" because there's no one to care for him back home. But thanks to an innovative social services scheme in his area, there is a good chance he will be able to live at home independently and on his own terms. The East Sussex Living at Home programme is using 38 of its residential home placements to help older people regain skills and confidence - typically after being hospitalised for a fall or a stroke - before returning home.

At St Anthony's Court in Eastbourne, Ralph and five other temporary residents have been put through their paces by a team of occupational therapists, physiotherapists and care workers. The aim, after six to eight weeks, is to be able to wash, dress, cook and generally cope at home.

Angela Howes came in after a hip replacement operation and was lurching badly when she walked. Now she's looking forward to doing a spot of gardening in her newly adapted flat. Ron Walters, who is 75, had a bad stroke and couldn't walk straight when he arrived. After six weeks of exercise programmes and memory games, he's making tea, washing up and - with help - going out to the shops.

Just one year into the scheme, it has already had a 70% success rate at helping people live at home. Staff say it's much more effective than old-style rehabilitation programmes, that the emphasis on confidence-building and the camaraderie between "guests" really helps.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has acknowledged the importance of this kind of intermediate care, or "reablement," in preventing people being rehospitalised, or needing institutional care. The trouble is, there isn't much of it about and funding for such schemes is precarious.

The East Sussex programme got some help from NHS "winter pressures" money. But the social services budget is very tight, particularly when it comes to financing follow-up services that many people still need after completing an intensive home care programme. This often involves buying in provision from the independent sector, says assistant social services director Heather Hills. Finding the money for that is difficult. Only people on the highest eligibility band get referred to Living at Home, and they are charged for it on a means-tested basis.

Nationally, the number of people receiving home care services has dropped by 7% in one year. According to one survey by welfare charities, nine out of 10 elderly or disabled people have suffered cuts in home care, ranging from housework and meals-on-wheels to help with using the lavatory.

Ironically, the £2bn cash injection recently announced for the NHS could make matters even worse. None of the extra money is earmarked for spending on social care. The focus on cutting waiting lists and speeding up hospital discharges inevitably will mean more people needing at least short-term community care when they come out, with social services being expected to pick up the tab.

Social services chiefs are looking, though none too optimistically, to July's comprehensive spending review. In North Yorkshire, where some people pay over £100 a week for home care, the head of community care services admits that the service they are able to provide is "pretty minimal": in some cases, not even access to a regular bath. Their central government funding does not allow for any additional growth in demand on the previous year.

In Essex, social services director Mike Leadbetter says local hospitals are worried about the impact of bed-blocking on their ability to meet patient through-put targets. But social services cannot come to the rescue with suitable care packages, because underfunding has led to severe staff shortages.

Radar, the disability charity, says that many social services departments are bumping up charges for services by at least 9%. At one Brighton day centre where this has recently happened, the manager fears that elderly people will be deterred from using a service that helps keep them physically and mentally well.

At St Anthony's, manager Denise Leary say it's often the little things - home adaptations, aids to help pour a kettle or get dressed, a bit of social contact - that make the difference to successfully living at home.

When living-at-home residents leave, they are followed up for several weeks by a home care team. But it's what happens further down the line, and to all those who don't qualify for high-level support, that concerns the workers. "What most older people want is to get back home, not end up in long-term care, when they've been in hospital," says Leary. "But you can't give them that on thin air."

fields.headline: 2020 vision
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill previews a crucial conference to ensure voluntary sector finance directors get in gear for a high-powered future
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill previews a crucial conference to ensure voluntary sector finance directors get in gear for a high-powered future
fields.body:
People over 50 are forced to volunteer; charities account for 15% of GDP; and all charity tax breaks have been abolished. Could this be the charity world in 2020? Today, finance directors of charities will gather at a conference, themed Figuring Out The Future, to discuss potential developments in the 21st century.

The keynote speaker is Michael Mainelli, from the management consultants, Z/Yen. He has a wealth of experience in industry and the voluntary sector and specialises in assessing financial risk. Mainelli will present three scenarios of the charity sector in 20 years' time. He says you can't predict the future but you can plan for it and scenarios are a way of checking whether an organisation would be prepared for any eventuality.

He calls the first scenario "control freaks", and describes the charity world as the new glamour sector. "Since the emergence in the early 2000s of the MCA (Master of Charities Administration), the sector has been the career of choice for more and more high-fliers. Instead of going to the power-starved House of Lords, ex-ministers will flock to the sector as a second career."

In this scenario, he continues, charities will also have an increased global influence. "On the international scene, the voluntary sector is the new cavalry, riding to the rescue. Since AAA (Aid and Administration for Africa) took over the management of three African countries five years ago, with at least limited success in two of the three countries, NGOs have been the mechanism of choice for dealing with international systemic failures." Up to 20% of OECD GDP will be invested in the voluntary sector, according to the scenario, but Mainelli foresees that critics will claim that the larger charities are too cost-obsessed to take risks.

In fact, this is what one of the other speakers at the conference, Stephen Lee, claims is happening today. A research fellow at South Bank University, London, specialising in fundraising, Lee believes that finance directors are too focused on short-term gain and are worried about the public's perception of charities spending too much on fundraising.

But Lee says research shows that donors understand the need to invest in fundraising to accumulate. "Fundraising needs longer term investment," he says. "Finance directors should take the risk and spend some of their reserves. In terms of return on investment, fundraising far out-performs other forms of income generation."

Other speakers will cover the impact of e-commerce on the sector, how finance directors should make the most of the government's recent changes to charity taxation, and even how they should dress for the future.

Suzi Carberry, of consultants, Public i, will argue that finance directors are grey and boring and that they should take more responsibility for the image of their charity. With the move towards dressing down or "smart casual", Carberry will advise finance directors on how to maintain an image of authority and credibility. "The British have a propensity to look a mess when they dress casually," she says. "Men only have to undo a button and they look like an unmade bed!"

fields.headline: Mirror editor censured over shares
fields.standfirst: More about the Mirror share scandal
fields.trailText: Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan has been criticised by press watchdogs over his involvement in the recent share dealing scandal at the newspaper.
fields.body:
Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan has been criticised by press watchdogs over his involvement in the recent share dealing scandal at the newspaper.

The press complaints commission ruled that Mr Morgan was in breach of the industry's code of practice and had "fallen short of the high professional standards demanded by the code".

The PCC concluded that "in view of the unsatisfactory state of affairs revealed by this episode, the commission has decided to refer the terms of this adjudication to the chief executive of Trinity Mirror".

The commission also found against journalists Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who had written and edited the paper's City Slickers column, concluding they had "engaged in flagrant, multiple breaches of the code over a sustained period of time".

The PCC launched its inquiry into share dealing by journalists at The Mirror after it emerged that a number of staff, including Mr Bhoyrul, Mr Hipwell and Mr Morgan, had bought shares tipped in the City Slickers column.

The code of practice prohibits journalists from making personal gain out of financial information before it is published, writing about shares they own without informing their editor and buying or selling shares they have written about recently or intend to write about in the near future.

webTitle: Making a drama out of an African crisis

fields.headline: Making a drama out of an African crisis
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook's showy response to the situation in Sierra Leone won't help the underlying problems, says Guardian deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain
fields.trailText: Robin Cook's showy response to the situation in Sierra Leone won't help the underlying problems, says Guardian deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain
fields.body:
The British government's response to the political crisis in the west African state of Sierra Leone is a wildly over-dramatic attempt to place our government at the centre of a spectacle which is briefly grabbing the world's attention.

If the large deployment of troops was really just to evacuate British, Commonwealth and European Union nationals who wished to leave, it did not need the firepower that has been displayed. If, on the other hand, Robin Cook's ambitions are for British troops to form the backbone of a United Nations force which is to disarm rebels and bring democracy to Sierra Leone, he should have thought hard about the example of the humiliation of the United States and the death of 30 of their soldiers in a similar mission in Somalia - and the continuing lack of government in that country a decade later.

Sierra Leone has been a shaky state since Britain created it from former black slaves in 1787. Post-independence its government, led by a former British soldier and supported by Britain, was notoriously corrupt and inefficient, surviving only on the wealth of the diamond mines in the area bordering Liberia. When the Revolutionary United Front revolt began against central government in 1991 it was supported by large numbers of deeply impoverished rural people and by many angry students and intellectuals.

In a decade of civil war the RUF turned increasingly to brutal tactics and to the use of drugs. Large numbers of youths and girls were abducted and joined the rebel forces who took over most of the north of the country. A west African military force made up mainly of Nigerian soldiers, ECOMOG, allowed successive weak governments to hold on to a semblance of power in the capital and about half the country.

Almost a decade later, after three coups and a splintering of both rebel and government forces, ending the civil war is an extremely complex question. Neighbouring Liberia, where president Charles Taylor was a key supporter of the RUF, provided the only model likely to work. Mr Taylor, a former warlord, finally agreed to end Liberia's civil war when an election was organised which he was likely to win. There are no illusions that he suddenly became a keen democrat.

Britain has wasted a lot of time trying to promote "democrats" with little political clout. The deal finally brokered by the UN in Sierra Leone brought into the political equation Foday Sankoh, one of the RUF's leaders with a bad reputation for brutality and some, though not all, of his commanders. The deal and the amnesty that came with it was bitterly criticised by supporters of the weak government in Freetown. It was, as Kofi Annan admitted, not a deal anyone was happy about, but it was undoubtedly better than the war.

The UN operation began to fail partly because it became clear that many in the RUF were, predictably, unwilling to relinquish the diamond areas. Then 10 days ago the Nigerian troops - who had been the tough opponents the RUF had learned to fear - were pulled out. Now they are willing to come back, but only if western countries like Britain are willing to put in money. The equipment for the 8,000 (soon to be 11,000) African and Asian UN peacekeepers who went in to try to disarm the rebels and give the peace a chance to take hold is far too poor for the task. It would be better for all concerned to have Britain pull out completely from the mess we have helped to make, and give the necessary tools to those more likely to be successful.

fields.headline: Feature: This year's wig thing
fields.standfirst: Cannes and the costume drama
fields.trailText: Here we are in the 21st century and yet this year's Cannes festival features a bumper crop of the genre that refuses to die - the historical costume drama, writes Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
Here we are in the 21st century and yet this year's Cannes festival features a bumper crop of the genre that refuses to die - the historical costume drama. You wonder why film-makers bother - after all, everyone watches the Cannes competition in the hope of seeing cinema's future revealed in a flash of innovation, and surely it won't be found in a pile of whalebone and old linen.

Nevertheless, periwigs and perukes are big this year, with not one but two dramas set in the age of Louis XIV - Roland Joffé's Vatel (pictured), which opens the festival tonight, and Patricia Mazuy's Saint-Cyr, with Isabelle Huppert as Madame de Maintenon. It's no surprise that the long-established firm of quality costumiers to the gentry, Merchant and Ivory, have made another Henry James adaptation, The Golden Bowl. But now even the more left-field French directors are getting in on the act, with Arnaud Desplechin's film Esther Kahn, set in the East End of Victorian London, and Olivier Assayas (best known for the quintessential film-about-film Irma Vep) tackling the porcelain trade of old Limoges.

Among the Asian films are Nagisa Oshima's Gohatto, about gay samurai in the 1860s, and Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, set in the Ching dynasty.

Critics in Cannes tend to have something of a prejudice against costume cinema, especially those in the epic mould. A few years ago, following a run of spongy, over-egged Euro-puddings, I decided to skip the morning's big French heritage offering. Later that day, I asked a colleague if I'd missed anything. "Missed anything?" she practically swooned. "You only missed Vincent Perez in tights."

When I finally saw it, I realised that La Reine Margot, Patrice Chéreau's grim, crackling tableau of the St Bartholomew's Day massacre, had a lot more going for it than Perez's well-turned calves. But don't discount the lure of the tights. The highest-minded film academics will all tell you that this is precisely the erotic appeal of the genre - the chance to see your favourite stars wearing fetching (and, in some cases, fetishising) attire from bygone days.

It's only when there's a deeper correlation between the clothes and the way people behave when wearing them that a costume drama really takes off - when clothes become metaphor for manners and vice versa. The best Cannes costume extraganza in recent memory was Patrice Leconte's Ridicule. The entire story, about court politics in Versailles, revolved around the question of how you wore a wig, what you said when you wore it, and what sins of vanity and folly those wigs covered: it's a film about costume and custom.

What can be irksome about historical drama is the neurotic fastidiousness of the whole undertaking. If a costume picture works, no single item of clothing should jump out in its magnificence. At the same time, no corner of the screen must be left undressed: you can't have a Regency beau if he isn't walking down a Regency street patrolled by Regency horses and illuminated by a Regency sunset. That's the strange logic of historical reconstruction - not just the actors, but the sets, architecture, even lighting must, in a sense, be in costume.

That factor explains the brilliance of Ridley Scott's Gladiator, released in Britain this week, which may prove to be the most fiendishly thorough costume epic ever made: there isn't a single element on screen at any point that hasn't in some sense been dressed for the occasion. And the strange result is that, after a while, you don't really see Gladiator as a costume film. Where Hollywood Roman epics traditionally flashed their togas with pride, Scott's film comes across not as a costume drama, which suggests something stagey and static, but as an action picture that moves. Because every centimetre of the screen is decked out to full period effect, Gladiator doesn't so much evoke the past as create its own vivid present.

After a while, you barely notice what people are wearing. At least, you don't look at them as if they're wearing old clothes. The notable exceptions are Joaquin Phoenix's eerie talcum-white armour, and the flowing robes worn by Connie Nielsen, with their elaborate cross-laced ribbons - be very surprised if the Noble Roman Matron look isn't in this season. Even blood-and-sand classical epics are susceptible to the chic of a well-cut gown, or as costume scholars call it, the Shock of the Frock.

webTitle: Protesters defy Milosevic in his home town

fields.headline: Protesters defy Milosevic in his home town
fields.standfirst:
Police arrest demonstrators and seal off Pozarevac in an attempt to prevent opposition rally

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The home town of Slobodan Milosevic was the focus of a major clampdown on opposition to the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic across Serbia yesterday.
fields.body:
The home town of Slobodan Milosevic was the focus of a major clampdown on opposition to the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic across Serbia yesterday.

Police arrested an opposition leader, journalists and members of the youth resistance movement and set up checkpoints on all roads in and out of Pozarevac - where the Yugoslav president grew up and has a home - to prevent opposition supporters and political leaders arriving for a major opposition rally.

But around 100 members of the Youth Resistance Movement, Otpor, and other anti-Milosevic activists slipped past the cordon to interrupt a hastily convened counter-meeting set up by officials in Pozarevac's central square.

By mid-afternoon, it was the scene of an extraordinary stand-off, with the banner-waving anti-Milosevic protesters on one side and Socialist party officials from the city seeking to address 100 or so party stalwarts on the other.

A small group of men in black trousers, black leather jackets and sunglasses - the usual garb of men working as Milosevic family bodyguards - moved to within inches of the jeering protesters.

The demonstrators did not shift or back away, but continued distributing leaflets and brandishing their flags and placards, bearing the clenched fist symbol of Otpor.

One 23-year-old Otpor protester said: "We want to show our resistance to the system. Milosevic is afraid of the youth of Otpor. We have parents. We have relatives. We have so many people who know us and know we are not the terrorists which the regime calls us. We just want to live like ordinary people."

A hundred yards from the stand-off, the Serbian minister of the interior, Veljko Stoiljkovic, watched, as did several dozen young men wearing T-shirts with the Serbian national flag. It was as if they might be waiting for a signal.

Pozarevac is a haven for the Milosevic family and its enterprises. Marko Milosevic runs the Madonna disco, which has the reputation as the hottest nightclub in the Balkans, a cybercafe and coffee shop called Passage in the town.

Many of President Milosevic's friends from childhood in Pozarevac have become significant figures in his regime. The interior minister is among this group, as was Zika Petrovic, the recently assassinated head of Yugoslav Airlines JAP, who was gunned down in Belgrade just over a week ago.

Several domestic and foreign journalists and cameramen, who had also slipped into the town through the police cordon, watched as the stand-off continued. Every minute threatened to explode into violent confrontation, if either side made a wrong move.

The authorities had sought in every way to block the rally, held on Victory Day, which traditionally celebrates the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945. A lorry taking stage and sound equipment into the town was stopped en route shortly after midnight yesterday, said Dra gan Curcija, an official from the opposition democratic party in Pozarevac.

An opposition leader, Nenad Canak from the League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina, was arrested early yesterday morning on his way from Novi Sad to Pozarevac.

In Belgrade, opposition leaders held an emergency meeting after coaches they had ordered to take them to the rally failed to turn up or were sent back to Belgrade by police at checkpoints.

The non-government radio station B292 and the Belgrade television station Studio B, controlled by the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement, were taken off the air. Opposition leaders said they would hold a major demonstration in the capital within days to protest at yesterday's events.

The incident that sparked this crisis happened last week in Pozarevac, when three members of the Otpor movement became involved in a fracas with bodyguards of Milosevic's son Marko. They were arrested, held beyond the maximum legal detention period and appeared to have been beaten when they appeared before an investigating magistrate on Monday.

One, Radoje Lukovic, had a 10cm head wound, the other two were in bandages with bloodstained pads around their eyes, said their lawyer, Borivoje Bokovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement.

They had been released, but yesterday they were arrested again, with a freelance reporter for non-government media who works in Pozarevac and is a brother of one of the three.

fields.headline: Young Serbs provoke authorities
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Their symbol is the clenched fist of defiance and they are hungry for the overthrow of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Their symbol is the clenched fist of defiance and they are hungry for the overthrow of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

Many young anti- Milosevic activists belong to the resistance movement, Otpor, whichburst on to the political scene in November.

Formed as an underground movement, Otpor now commands support from more than 20,000 young people across the country, particularly in university towns.

Activists claim that Mr Milosevic fears Otpor because of the movement's daring and energy.

The crisis in Serbia yesterday was sparked by the arrest of three members of the resistance movement, but it was just the latest incident in which Otpor supporters have deliberately provoked the regime.

Almost every week in recent months Otpor activists have organised actions: handing out leaflets, holding meetings or anti-Milosevic street theatre and pasting their clenched fist posters on walls across the country.

Almost every week, in response, men in plain clothes have attacked Otpor activists found with leaflets and posters. Police reg- ularly arrest them or call them in for what is termed "an informative talk".

One former student, who slipped through the police net to enter the town of Pozarevac yesterday, said: "I think that Milosevic believes that Otpor has become too strong. Otpor has become now a social movement not just a political movement."

Many young anti- Milosevic activists belong to the resistance movement, Otpor, whichburst on to the political scene in November. Formed as an underground movement, Otpor now commands support from more than 20,000 young people across the country, particularly in university towns. Activists claim that Mr Milosevic fears Otpor because of the movement's daring and energy. The crisis in Serbia yesterday was sparked by the arrest of three members of the resistance movement, but it was just the latest incident in which Otpor supporters have deliberately provoked the regime. Almost every week in recent months Otpor activists have organised actions: handing out leaflets, holding meetings or anti-Milosevic street theatre and pasting their clenched fist posters on walls across the country. Almost every week, in response, men in plain clothes have attacked Otpor activists found with leaflets and posters. Police reg- ularly arrest them or call them in for what is termed "an informative talk". One former student, who slipped through the police net to enter the town of Pozarevac yesterday, said: "I think that Milosevic believes that Otpor has become too strong. Otpor has become now a social movement not just a political movement."

webTitle: Size matters for Sorrell's global vision

fields.headline: Size matters for Sorrell's global vision
fields.standfirst: Advertisers demand a single message. That's why Young & Rubicam will fall to WPP
fields.trailText: WPP chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell flew into New York yesterday in an attempt to seal a $5.5bn (£3.6m) takeover of US rival Young & Rubicam and so finalise the largest deal in the history of advertising.
fields.body:
WPP chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell flew into New York yesterday in an attempt to seal a $5.5bn (£3.6m) takeover of US rival Young & Rubicam and so finalise the largest deal in the history of advertising.

The master of marketing and public relations left an unfortunate news story behind: his stock was falling heavily on the London stock market. WPP shares fell 90p to 822p after similar falls on Monday, a result of City jitters about the proposed all-stock agreement.

Critics pointed to Sir Martin's ill-timed acquisition of advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather which nearly bankrupted WPP 10 years ago. Other nervous investors just feared the proposed deal would dilute the UK company's stock too much.

An announcement about a deal is expected within days. WPP has agreed to pay 0.835 of its own American depository receipt shares for each share in Y&R - the equivalent of $63 for each Y&R share based on Friday's closing price.

The problem for WPP is that the more the company's stock price falls, the more its shares are diluted by the acquisition. But WPP last night shrugged off the market turbulence, pointing out that trading volumes were relatively small. "Sell-offs are only to be expected as people take profits," said one insider.

Top of a cycle

At SG Securities they were concerned that WPP would be buying at the top of a cycle. Media analyst Anthony de Larrinaga said this uncomfortably mirrored the Ogilvy & Mather purchase.

Timing aside, most agree with WPP's ambitions to expand. The takeover of Y&R would put the company at the top of the industry, ahead of rivals Omnicom and Interpublic.

Globalisation has been driving consolidation by advertising agencies and Y&R is one of the few independents still waiting to be snapped up. It is losing its independence barely two years after going public.

Large clients, such as carmakers and financial services firms, have been consolidating across the world and the internet has also played a role in accelerating the need for global marketing messages.

Already Ogilvy & Mather and sister company J Walter Thomson have been pooling their media buying through the creation of a combined company, Mindshare.

Driving force

There is scope for more consolidation with Y&R but this is not the driving force behind the merger. Ford and its rivals operate in worldwide markets and they want the people in charge of their advertising and marketing to do the same.

Ford, IBM, and American Express would all be clients of the combined group. All three of the leading advertising and marketing groups have kept their creative subsidiaries autonomous to prevent perceived conflicts of interest.

The concerns of Ford ended a possible deal between Y&R and Publicis of France, apparently because the car company objected to the French company's commitment to Renault.

The run up to the anticipated deal between WPP and Y&R was anything but smooth. Negotiations frequently broke up over issues such as Y&R's demands that it be guaranteed 12 months of autonomy after a takeover.

This was unacceptable to Sir Martin, as was the compensation package outlined by Y&R's senior executives. But he has re turned to the negotiating table with a higher offer in return for a free pair of hands.

Thomas D Bell Jr, chief executive of Y&R, has been offered the chairmanship of the enlarged WPP but it is unclear whether he will accept.

His financial director, Michael Dolan, would take over as chief executive of Y&R while Sir Martin would remain chief executive of the holding group.

The enlarged WPP, in which the UK firm would control two-thirds of the eq uity, will make siblings of public relations firms such as Hill & Knowlton, Burson-Marsteller and Cohn & Wolfe.

The public relations sector, along with market research and sales promotion, has been making fat profits on the back of internet start-ups. It too is poised to go global.

In the meantime the in-house PR team at WPP and Y&R might need to be marshalled for a more parochial matter: how to sell their parent companies' merger to those sceptical investors.

Slogan generators to the world

WPP's planned takeover of Young & Rubicam makes it the largest advertising agency in the world. But it will compete head to head with the next two largest: Omnicom and Interpublic .

The enlarged British-based WPP would bring together agencies Y&R , J Walter Thomson and Ogilvy & Mather , which are ranked by revenue, number 11 in the world, number four and number 10. They have combined revenues of $5.2bn.

Omnicom controls a stable of agencies led by BBDO (number three), DDB (number seven) and TBWA (15). Omnicom was formed in 1986 and produces revenues of $5.1bn.

Interpublic controls ad agencies McCann-Erickson (number two), Lowe Lintas & Partners (13), and Draft (24). The present number one single agency is Japan's Dentsu .

The holding company was created in 1960 although it has its origins in the Alfred W Erickson agency, formed in 1902. Its operating firms now employ 23,000 people in 110 countries and produce revenues of $4.6bn.

webTitle: I'm floored, says winner of £75,000 fiction prize

fields.headline: I'm floored, says winner of £75,000 fiction prize
fields.trailText: A book praised by a critic last year as "too good" to win the £21,000 Booker Prize yesterday won instead the world's richest fiction prize worth £75,000.
fields.body:
A book praised by a critic last year as "too good" to win the £21,000 Booker Prize yesterday won instead the world's richest fiction prize worth £75,000.

Nicola Barker, 34 - who has so far not made large sums from writing - carried off the Irish IMPAC literary award for her novel Wide Open against a formidable field which included Philip Roth and Toni Morrison.

Ms Barker, who lives in Hackney, east London, said: "I'll have to pick myself up off the floor. I always said that winning doesn't matter in literature but now that I've won I think it's great".

She said the first thing she would buy with the prize money was a new pair of running shoes.

The four-year-old IMPAC award is the biggest for a single work of fiction. Funded by the US management consultancy Improved Management Profitability and Control, it is run by Dublin corporation libraries department.

It has not yet acquired the prestige of the Booker or of the Prix Goncourt, which gives only 50 francs (about £5). But it has come to be nicknamed the "honeypot prize" because of the avid worldwide entry it draws.

Ms Barker was up against two other Barkers - Pat and Clive. The Bs alone among her 104 competitors included Nicholson Baker, Julian Barnes, Ronan Bennett, Judy Blume, William Boyd and Anita Brookner.

Among heavyweights lower down the alphabet were Sebastian Faulks, Nadine Gordimer, Robert Harris, Nick Hornby, Milan Kundera, Hanif Kureishi, Penelope Lively, Ian McEwan, Joyce Carol Oates, William Trevor and Tom Wolfe. The shortlist of seven included Roth's I Married a Communist, Morrison's Paradise, and Cormac McCarthy's Cities of the Plain.

In singling out Wide Open, a a tale of two estranged brothers on the isle of Sheppey, the judges said it focused on marginal lives, the dispossessed and the apparently mad. They praised its "manic energy and taut eloquence worthy of a large, serious and global readership" and its stunning manipulation of language.

"Wide Open is word perfect, witty and ironic. Its dialogue sparkles and its chiselled sentences display both a razor-sharp comic sensibility and flawless structure," they said.

Ms Barker said: "I am greatly influenced by where I live in the Hackney Downs. It's full of life with people always shouting in the street at each other - just like I tend to do."

In an interview earlier this year, Ms Barker said she had been a "morose" teenager after her parents emigrated to South Africa when she was nine and split up there. She returned to Britain with her mother when she was 15. "Cambridge [university] was a disaster for me. People were very cruel.

"There's this huge sterotype in fiction about what a normal person is. I often feel as if writers are trying to write about normal people, or a concept of normality, so that everyone will be comforted. Well, I'm not interested in comforting people."

She also indicated that her publishers, Faber and Faber, may be disappointed if they hope to capitalise on the prize by getting her to give literary readings.

fields.headline: How to cope in hospital
fields.standfirst: After a series of alarming reports about hospital treatment, the Guardian's medical adviser, Dr Ann Robinson, advises you on how to steer a safe course through medical services
fields.trailText: After a series of alarming reports about hospital treatment, the Guardian's medical adviser, Dr Ann Robinson, advises you on how to steer a safe course through medical services.
fields.body:
Reading recent reports about the Bristol heart babies and the Staffordshire babies treated with experimental incubators, you could be forgiven for never wanting to set foot in a hospital again. But events can overtake you - a baby born prematurely who will die without intervention, a surgical emergency such as a ruptured appendix or a life threatening illness such as meningitis. Hospitals can and do save lives and avert disaster far more often than they screw up. But how do you know whether you're getting safe and good treatment and where do you go for advice?

Good practice in hospitals:

Autonomy You are given the right to choose the best course of action after being fully informed of the pros and cons of the various options.

Beneficience Treatment is more likely to do good than harm.

Consent Of huge importance. Don't sign any consent form until you are satisfied that you understand what you're signing. If you are in any doubt, ask to discuss the issues with a senior member of staff. Don't let anyone do anything interventionist unless you have signed a consent form.

Confidentiality Doctors, nurses and hospital managers have a duty of care to you as a patient. They are not allowed to discuss you with members of your family without your express consent.

Equity in decision making You should feel that you are an equal partner in the decision making process: not patronised, ignored or overlooked.

Useful sources of advice:

Community Health Councils

Act as patient advocates, liaising with medical authorities

Website (under development): www.achcew.org.uk
Telephone 020 7609 8405 to find the number of your local CHC

General Medical Council

Lists registered doctors and investigates complaints against doctors after they have been dealt with by the local health authority Website: www.GMC-UK.org

National Association for Patient Participation (NAPP)

Helps to set up patient participation groups, especially in primary care (GP surgeries etc)

Telephone: 0151 630 5786

webTitle: Don't blame the captains: blame the press

fields.headline: Don't blame the captains: blame the press
fields.standfirst: Jennifer Gibbons argued in last weekend's Punter's Point that a succession of England Test captains have proved to be 'an elite group of professional losers'. Do you agree? Here is what readers had to say about her article. To add your views to the debate, email beamer@guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Jeroen ten Berg from Tilburg, Netherlands, writes The problem cannot be the lack of leadership qualities of England's most recent captains. If that particular quality is so important, why have Australia been so successful for the past decade when their policy is to name the best twelve players in the country and then appoint a captain from them?
fields.body:
Jeroen ten Berg from Tilburg, Netherlands, writes The problem cannot be the lack of leadership qualities of England's most recent captains. If that particular quality is so important, why have Australia been so successful for the past decade when their policy is to name the best twelve players in the country and then appoint a captain from them?

The fact is that Australia have (at least) two reasons why their team is performing better than England. Firstly, they stay focused and play every game to win. This they do because they do not have to play 16 county matches in addition to Tests and one-dayers; the Test players don't even appear in many Shield matches. Therefore, their minds are a lot more focused and their will to win is a lot stronger than in the English game. In England there is so much cricket that both body and mind are exhausted after the season and because of the workload the English players are more often injured than their Australian counterparts.

The next reason that the English team has underperformed for more than a decade is the selection policy. You only have to look at the Ashes series in 1989 to see the difference. In that series Australia played 12 players in the six matches, using the same 11 for the last five games. England used 29 players, of which 13 players were given just one match to prove their worth. You can say that the selectors were hampered in their selections by the rebel tour going to South Africa later that year, but you can't blame players for opting for the money when their future in the England squad is so insecure.

It would be to easy to blame the selectors for the entire state of English cricket. I think the reason they made the decisions they did was because of the English press. Every time an English player makes a hundred or gets a five-wicket haul, the papers write him up and urge his inclusion in the England squad. Then when he doesn't perform they hammer the selectors and want him replaced by another young prospect. Central contracts are an answer to the problems of English cricket if the selectors finally have enough courage to stick with those players and not replace them whenever they make a bad score or bowl a bad spell. It took Steve Waugh 42 innings to get to his first century and now he has made 150 against every Test nation in the world!

Jennifer Mills from Dubai, United Arab Emirates, writes Patricia Gibbons's comments are unusual, though not very original. We've heard England's lack of form blamed on everyone from the Chairman of the ECB to the groundsmen at Lord's, but to bring in the name of a leading supermarket chain is adding a new twist altogether. I'm not too well up on what Lord MacLaurin did at Tesco, and neither do I think it relevant to the current state of English cricket. I do wholeheartedly agree that there is scope for improvement - and lots of it. However, to go as low as to label England's cricketers a group of professional losers smacks of a personal dislike for one or more players: Michael Atherton in particular.

In this respect, Ms Gibbons makes some interesting points. She observes that Atherton was appointed with barely any qualifications. Well, just his ten or so 'A'levels and a Cambridge honours degree, but other than that no formal England cricket captain qualifications, references and guarantees to state that he would do the job 100 per cent to everyone's satisfaction - and produce a century each time he donned the pads. Then of course Atherton made the mistake of greedily hanging on to the job of England skipper for a record number of Tests. All the while, hugely talented England players with exceptional leadership capabilities were lining up, begging Michael to leave, but naturally he refused, and in doing so, he single-handedly and deliberately sabotaged England's otherwise certain ascent to the top of the international cricket ladder. Good points.

No points though for originality. Even with a fresh dollop of vindictiveness, the "Let's blame Michael, we've never liked him anyway" argument has worn awfully thin. Exhausted by just about every second rate columnist seeking his two minutes of fame in the tabloids. We are now in May 2000: it is perhaps time to stop blaming Michael Atherton for being England captain from 1993-98, for every match lost during that time and since then, as well as for England's current lack of form.

Personally, I think the man deserves a medal. For his style, his dedication, his determination, his integrity and most of all for his ability to keep his mouth shut. When he did speak and made a correct observation about the state of county cricket earlier this year, the second-rate columnists had a field day again.

One wonders what they will write about when Michael finally decides to call it a day. On that very sad day for cricket, there will be no one left to blame.

Want to write your own Punter's Point? Email your opinions, musings and rants to beamer@theguardian.com. Please don't forget to include a daytime telephone number.

webTitle: Factories fight back but strong pound takes its toll

fields.headline: Factories fight back but strong pound takes its toll
fields.trailText: Manufacturing orders and output are growing in some parts of the country despite sterling's record-breaking rise against the euro, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Manufacturing orders and output are growing in some parts of the country despite sterling's record-breaking rise against the euro, according to a survey published yesterday.

The survey of regional industrial trends, carried out by the Confederation of British Industry and the consultancy Business Strategies, shows that steady domestic demand is filling up order books in several regions offsetting a decline in export orders.

But the strength of sterling against the euro is threatening to snuff out manufacturing's tentative recovery, with confidence falling in seven out of 11 UK regions in the past four months.

Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's director of economic analysis, said: "There are worrying signs that the manufacturing sector is taking a turn for the worse. Our last regional analysis showed a fragile recovery spreading slowly across the UK. This survey suggests that sterling's strength could now bring the manufacturing recovery to a premature end."

Total orders rose in four regions - the East Midlands, East of England, North-west and South-east - where the buoyancy of domestic demand offset the depressing effect of the strong pound on exports. But total orders fell sharply in Northern Ireland, the North-east and Yorkshire and Humber and the outlook for investment and employment was generally bleak.

The survey suggests jobs were cut in all regions, except the North-east, during the first quarter and will continue to be lost in the second quarter. Andrew Schofield, managing economist at Business Strategies, said: "The employment trends are a cause for concern. On the whole, regions experiencing the fastest growth in orders are shedding jobs at the fastest rate. This indicates a drive to improve productivity as regions recover. If this is the case, job losses may intensify even if other regions pick up."

fields.bodyText: Manufacturing orders and output are growing in some parts of the country despite sterling's record-breaking rise against the euro, according to a survey published yesterday. The survey of regional industrial trends, carried out by the Confederation of British Industry and the consultancy Business Strategies, shows that steady domestic demand is filling up order books in several regions offsetting a decline in export orders. Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's director of economic analysis, said: "There are worrying signs that the manufacturing sector is taking a turn for the worse. Total orders rose in four regions - the East Midlands, East of England, North-west and South-east - where the buoyancy of domestic demand offset the depressing effect of the strong pound on exports. But total orders fell sharply in Northern Ireland, the North-east and Yorkshire and Humber and the outlook for investment and employment was generally bleak. webTitle: Headley injury could deprive us of a battle within a battle

fields.headline: Headley injury could deprive us of a battle within a battle
fields.trailText: Dean Headley could miss the rest of the season, because he has to undergo spinal surgery. It's a shame, because awarding him a central contract as the England and Wales Cricket Board did, was a huge affirmation of faith in a player who was not even fit to play on the tour of South Africa just before they were issued. They clearly did not have a look at him, and picking him says a lot. It's the same for Mark Ramprakash, who was not selected but got a contract. So those who wish to see the England team reflect the ethnic makeup of the country will be disappointed that Headley's injury problems continue. Mark Butcher is now out of favour, Alex Tudor has been overtaken in the fast-bowling queue by Chris Silverwood and Alan Mullally, and Chris Lewis? Well don't even mention his name in polite circles.
fields.body:
Dean Headley could miss the rest of the season, because he has to undergo spinal surgery. It's a shame, because awarding him a central contract as the England and Wales Cricket Board did, was a huge affirmation of faith in a player who was not even fit to play on the tour of South Africa just before they were issued. They clearly did not have a look at him, and picking him says a lot. It's the same for Mark Ramprakash, who was not selected but got a contract. So those who wish to see the England team reflect the ethnic makeup of the country will be disappointed that Headley's injury problems continue. Mark Butcher is now out of favour, Alex Tudor has been overtaken in the fast-bowling queue by Chris Silverwood and Alan Mullally, and Chris Lewis? Well don't even mention his name in polite circles.

We've become used over the years to seeing Lewis and Devon Malcolm play against "the family", as it were. Could it be that this is the summer no Afro-Caribbean players will line up against the Windies? No Walsh glaring at Headley, Jamaican to Anglo-Jamaican? Does it matter? It does for the development of the game among Anglo-Caribbeans, but I don't think they'll be less interested because there are no blacks in the team.

Nor should they be given any special favours or, worse, affirmative-action picks. They have to earn their place, and on current form none of them deserves to be picked. We've debated at length in these pages about who was deserving of a contract and who wasn't, but with the exception of Ramprakash (yes that's right, he's half Asian-Caribbean/Guyanese), no one has exactly made a strong case for himself.

I've come back to the issue of contracts because although the ECB did not quite put it this way the 12 must be, if not their best players, then the ones they regard as the most valuable. It's said that the England captain Nasser Hussain played a significant part in the decision concerning Headley. Hussain strikes me as the kind of player, the kind of captain, who sets great store by loyalty. He's already made plain his admiration for players who are tireless triers. "Goughie would always be in my team," he said of Darren Gough as he went through a lean time in South Africa. He was prepared to disregard Andy Caddick's difficult label and give him another chance. The line-up for central contracts strongly suggested that Headley is the third of his preferred fast-bowling trio.

I saw signs of evident closeness between Headley and Hussain, on the England tour of the Caribbean two years ago. They surprised me and a few other members of the (not quite so barmy) army of England travelling fans in Barbados by strolling casually into our bar. They were hanging out together and had come to have a few drinks. Over chants of "Deano!" "Deano!", I was given the task of taking pictures of the fans posing with them and did my job with the admirable co-operation of both players. Once we decided to leave them alone after that, they showed the kind of matiness you see every weekend in good friends having a beer. Another of the non-cricketing memories of the tour is of Headley dealing out a pack of cards during a rain break in Antigua, in the open-plan dressing room that the teams shared - cigarette stuck between lips, pool-room style, head slightly tilted to one side so the smoke didn't get in his eyes.

This is not me being voyeuristic, but making a couple of wider points. The first is that there's an empathy there between the bowler and the man who's now his captain, because they're both - and I use the word in its widest sense - black players, but English to the soles of their boots. A magazine article questioned some time ago whether non-white players could be fully committed to England's cause. The writer should have seen Hussain, red-faced, dishevelled, utterly exhausted and bruised, after surviving a barrage from Ambrose and Walsh to score an unbeaten 40 by the end of the day in Barbados. He looked like someone who had been dragged through the jungle backwards - but he gutsed it out for his country.

That spirit is something I think he sees in Headley, who can bowl long spells full of heart and effort. Headley seems to forget he's the grandson of George, one of the greatest West Indian players of all time, when he pulls his England jumper on. Aware of it and proud, yes, but to judge from his exertions for England, damn proud of that too. The other thing that I think is valued about Headley is the spirit he brings to the dressing room. Hard trier, great team man, and his record's good too - 60 wickets at a shade under 28 each, with a healthy strike rate of 50 balls per wicket. He's not Glenn McGrath but he'll keep knocking on England's door, fitness permitting.

None of this is intended as a slight against Butcher, Tudor or the rest. "Tudes" in particular is known as a great team man with a fantastic attitude, and worked very hard in South Africa to put the bite back into his bowling. It's to show why I think that Headley deserved to take precedence. Devon Malcolm used to like trying to match the West Indian players for speed and skill, and succeeded often in the former. Those are the battles within battles that fire the imagination of many diehard Anglo-Caribbean fans. But once they're into the game, they'll scarcely notice that there's not one of their number out there representing England. They'll be thinking instead that there's more than enough on the other side.

Orin Gordon works for the BBC World Service. His Anglo-Caribbean View appears on wisden.com and CricketUnlimited every other Wednesday. Next week, Kamran Abbasi's Anglo-Asian View returns.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: I can recall transfers taking place between Manchester Utd and just about every top side in England - except Liverpool. Have the two clubs ever concluded a transfer deal? If so, when and involving whom? (And if not, why not?) asked Kevin Smith last week.
fields.body:
I can recall transfers taking place between Manchester Utd and just about every top side in England - except Liverpool. Have the two clubs ever concluded a transfer deal? If so, when and involving whom? (And if not, why not?) asked Kevin Smith last week.

As you might expect, the fierce rivalry between the clubs has limited the amount of transfer activity between them. However there has been the odd moment in history (albeit from a long time ago) where this mutual antipathy has briefly dissipated. At the end of the second world war, for instance, Matt Busby retired as a player from Liverpool to become manager at Old Trafford.

But the last player to move between the clubs was Phil Chisnall back in April 1964. The inside-right played 35 games for United before his transfer to Liverpool for a then-substantial sum of £25,000. But Chisnall never established himself at Anfield, although he did play in Liverpool's first European match (against Reykjavik in August 1964) and in the first-ever Match of the Day game (a 3-2 win over Arsenal). But after being dropped after a defeat at Leeds in the next match, he never re-established himself in the first team, and his record for Liverpool makes sorry reading. In three seasons at the club he played just eight times (scoring two goals) before he was transferred to Southend in 1967. Thanks to Darin Wright and Luke Salaman.

I recently foolishly entered an argument with a knowledgeable friend about the football-playing history of top flight managers. With absolutely no proof to back up my case, I tried to tell him that it is possible to enter football management at a respectable level without having played the game. Now, after much brain-wracking I am beginning to wish that I hadn't, as there's a tenner on it. Can you help? asked a desperate Matthew May last week.

Rest assured Matthew - your tenner is safe. Among the names we've had suggested are former England no.2 Lawrie McMenemy (who was in the Coldstream Guards before entering football), Brentford manager Ron Noades, and ex-Italy boss Arrigo Sacchi, who deflected criticism of never having played the game by saying: "You don't need to be a horse to be a jockey."

In Holland at the moment, as Rick Buur points out, there's currently a polemic about this very subject, which was started by Johan Cruyff. Cruyff has argued that it is absolutely necessary for a coach to have been a top player. But journalist Paul Onkenhout claims that the best coaches are minor players with not enough skill for the top but enough ambition (Van Gaal, Hiddink, Advocaat to name a few). In fact many top Dutch coaches haven't played professional football at all. Leo Beenhakker of Feyenoord was only an amateur player before he started coaching when he was 25. And Heerenveen coach Foppe de Haan brings his team into the Champions League next year without ever having kicked a ball professionally himself (although he was the man who taught all the above managers at the Dutch FA's trainers course).

There's an even greater tendency for non-playing coaches in Norway, according to Raymond Njerve. Over there, they emphasise the education of the trainers - not necessarily what they have done in the game. And several managers - Tom Nordlie, Nils Johan Semb and Lars Tjaernes for instance - haven't much of a background in professional football, but have still become top coaches.

Last week we mentioned five cities that have had two different teams in the European Cup semi-finals (Milan, Glasgow, Dundee, Moscow and Madrid).

But as Jon Cudby points out, there's also a sixth - Belgrade. Partizan lost in the final to Real Madrid in 1966 (having beaten Man Utd in the semi-final) and Red Star won the competition in 1991, beating Marseille on penalties.

I'm trying to track down a forward, a chap named 'O Monterrubio'. I don't know what nationality he is, but he is aged about 26. I don't know who he plays for, but it is possibly a French club asks Ben Harrington

The player you are referring to is the French striker Olivier Monterrubio, who plays for Nantes. Monterrubio - who is not as old as you think (he'll be 24 on 8th August) - was crowned young player of the year in France last spring, and six days after picking up his honour scored the only goal in the 1999 French Cup final to clinch Nantes' first major trophy for four years.

Can you help?

What is the highest number of different countries represented by the starting 22 players in a Premiership match? asks Phil Brown

Hello! Who is responsible for the nutty situation that Heathrow Airport lacks any and all football memorabilia? Last December I made a stop-over (from Amsterdam to Montreal) and tried to get some Manchester United items. Alas, not one store carried anything from MU, or from any other football club for that matter. Doesn't England know how to honour its heroes? Cheers, Jesse Vorst.

Answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

webTitle: 'Arrogant' doctors rapped on child organ removal

fields.headline: 'Arrogant' doctors rapped on child organ removal
fields.standfirst: Bristol inquiry calls for more regulation in dealing with deceased
fields.trailText: Doctors at Bristol Royal Infirmary who removed hundreds of organs from dead children without parental knowledge or consent had acted with "professional arrogance", according to an inquiry released today.
fields.body:
Doctors at Bristol Royal Infirmary who removed hundreds of organs from dead children without parental knowledge or consent had acted with "professional arrogance", according to an inquiry released today.

The interim report recommended a strict new code of practice to regulate the removal and retention of organs and the treatment of bereaved parents.

It includes almost 70 recommendations covering coroners' inquests and postmortem examinations carried out by hospitals. The authors criticise the way in which doctors routinely took human material from dead children for a variety of purposes and kept large collections without the knowledge of parents or the public. The hearts of 170 children at the Bristol hospital were removed during postmortem examinations and kept for educational purposes without parents' knowledge, causing great distress to those parents when they later learned that they had buried their children with organs missing. Details of the practice emerged during investigations into high death rates of children who underwent heart surgery at the Bristol hospital between 1984 and 1995. The inquiry into heart surgery at the hospital, which is being led by Professor Ian Kennedy, was widened to include the way organ removal was handled and today's report focuses on this issue.

The report found that during the inquiry's terms of reference and indeed for some time after "there was in essence, a professional arrogance, justified when necessary by the recourse to traditional paternalism, that parents, on this view, are best kept from the details but would be thankful if they knew what was being done".

The cause lay in two conflicting attitudes: that of the parents of a recently deceased child who continue to regard the organs as part of the child's body and therefore still the child; and that of the pathologists and clinicians for whom such material was simply a dehumanised specimen.

The study called for a strict code of practice to be introduced to help solve this conflict which would be based on two fundamental guiding principles: firstly and most importantly, respect for parents and their dead child; secondly, the value of continued access to human material for the advancement of medical care and treatment.

It recommended that parents should be told exactly what was happening and what the benefits would be from organ removal, as well as making sure that parents were told in an appropriate manner and at a suitable time. Evidence within the report showed that parents found themselves asked to discuss the signing of papers at a time which was too close to the death of their child, when they were "clearly and understandably unable to comprehend what was being put to them". The report recommended: "Obtaining parents' consent should be seen as a process, and not just a signing of a form. As part of that process parents should be allowed proper time to reflect and be informed that they may change their mind until such time as they sign a form indicating their consent." It was also recommended that parents should be told that they may refuse consent for the retention of organs and be able to do so in a supportive atmosphere where they had access to clear and comprehensible information.

The report also described the law regulating the removal, retention, use and disposal of human material as "obscure, uncertain and arcane" and recommended that it should be amended or clarified.

Speaking at the launch of the interim report in London, inquiry chairman Professor Ian Kennedy said it was important to recognise that the issues that the report focused upon were not confined to Bristol, but were national and should therefore have national effect. Prof Kennedy said the practice of excluding parents was "indefensible". He continued: "Parents should no longer be left out, they must be at the centre" and he added "we must recognise that the practice of the past was a product of the culture of the past". Prof Kennedy emphasised it was important to avoid blaming individuals, saying "that is not a proxy for real accountability, furthermore it is a barren substitute for real progress. The challenge for us is to look beyond the individual to the culture in which that individual works."

webTitle: Pope tells Uefa that it's time to think spiritual

fields.headline: Pope tells Uefa that it's time to think spiritual
fields.trailText: Football may be a religion but it does not appeal to the Pope in its present incarnation. God's assistant manager has laid down the law to some of the European game's movers and shakers about the dangers of Mammon.
fields.body:
Football may be a religion but it does not appeal to the Pope in its present incarnation. God's assistant manager has laid down the law to some of the European game's movers and shakers about the dangers of Mammon.

During a 45-minute audience with a high-powered Uefa delegation at the Vatican on Monday, Pope John Paul II drew on his love of the game to counsel against the growing influence of money - on the day that figures were released showing Premiership wages fast heading for the £2bn barrier.

The pontiff did not quite preach about the wages of sin but against the dangers of football losing sight of the fact that it is, at the end of the day, a sport.

"Football shouldn't become submerged by financial interests," said the former goalkeeper, demonstrating how he has kept his eye on the ball when it comes to spiralling television deals, transfer fees and salaries. "It ought to be more about the excellence of performing than about possession.

"Football must look to develop human and spiritual qualities. It is a diverse sport but the managers, agents and the media working within it should ensure that it never loses its essential characteristic as a sporting activity."

Warming to his theme, he also warned of the dangers of false idols. "Players - especially the most famous ones - should never forget they are role models for young people. It is very important for them to show human and spiritual qualities and set favourable examples.

"Football must rid itself of everything that prevents it from being a positive example of solidarity, brotherhood and mutual respect."

The meeting was organised by the Italian FA, who invited representatives of all 51 members of Uefa to a weekend celebration of the millennium and the Pope's jubilee. The delegation invited to the Pope's audience numbered about 160 and included the chief executive Gerhard Aigner and the Football Association's executive director David Davies.

"Meeting the Pope was a very moving experience," said Davies. "He is an immense figure on the world stage, revered by catholics and non-catholics alike. Such an opportunity comes once in a lifetime. I thought it was quite a humbling experience. It was a privilege that I will never forget."

Earlier Davies had used the weekend to lobby the Uefa representatives about England's 2006 World Cup bid. But that does not mean God is now on our side. "I shook hands with the Pope," added Davies, "but so did Germany's representative."

webTitle: The best hit scene: Ghost Dog

fields.headline: The best hit scene: Ghost Dog
fields.trailText: Brooklyn. Ghost Dog (Forest Whitaker) drives through the night. His voiceover begins.
fields.body:
Brooklyn. Ghost Dog (Forest Whitaker) drives through the night. His voiceover begins.

"It's bad when one thing becomes two. One should not look for anything else in the Way of the Samurai. It's the same for anything else that is called a Way. If one understands things in this manner, he should be able to hear about all Ways. Every law and moral, in accord with his own."

Eventually, he reaches a suburban house. Inside, mob soldier Handsome Frank (Richard Portnow) relaxes with Louise Vargo (Tricia Vessey), the daughter of his Mafia captain.

Louise slumps on the couch, watching an old cartoon in which an octopus dances maniacally. Jaunty music fills the house, as Ghost Dog creeps inside.

Frank leans down to address his girlfriend. He pushes her glass towards her.

"Have some more wine, Louise."

She glares up at him.

"I don't want any more wine."

Suddenly Frank spins around to see Ghost Dog standing at his open front door. A look of confused irritation flashes across his face.

"What the fuck? Whaddya want?"

Ghost Dog doesn't respond.

"What, you want my Rolex?"

Ghost Dog pulls out a revolver, with a silencer attached. He fires three times at Frank, who falls to the floor.

Stepping inside, Ghost Dog notices Louise. For a moment, they stare at one another in mutual incomprehension.

See also: The Manchurian Candidate, Prizzi's Honor, Get Carter, Scarface

Don't see also: Assassins

Pointless trivia: Richard Portnow played the corpse of Dr Beardsley in David Fincher's Seven.

fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip pumped full of liquid nitrogen and put into cold storage for the benefit of future generations
fields.trailText: The Sun reports that the deal to bring Sergei Rebrov to Spurs has stalled after Dinamo Kiev demanded an extra £2m in transfer fees. Spurs had agreed a £10m deal with the club for Rebrov, but the Ukrainian champions now want £12m. Spurs will refuse to go that high as they have earmarked £5m of their £15m summer budget for the signing of Ben Thatcher from Wimbledon.

Spurs had agreed a £10m deal with the club for Rebrov, but the Ukrainian champions now want £12m. Spurs will refuse to go that high as they have earmarked £5m of their £15m summer budget for the signing of Ben Thatcher from Wimbledon.

The Mirror reports that Spurs are set to buy a partner for Sergei Rebrov: Mickael Gerard of French folk heroes Calais. "I am in actual contact with an English Premier League club," Gerard - who scored 25 times for the Cup finalists this season - told the paper.

The Sun believes that Middlesbrough are on the verge of bringing Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink back to England in a £10m deal. However the Daily Mail reports that Bryan Robson will face stiff competition from Real Madrid and quote Hasselbaink as saying "I would like to stay with a Spanish club".

Phil Babb and Gary McAllister will swap clubs this summer, according to the Daily Star. Liverpool defender Babb, who hasn't featured for the Merseysiders this season, will return to Coventry, the club he left six years ago, in exchange for current club captain McAllister who is much admired by Gerard Houllier.

Arthur Numan wants to join Liverpool, according to Planet Football. They quote the Rangers full-back as saying: "Anfield is the place to be. I will play for Rangers for another year then Liverpool definitely." However, Teamtalk claim that Numan is perfectly happy at the Scottish champions. "I have two years of my contract to run at Ibrox," he told the site. "I hope to play for at last one more season and then discuss a new deal."

John Hartson will be the subject of a £7m bid from Blackburn Rovers if Wimbledon are relegated next weekend. The Mirror believes that Rovers manager Graeme Souness will finance a move for the Welshman by selling Matt Jansen to Rangers.

The Daily Mail reports that Michael Duberry is likely to leave Leeds United this summer and return to the capital.

fields.headline: Cannes
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the film festival on the net...
fields.trailText: 1. The Cannes film festival starts today on the glittering shores of the Côte d'Azur.
fields.body:
1. The Cannes film festival starts today on the glittering shores of the Côte d'Azur.

2. From now until May 21 directors from across the world will battle to get their film noticed and win the prestigious Palme d'Or.

3. Previous winners include Francis Ford Coppola, Quentin Tarantino and Mike Leigh.

4. The festival's strength is that Hollywood largely ignores it. Stars turn up but the studios stay away to leave the field open for independent film makers and international entries.

5. Of 23 films competing for the top prize, seven come from Asia, nine from Europe and four from the United States.

6. It helps that Cannes is a rather pleasant place in May.

7. However festival virgins and independent film makers visiting the city on a shoestring will need all the help they can get in a playground of the rich and famous.

8. To enter, a film must have been produced in the 12 months preceding the festival, not shown at any other event, and submitted by March 31. So tough.

9. Once a picture had be diplomatically sensitive: Alain Resnais' Hiroshima mon amour was dropped from the official selection in 1959 so as not to upset the American government.

10. But in the spirit of huge celebrity get-togethers everywhere, the festival is also a place for good old self-congratulatory parties.
