webTitle: 'Arrogant' doctors rapped on child organ removal

fields.headline: 'Arrogant' doctors rapped on child organ removal
fields.standfirst: Bristol inquiry calls for more regulation in dealing with deceased
fields.trailText: Doctors at Bristol Royal Infirmary who removed hundreds of organs from dead children without parental knowledge or consent had acted with "professional arrogance", according to an inquiry released today.
fields.body:
Doctors at Bristol Royal Infirmary who removed hundreds of organs from dead children without parental knowledge or consent had acted with "professional arrogance", according to an inquiry released today.

The interim report recommended a strict new code of practice to regulate the removal and retention of organs and the treatment of bereaved parents.

It includes almost 70 recommendations covering coroners' inquests and postmortem examinations carried out by hospitals. The authors criticise the way in which doctors routinely took human material from dead children for a variety of purposes and kept large collections without the knowledge of parents or the public. The hearts of 170 children at the Bristol hospital were removed during postmortem examinations and kept for educational purposes without parents' knowledge, causing great distress to those parents when they later learned that they had buried their children with organs missing. Details of the practice emerged during investigations into high death rates of children who underwent heart surgery at the Bristol hospital between 1984 and 1995. The inquiry into heart surgery at the hospital, which is being led by Professor Ian Kennedy, was widened to include the way organ removal was handled and today's report focuses on this issue.

The report found that during the inquiry's terms of reference and indeed for some time after "there was in essence, a professional arrogance, justified when necessary by the recourse to traditional paternalism, that parents, on this view, are best kept from the details but would be thankful if they knew what was being done".

The cause lay in two conflicting attitudes: that of the parents of a recently deceased child who continue to regard the organs as part of the child's body and therefore still the child; and that of the pathologists and clinicians for whom such material was simply a dehumanised specimen.

The study called for a strict code of practice to be introduced to help solve this conflict which would be based on two fundamental guiding principles: firstly and most importantly, respect for parents and their dead child; secondly, the value of continued access to human material for the advancement of medical care and treatment.

It recommended that parents should be told exactly what was happening and what the benefits would be from organ removal, as well as making sure that parents were told in an appropriate manner and at a suitable time. Evidence within the report showed that parents found themselves asked to discuss the signing of papers at a time which was too close to the death of their child, when they were "clearly and understandably unable to comprehend what was being put to them". The report recommended: "Obtaining parents' consent should be seen as a process, and not just a signing of a form. As part of that process parents should be allowed proper time to reflect and be informed that they may change their mind until such time as they sign a form indicating their consent." It was also recommended that parents should be told that they may refuse consent for the retention of organs and be able to do so in a supportive atmosphere where they had access to clear and comprehensible information.

The report also described the law regulating the removal, retention, use and disposal of human material as "obscure, uncertain and arcane" and recommended that it should be amended or clarified.

Speaking at the launch of the interim report in London, inquiry chairman Professor Ian Kennedy said it was important to recognise that the issues that the report focused upon were not confined to Bristol, but were national and should therefore have national effect. Prof Kennedy said the practice of excluding parents was "indefensible". He continued: "Parents should no longer be left out, they must be at the centre" and he added "we must recognise that the practice of the past was a product of the culture of the past". Prof Kennedy emphasised it was important to avoid blaming individuals, saying "that is not a proxy for real accountability, furthermore it is a barren substitute for real progress. The challenge for us is to look beyond the individual to the culture in which that individual works."

webTitle: Film Four and Warners announce partnership

fields.headline: Film Four and Warners announce partnership
fields.trailText: In a deal that signals its intention to raise its profile and move into larger scale production, FilmFour has entered a co-production alliance with Warner Brothers. The arrangement will reap its first harvest with Gillian Armstrong's adaptation of the Sebastian Faulks novel Charlotte Gray
fields.body:
In a deal that signals its intention to raise its profile and move into larger scale production, FilmFour has entered a co-production alliance with Warner Brothers. The arrangement will reap its first harvest with Gillian Armstrong's adaptation of the Sebastian Faulks novel Charlotte Gray, which stars Cate Blanchett as a Scottish woman who becomes an undercover agent in Nazi-occupied France.

Under the deal, Warner will co-produce around half a dozen FilmFour projects over the next three years. Warner will always take North American rights, but may also pick up other foreign territories on selected pictures.

The deal was struck by FilmFour chief exec Paul Webster with Lorenzo di Bonaventura, Warner's head of worldwide production. "Lorenzo initially approached us to discuss working together on the same kind of films that FilmFour has made its name with," commented Webster. "This is an amazing opportunity for FilmFour to learn from Warner's incredible expertise and contribute our own fresh take on things."

Said Di Bonaventura, "We are thrilled to join forces with FilmFour and tap into their excellent pedigree producing and marketing distinctive, high-quality independent films."

webTitle: A snatch of Guy Ritchie's latest

fields.headline: A snatch of Guy Ritchie's latest
fields.trailText: Ain't It Cool News has bagged the first reviews of Guy Ritchie's Lock, Stock follow-up, Snatch
fields.body:
Ain't It Cool News has bagged the first reviews of Guy Ritchie's Lock, Stock follow-up, Snatch, which stars Vinnie Jones and Brad Pitt - not a cast that assembles every day.

The first of two reviews, from a critic who calls himself 'Danger', described the film, which test-screened in London this week, as "more of the same Lock Stock stuff, with everyone shooting guns and swearing. The plot moves at such a pace you don't care that the characters are as deep as a puddle."

A second critic, Monkeeboy, is still less enthusiastic, branding the pic "terribly baffling", lampoons the Lock Stock-alike plotting, and laments that "Ritchie... equates someone saying 'You Fackin' Cahnt!' with comedy."

fields.headline: Spielberg teams up with Lego
fields.trailText: Never let it be said that Steven Spielberg is a big kid - but he's just announced a new creative partnership, with the popular children's toy, Lego
fields.body:
Never let it be said that Steven Spielberg is a big kid - but he's just announced a new creative partnership, with the popular children's toy, Lego.

The building-block giants have co-operated with Spielberg on a new digital movie-making kit that lets children create and edit their own films. The toy will be only the second entertainment product to which the ET director has lent his name - the other being the unforgettable 1996 CD-ROM Steven Spielberg's Director's Chair.

Lego will today announce the introduction of its Lego Studios Steven Spielberg MovieMaker. The set includes a digital movie camera, which plugs into a computer port. The camera has Lego blocks on the outside so users with shaky hands build and attach a Lego tripod - handy, eh? The set, which will sell in the US for $179.99, also includes Lego props such as buildings, houses and cars, as well as characters including firefighters and dinosaurs and other animals. So now we know the secret to Speilberg's success - we at Film Unlimited always thought those Jurassic Park dinosaurs looked a bit, well, blockish.

fields.headline: Cruise: because I'm worth it
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise has responded to Michael Caine's Oscar-accepting wisecrack at his expense, justifying at the same time his whopping pay packets
fields.body:
Tom Cruise has responded to Michael Caine's Oscar-accepting wisecrack at his expense, justifying at the same time his whopping pay packets. Caine, you will remember, joked that had Cruise pipped him to the Best Supporting Actor gong, the Jerry Maguire star would have had to lower his asking price correspondingly (see our Oscar report.

Says Cruise, in an interview with Cameron Crowe in Rolling Stone magazine, "Michael Caine's speech was very funny, and I enjoyed that.. But I've never done work for money, ever. ..But [after the Oscars] I went home and I thought about it. And I thought, "Is this what [people think]? ..Because I take it for granted that no one thinks that".

When pressed on the subject of his fat-cat million-dollar-plus cheque demands, however, Cruise petulantly replied, "I get paid because I'm worth it, and they should pay me that much." Ooh, get him.

webTitle: Act on Paddington inquiry, angry survivors urge

fields.headline: Act on Paddington inquiry, angry survivors urge
fields.trailText: Survivors of the Paddington rail disaster have demanded that the government heeds lessons from the inquiry which opens in London today.
fields.body:
Survivors of the Paddington rail disaster have demanded that the government heeds lessons from the inquiry which opens in London today.

Speaking this morning ahead of the inquest into the train crash in which 31 people died, solicitors for the survivors and bereaved relatives called on the government to treat the inquiry with respect and use it as a "blueprint for the future" of rail safety.

The inquiry comes amid fresh anger after yesterday's Crown Prosecution Service decision not to bring manslaughter prosecutions over the crash.

A spokeswoman for the Ladbroke Grove solicitors group said: "We're looking for this inquiry to provide a blueprint for the future. The government and rail companies must treat the inquiry with respect and make money available to implement recommendations."

At a news conference in Westminster, crash survivors spoke of their anger and "disgust" at the state of Britain's rail network.

Evelyn Crosskey and Pam Warren called on rail companies to invest more of their profits in safety. Fellow survivor Emily Schwartz from the USA said the firms should be punished for their "criminal" actions.

Lord Cullen, who chaired the inquiry into the Piper Alpha North Sea oil platform disaster in 1988, said today: "We should never lose sight of how it was that this inquiry came to be set up. We owe it to all those who have suffered in any way as a result of this disaster to make sure that its lessons are fully learnt and effective recommendations are made for the future safety of all who travel on this country's railways."

The morning rush-hour accident happened when a Thames train passed through a red light at Ladbroke Grove, two miles outside Paddington station in west London.

The Thames train, driven by Michael Hodder, 31, collided almost head-on with a London-bound Great Western high-speed train. Both Mr Hodder and the Great Western driver Brian Cooper, 52, were among those killed.

More than 400 people were injured in the accident.

The health and safety executive has already published three interim accident reports. The third of these, which came out in mid-April, said the initial cause of the accident still appeared to be that the Thames train had passed a red light at signal 109.

But it added that the reasons the train had passed the red light were likely to be complex and that "any action or omission on the part of the driver was only one such factor in a failure involving many contributory factors".

After today's opening statement from leading counsel Robert Owen, statements will follow on Thursday from the Ladbroke Grove solicitors group, Railtrack and the two train companies directly involved, Thames and Great Western.

fields.headline: Mum, do you think I'm her father? - Definitely
fields.standfirst:
In 1974, Martin Amis had a brief but passionate affair with a married woman. Later he learned she had had a child and subsequently committed suicide. In the second exclusive extract from his memoir Experience, he describes how two decades on he met that child - his daughter - for the first time

fields.trailText: In 1974,  Martin Amis  had a brief but passionate affair with a married woman. Later he learned she had had a child and subsequently committed suicide. In the second exclusive extract from his memoir Experience, he describes how two decades on he met that child - his daughter - for the first time
fields.body:
When my father was 33, he was fronting a family of five. My mother was my mother when she was 21. This was the pattern of their generation. The pattern of mine was to marry late, have children late . . . there was an awful lot of bachelorhood to be swum through . . . Ardour dwindled. Three months, six months, 12 months, with the affairs tending to elide. Tina Brown, pointing to a lacuna in my emotional repertoire, would later say that I had never had my heart broken. And I can now recognise that I somewhere harboured an unconscious distrust of love. But at the time it just felt like a process, increasingly familiar and inexorable. Ardour, then diminishing ardour, and constantly starting again.

One of the briefest of these affairs, one of the most condensed in time, caused me to pay a visit to my mother in 1977. I said I had a story I wanted to tell her. And a photograph I wanted to show her.

- Yes, dear.

Nearly three years ago, I said, I had an affair with a young woman called Lamorna. She had been and still was married to a rather older man, Patrick, whom I had known, slightly, for some time.

- Yes, dear.

I said that Lamorna and I were still friends and that I had recently had lunch with her . . . I did not go on to tell my mother that Lamorna had impressed me with her general bearing and burnish - her beauty, her sanity. Lamorna suffered from manic depression, a condition once frivolously but memorably described by a psychologist as the Arnold Schwarzenegger of mental illnesses.

I had seen her, and would again see her, in a state of tranquillised agitation, disorganised in thought, and seemingly beset by small fears, small enemies. That day at lunch it was I who was agitated (a current matter of the heart); and I remember Lamorna suggesting that I order something nonmonolithic, like a stew or a fricassee, rather than face the edifice of a steak or a chop. She knew about agitation . . . I thought she had never seemed stronger or happier. I thought she had found equilibrium. And I was wrong.

- She talked about her daughter. And then there was the photograph, Mum. She gave me the photograph.

- Yes, dear.

It was ready in my pocket. It showed a two-year-old girl in a dark flower dress, smocked at the chest, with short, puffed sleeves and pink trim. She had fine blonde hair. Her smile was demure: pleased, but quietly pleased.

My mother snatched it from my hand.

- Lamorna says I'm her father. What do you think, Mum?

She held the photograph at various distances from her eyes. Without looking up she said,

- Definitely.

- What should I do?

- Nothing. Don't do anything, dear.

In late spring 1995, I had just returned from a three-week book tour of north America . . .

My plane had arrived four or five hours late. The après book tour condition, I think, would be indistinguishable from extreme jet lag, with or without the extreme jet lag that usually accompanies it. Alone in the studio apartment, I went through my mail. One letter caused me to sit down suddenly when I was halfway through its first sentence. This, I might have murmured to my ghost, is probably for you . . .

That night, carrying the letter in my chest pocket, I escorted Isabel to the Coronet in Notting Hill Gate, where we saw An Awfully Big Adventure - the screen adaptation of Beryl Bainbridge's novel. And I'm very sorry, Beryl, but I slept through most of it, and then walked out. We regrouped for dinner at that pizza/pasta place just down the street. I took the letter from my jacket and passed it across the table.

Isabel finished reading it and said,

- . . . Good.

- There isn't any reason, is there, why this shouldn't be a great thing?

- None.

I rang my mother in the morning and sent her mind back almost 20 years. She said immediately,

- I've still got the photograph.

- Do you think you could dig it out, Mum?

- It's here on the dressing table, she said.

And now it's on the shelf in the study, within arm's reach of my desk.

I felt it was important to tell the story in the simplest possible terms. My interlocutors, after all, were aged 11 and 10: number one son, Louis, and number two son, Jacob. What I was about to reveal to them was a family matter, a private matter, but I knew it couldn't remain private. There was a feeling among my intimates that I should wait, that "the boys weren't ready" for the news. But it seemed to me that I didn't have a choice. The Fourth Estate wasn't going to care whether or not the boys were ready. Over and above this, though, I thought that the boys were ready, had always been ready. I trusted the morality of my sons.

I said, I'm going to tell a story. There was once a little girl called Delilah. She had a brother and a mother and a father. When she was two years old her mother died. Her mother killed herself. She hanged herself. Delilah grew up with her brother, raised by her father, who remarried. Then when she was 18, it was revealed that her father wasn't her real father. And so suddenly it seemed that she had no parents at all.

Louis and Jacob spoke in one voice. They had a habit, that night, of speaking in one voice.

- Poor her, they said.

- Well, boys, the real father . . . is me.

- Good, they said.

The meeting was set for seven o'clock in the bar of a Knightsbridge hotel. I arrived 20 minutes early, accompanied by an indispensable Isabel. My hands were shaking. We sat on a sofa among lamps and low tables, doilies, antimacassars. I watched the door. She knew what I looked like. And I knew that she was 19 and would arrive on the very stroke of the hour.

This time the day before, in the same bar of the same hotel, I had had a long conversation with Delilah's father, or co-father, Patrick Seale. He was the author of several books; he was also the author of the letter in my jacket pocket. Patrick told me that his original plan had been to tell Delilah everything when she turned 21. Family politics had intervened (there was the stepmother, and two further children), and now Delilah knew. She had known for some months.

And how had she reacted? Patrick described a process that began in grief and had since moved on towards something more resilient. In his super-evolved fashion, he had given Delilah a box of my books (a kind of kit) plus a video cassette of an hour-long interview. I would be coming at her partly as a mediated being, mediated by myself - and others: Delilah would presumably be aware that I had abandoned my sons to go and live with an heiress in New York, the better to squander my advances on a Liberace smile . . .

But this was a secondary or tertiary matter. At the moment of revelation, she must have been wholly indifferent to my identity (and never mind its carapace). When I tried to imagine it, I saw her aswim in a panic of lost connection. The connection - with her father, her brother - seemed lost, but it wasn't. And here was another connection waiting to be made. I thought, too, of the courage she would need on this summer evening as she mounted the steps and opened the door.

She entered.

- It's you, said Isabel.

Then hugs and kisses for the girl with my face.

"I'm very pleased and proud that you've taken it this way," I told the boys. And again the eerie unison, with the frowning duo saying: "Why would we not?" Yes, exactly. Why would you not? And when a day or two afterwards Delilah came to dinner for the first time, the boys leapt to the sound of the buzzer and ran upstairs to open the door and let her in.

All the press coverage wore an indulgent smile: it beamed fondly on us. No doubt it was Delilah's youth - her manifest innocence and vulnerability - that softened the mood. I was very glad that they hadn't tried to hurt her. But I sat through it all in the way that one tolerates (counting one's immediate blessings) the tearful interlude of a notoriously violent drunk. Our story did the rounds of the dailies and was picked up for more thoughtful treatment at the weekend. Then came another revelation.

In his essay on The Old Curiosity Shop, GK Chesterton talks about the kind of criticism or commentary that makes a writer "jump out of his boots". Such an occurrence is vanishingly rare. Nine out of 10 writers, I imagine, get through life without once experiencing it. But it does happen, and it happened to me. In the Observer, the novelist Maureen Freely staged a straightforward retrospective of my fiction and noted the punctual arrival - just in time for my third novel, Success (1978) - of a stream of lost or wandering daughters and putative or fugitive fathers, and that these figures recurred, with variations, in every subsequent book.

There was nothing I could do about this diagnosis. It chimed with something Patrick had said during our first talk on the telephone: "I expect it's been in the back of your mind." Yes, exactly: in the back of my mind. Your writing comes from the back of your mind, where thoughts are unformulated and anxiety is silent. I felt there was something almost embarrassing about the neatness and obviousness of the Freely interpretation. But it also sharply consoled me, because it meant that I had been with Delilah in spirit far more than I knew.

Delilah was a two-year-old standing on the stairs. Her older brother Orlando, who led the way, could see the hanging body. And it was Patrick who had to go in and "take her down". That void world up there is, of course, the central fact behind Delilah's origin and evolution, and not the little mystery of the lost-found father, which is good, good, only good. No mother, but more than one father, now - and much else. It does go on. When the revelation came, Delilah forfeited technical consanguinity with her half-brother and half-sister. But there were two more, a half-brother and another half-brother, waiting, like a team, just as they wait for the sound of the buzzer and then run upstairs to let her in.

I had always wanted a girl and suddenly there she was, like a mirror. For 17 years I had been worrying about her, in the back of my mind. Time, thus affronted (I thought), would give us work to do; but it hasn't been like that. Love flowed (and was soon declared). And now she and I can say the words in unison: why would it not?

Although I now had Delilah, I had not raised Delilah. And I wanted to raise a girl. I was desperate to see how the other half lived. [On November 8 1997, Fernanda Amis was born at St Mary's Hospital, Paddington.]

Our first visitor the next day was Delilah Seale. On her way up, she had stopped at the in-house florist's on the ground floor. She said,

- When she was wrapping the flowers, the woman asked me, Nephew or niece?

- What did you tell her?

Delilah's words made me happy, but they also made me realise how many days and nights I had spent on the planet.

- No, sister, I said. Sister.

During school vacations, with various friends, we cruised all day. The method: you wrote out visiting cards, with your name and number, and distributed them, by the tens of thousands, to every girl you could find on the London Underground. Then you hurried home to wait, often in vain, for your one or two calls.

Concentration was a fortress it never occurred to me to scale; and I remember gaping through hours of tuition without a thought in my head. I didn't like working. What I liked was bunking off school and hanging out with my friend Rob, and betting in betting shops (not the horses: the dogs), and mincing up and down the King's Road in skintight velves and grimy silk scarves and haunting a coffee bar called the Picasso, and smoking hash (then £8 an ounce) and trying to pick up girls. One time I said,

- Let's go down King's.

Rob turned away. I should point out here that Rob was and is about my height.

- Come on. What's the matter? We'll pick up girls.

- Where? In the Picasso?

- In the Picasso.

- I can't cope with the Picasso. I can hardly cope with being in my room.

As usual we had smoked ourselves into a state of clinical paranoia.

- What's wrong with the Picasso? Okay, we won't go to the Picasso. We'll pick up girls somewhere else.

- Where?

- Uh, that other place. Beyond the Picasso.

- But we'll end up in the Picasso.

- We won't go to the Picasso.

- I always feel such a short-arse in the Picasso.

- Me too. That's why we won't try and pick up girls in the Picasso. Come on.

- Okay. But I don't want to end up short-arseing round the Picasso trying to pick up girls.

But that's what we would end up doing. Whole school terms went by like this: wondering whether to go to the Picasso.

A while later, and very briefly, Rob and I hit the deb scene. It looked good at first but here we faced the giantesses of the gentry. The women were all elongated by centuries of huge meals, and so were all the men, and we felt, we admitted, as if we were walking around between everybody else's legs.

And my academic career started to fall into a pattern: one O-level every other year. I didn't have much time for reading, but when I did read, I read comics and, after I'd done that, I reread them.

Quietly, patiently, unobtrusively reeking, I lay there on the bed as my mother yelled my A-level English result up the stairs: "You failed." I arose, and spent the rest of the day transferring a sock from one end of the room to the other . . .

I did claim to myself that I wanted to be a writer. So what did I do all the time? Did I dream and doodle, did I read, did I pray? No. I was groping my way back across the bedroom, looking for the other sock.

At the party where I first exchanged whispers with Lamorna Seale, the attraction was so immediate that we disappeared into some unattended shadows; and when I emerged into the light, my girlfriend, Julie Kavanagh, burst into tears.

"What's the matter with you?" I asked, with defiant innocence - my mouth smothered in lipstick. (This was one of the few occasions when I rivalled my father, whose sexual recklessness often approached the psychotic.)

Tomorrow: my cousin, victim of Frederick West

Whole school terms went by like this: wondering whether to go to the Picasso. A while later, and very briefly, Rob and I hit the deb scene. It looked good at first but here we faced the giantesses of the gentry. The women were all elongated by centuries of huge meals, and so were all the men, and we felt, we admitted, as if we were walking around between everybody else's legs. And my academic career started to fall into a pattern: one O-level every other year. I didn't have much time for reading, but when I did read, I read comics and, after I'd done that, I reread them. I arose, and spent the rest of the day transferring a sock from one end of the room to the other . . . I did claim to myself that I wanted to be a writer. So what did I do all the time? Did I dream and doodle, did I read, did I pray? No. I was groping my way back across the bedroom, looking for the other sock. At the party where I first exchanged whispers with Lamorna Seale, the attraction was so immediate that we disappeared into some unattended shadows; and when I emerged into the light, my girlfriend, Julie Kavanagh, burst into tears. fields.headline: To rise or to rot
fields.standfirst: The government's response to housing and urban renewal is eagerly awaited, reports Peter Hetherington
fields.trailText: The government's response to housing and urban renewal is eagerly awaited, reports Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
Last year it was cities and how to regenerate them. This year it is housing and where to put it: the green fields beyond big centres, the green belt around them, or the inner core itself.

With a seemingly baffling array of policy and discussion papers coming from Whitehall departments, ministers and officials are keen to stress that there is - or soon will be - a linkage between, say, recently announced housing targets to accommodate unrelenting growth in the south-east, the housing green paper in the spring calling for more consumer choice, and the new national strategy for neighbourhood renewal.

All will become apparent, they say, when a long delayed urban white paper - the definitive regeneration policy of this parliament - is published later this year. It should pull together the various policy strands of the past month or so and point the way forward following publication almost a year ago of the report by Lord [Richard] Rogers' urban taskforce.

That weighty document, with a string of recommendations on how to revive cities, was given star billing by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, at a lavish launch in London. It was widely welcomed by many because it challenged the orthodoxy of the Treasury and Downing Street - but not necessarily Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions - with a call to put local councils, not government departments, at the heart of the regeneration process.

"They should lead the urban renaissance," the report declared. "They should be strengthened in powers, resources and democratic legitimacy to undertake this [regeneration] role in partnership with the citizens and communities they represent." We shall see.

Crucially, the Rogers report put tax adjustments and other radical fiscal measures at the heart of the urban agenda - principally harmonising VAT to discourage greenfield developments (new building is zero rated) and encourage urban regeneration. House and property improvement is held back because the government slaps 17.5% VAT on renovation schemes. Much better, say taskforce members, to harmonise the rate between greenfield building and city regeneration at, say, 5%. The trouble is, that amounts to a new house tax by any other name - and an election is looming.

Yet Prescott, it seemed, was cautiously confident of winning the harmonisation argument with the Treasury. Housing and renewal agencies, supported by backbench Labour MPs, were gearing up for change. But the Budget offered nothing. Lord Rogers, a friend of Prescott, is outwardly philosophical, if not - like the deputy prime minister - a little frustrated. All the international lessons of urban revival tell him that an innovative, more flexible use of the tax system - fiscal breaks here, low-tax (or council tax-free) zones there - are as important as Whitehall handouts for urban regeneration.

The taskforce report suggested that councils should be given a "package of tax measures, providing incentives for developers, investors . . . owner occupiers and tenants to contribute to the regeneration of urban sites and buildings that would otherwise not be developed". So to take the Rogers agenda forward, and keep the taskforce members on board, the forthcoming white paper must be bold. Whether, in the run up to an election, Downing Street and the Treasury are prepared to take up the challenge is another matter.

"The good sign is that they have said they are going to continue looking at this," Lord Rogers says diplomatically. "But it is crucial that we can take action and I am hoping that in the next year we will see change."

Naturally, he has not given up on VAT harmonsation, along with other measures, such as developers getting capital allowances to encourage them to redevelop re-cycled or "brownfield" land. "The whole question of fiscal policy has to be addressed," he says, while railing against the lack of cohesion in the Whitehall empire.

Lord Rogers has another worry: government departments, and a string of agencies, apparently working in different directions with an array of initiatives. "The problem is delivery," he says. "I am extremely concerned about education and skills and setting up structures that will be able to translate things into action." So, like others at the heart of the regeneration debate, he is biding his time, hoping for better things - but not entirely convinced that there is the will at the centre to push through the radical heart of his taskforce report.

fields.headline: Farewell to the sixties
fields.standfirst: As the bulldozers prepare to move in on Birmingham's much-maligned Bull Ring, Chris Arnot looks in on an exhibition that puts the city's transformation in perspective
fields.trailText: As the bulldozers prepare to move in on Birmingham's much-maligned Bull Ring, Chris Arnot looks in on an exhibition that puts the city's transformation in perspective.
fields.body:
When Tom Merilion first clapped eyes on Birmingham's Bull Ring, it was love at first sight. "I was seeing it through the eyes of a child," he recalls. "There were lots of people and shops and that was enough for me." By 1980, the markets complex and shopping centre had long been regarded as a national joke, a byword for bad planning. But young Tom didn't care about that. He was 12 or 13, out with his mates, hanging around record stalls, eyeing up giggly girls and listening to the raucous cries of stallholders.

Twenty years on, Merilion feels a little torn as the bulldozers prepare to move in on the Bull Ring and Brummies brace themselves for another round of redevelopment. "It deserves to be swept away because it's been allowed to become so tatty, but nostalgia stops me from seeing the buildings as totally awful," he admits between mouth-fuls of sausage, beans and chips, heavily laced with ketchup.

He is used to more refined lunches in the cafes and brasseries of Soho, where he makes television ads and rock videos for RSA (Ridley Scott Associates). Only for his more personal photographic work does he gravitate back to his home city. Hence his appearance today in the cafeteria at the Midlands Arts Centre - better known as MAC - where he's taking a brief break from overseeing the hanging of his latest exhibition, Concrete Dreams. Many of the pictures on show are aerial shots of Birmingham, for which he hired a Piper Seneca airplane "at £260 an hour, plus VAT".

Ironically, he felt that he needed to climb to 4,000 feet to get beneath the skin of the city. He wanted to see what the post-war planners saw when they peered down on their scale models.

"From up there you feel as though you could pick pieces up and move them around to make the place look more tidy," he says. "It's like looking down on a toy model."

The exhibition, due to be shown early next year at the Royal Institute of British Architects in London, would have resonances in Glasgow, Sheffield and other cities which suffered from over-zealous redevelopment in the 1960s.

It has certainly struck a chord with architect and urban designer Joe Holyoak, a reader at the Birmingham School of Architecture and founder of the pressure group Birmingham for People. "Tom's photographs have managed to reproduce the newness of these buildings 30 or 40 years after they were built," he says. "It's as though you're seeing them for the first time and you're not sure if you're looking at the real thing or a model."

In a thoughtful introduction to Merilion's exhibition, Holyoak reflects on how the centres of industrial British cities came to be transformed in the postwar years. How the blitz by the Luftwaffe created the conditions. How the war created a psychological desire for a fresh start. How radical town planning ideas had been developed in the 1930s by unfamiliar Europeans such as Le Corbusier, Ludwig Hilbersheimer and Walter Gropius. And how the past came to be seen as an obstruction on the road to the future.

"The intoxicating rhetoric about progress," Holyoak writes, "seems to have caused a collective amnesia in architects and planners about the timeless principles about what makes good places for people. Part of the reason for this was the enlargement of the scale on which area planning was done - a plan for an inner ring road or an estate for 10,000 tenants was like a military operation, with no time or inclination for a concern for the quality of a sociable street corner or a sunlit pub courtyard. . ."

For all that, Holyoak admits to a certain ambivalence in his response to the urban design of the 1960s. "Generally, we're much more cautious and conservative in our approach today," he says. "And that's not a bad thing. After all, it's the result of disillusionment with the unhappy results of the 1950s and 1960s. Yet you can't help but admire the gung-ho approach of that generation. There was so much undiluted confidence in their ability to build a totally new kind of urban future. Anything was possible.

"An awful lot of junk was built in the 1960s and 1970s, but also some outstanding pieces of work which have since been listed and incor-porated, however awkwardly, into the heritage culture."

A concrete signal box in New Street station and the elegant Alpha Tower, wedged on to the edge of Birmingham's Broad Street, are two examples featured in Merilion's exhibition.

Holyoak is well aware that his sneaking admiration, after years of outright opposition, is part of a well-worn pattern. "Every generation dismisses the work of the previous one," he says. "Then, a few decades later, it comes out of the shade. It happened to the Georgians and to the Victorians."

Indeed, it was the destruction of so much of Birmingham's Victorian heritage during the city's neo-brutalist phase which first made Holyoak, 54, such an active protester. He has been a thorn in the side of successive city planners for three decades or more.

In recent times, his criticism has been more muted, and he has even been known to praise the planning department. He heartily approved of the lowering of the "concrete corset" of the inner ring road, for instance. He likes the leisure, homes and office development around the canals at pedestrian-friendly Brindleyplace. And he couldn't help but applaud efforts to conserve the city's remaining Victorian buildings, however belated.

"In the 1960s," he says, "part of the start-again-from-scratch philosophy was the belief that you could dispense with streets and urban blocks. Now everyone - from Richard Rogers' urban taskforce downwards - is advocating going back to tried and tested patterns. It's part of the post-modern revisionism we're going through."

Today's planners and architects have access to what he calls "the computer fly-through" - the ability to look into a screen and take a virtual route through any proposed new development. They can see how it will look from ground level, rather than the distant, god-like perspective of 1960s planners so effectively reflected in Merilion's photographs. "It ought to mean that we get it right," says Holyoak.

But he still has doubts about the proposed £400m replacement for the 1960s' Bull Ring. He's concerned about the size of the "fortress-like" malls colonising more and more public space, the moving of market stalls further away from the city centre, and the absence of much provision beyond shopping. There are no plans for any homes, for instance. "The city council's policy is to encourage mixed-use developments," Holyoak says, "but it doesn't seem to be enforcing it in this case."

All the same, Holyoak knows that the new development is bound to be seen as a vast improvement on the dank passageways, the litter-strewn walkways and the grey, rain-stained concrete which so mocks the faded dreams of those god-like postwar planners.

Even Tom Merilion knows it, too.

· Tom Merilion's photographs, Concrete Dreams, are on show at the Midlands Arts Centre (0121-440 4221) in the city's Cannon Hill Park until June 4.

webTitle: BP bows to solar power pressure

fields.headline: BP bows to solar power pressure
fields.standfirst: Rethink after shareholder rebellion
fields.trailText: BP Amoco is considering a massive expansion of its renewable energy programme over and above the $250m it has already earmarked to spend over the next five years.
fields.body:
BP Amoco is considering a massive expansion of its renewable energy programme over and above the $250m it has already earmarked to spend over the next five years.

In a move that will delight its environmental critics, such as Greenpeace, the oil major plans to approach leading investors to see whether they would support a significant change of tack.

The move follows a rebellion at the recent annual meeting when a surprising number of shareholders voted in favour of a "green" motion despite opposition from the board.

Any increase in investment would almost certainly be centred on solar power in which BP Amoco has already established an industry lead. A senior executive privately admitted both the company and its main investors had been shaken by the vote at the annual meeting.

But the BP Amoco executive said the group was determined to act positively on the issue. "At the next round of meetings with investors if they do not raise the issue, which I am sure they will, then we will. If they want us to step out a bit then let's hear them give us their support," he explained.

The investment would represent a sea change in thinking about the future of the group, which is already moving away from oil to more environmentally-friendly fuels such as gas.

But the BP Amoco executive said there was no question of the second biggest oil company in the world becoming a renewable energy group overnight. It might take 20 or 30 years before that happened.

The potential commitment to renewable energy came on a day when a leading figure in the sector predicted solar power would become a multi-billion dollar market. Dr Jeremy Leggett, chief executive of the Solar Century, told an al ternative energy conference called by Dresdner Kleinwort Benson that solar power would "be to the 21st century what the microchip was to the 20th." He said the fossil fuel sector was entering its autumn years.

Plans to spend $250m over five years are significant but a drop in the ocean when put next to the group's other investment plans. Yesterday it said it intended to spend $10bn to $11bn, mainly on gas projects, over the next two years.

Gas production is set to jump 8bn cubic ft a day by the end of this year, giving BP Amoco the equivalent of 3.6m barrels of liquids, two thirds of the group's production portfolio. Oil output will remain steady at 2m barrels per day.

BP Amoco, which has just won approval for the takeover of America's Arco, unveiled record first quarter profits of $2.7bn. These were up 256% on the same period last year, mainly boosted by a big turnround in crude prices.

BP Amoco chief executive Sir John Browne said the outlook for the year was good with a "broadly positive environment". The company would now be entering a period of consolidation however with divestments and cost savings to come. BP Amoco shares fell 19.5p to end the day at 577.5p.

fields.headline: Labour MPs revolt in Commons
fields.standfirst: Livingstone joins Labour's rebel backbenchers
fields.trailText: Backbench Labour MPs last night staged one of the most serious revolts of the Blair era after the government rejected " the pleas of our supporters across the country" not to go ahead with partial-privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system (Nats).
fields.body:
Backbench Labour MPs last night staged one of the most serious revolts of the Blair era after the government rejected " the pleas of our supporters across the country" not to go ahead with partial-privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system (Nats).

Forty-five Labour MPs defied appeals from Tony Blair to back the plans amid backbench warnings that ministers have "stopped listening" to grassroots opinion.

Days after last week's local and mayoral election defeats, MPs staged one of the biggest revolts of the parliament.

Labour and Lib Dem rebels had mustered 99 votes to the government's 307, a majority of 208, in the first key vote, as the Tories abstained. London's independent mayor and MP for Brent East, Ken Livingstone, was among those voting against the government.

A further rebel Labour amendment - seeking to allow transfer of existing property, rights or liabilities only to a non profit making company and requiring Parliament's approval of any scheme - was defeated by 308 to 248, a government majority of only 60.

As a succession of MPs rose to condemn the move during the final stages of the transport bill feelings against John Prescott's £500m plans were raised still further by claims that the private sector may eventually get control of 75% of Nats, not the 51% originally envisaged.

Loyalists countered that the dilution of the government's shares would only be used as a means of raising extra capital via a shares issue and would not affect the control mechanisms which ministers will retain. It could not be done without Whitehall's consent either.

Gwyneth Dunwoody, the veteran Labour chairman of the Commons select committee on transport, joined forces with Mr Prescott's sacked deputy, Dr Gavin Strang, to warn just how serious Labour backbenchers regard the issue of public confidence in air safety.

"Do not, I beg you, make the mistake of thinking that a simple company reorganisation will maintain the same standards in the future as we have had in the past," Mrs Dunwoody told fellow MPs.

"I ask you to remember that you vote on behalf of every single person in this country and the right of the citizens of the UK to be safe every moment that they are in the skies."

In the wake of last week's poor local election results for Labour other MPs raised the stakes still further. John McDonnell, the leftwing MP from Hayes and Harlington - near Heathrow airport - complained of last week's "virtual strike among campaign activists. Why? Because they think we have stopped listening to them".

He pleaded directly with Mr Prescott to stop future privatisations because voters in general and "Labour supporters across the country ... do not want any further privatisations."

Up to 72% of voters oppose the scheme, Reading MP, Martin Salter said.

The deputy prime minister and his allies waged a fierce rearguard action in defence of the public private partnership (PPP) scheme which has been condemned as the worst option by the Labour-dominated transport select committee, despite Mr Prescott's assurances that his plan will bring vital private capital and management skills to Nats.

The deal will protect air safety in Britain's ever-more crowded skies - where traffic rises 5% a year - and will protect staff as well as the public interest by a tough but separate regulatory regime, loyalists argued.

It would also draw in private finance for Nats modernisation, and thus free other public funds for the NHS and schools, they said night.

fields.headline: Bribes bring Louisiana kingpin down
fields.trailText: Louisiana's flamboyant former governor, Edwin Edwards, was convicted on 17 counts of fraud and racketeering yesterday when he was found guilty of extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from applicants for riverboat casino licenses.
fields.body:
Louisiana's flamboyant former governor, Edwin Edwards, was convicted on 17 counts of fraud and racketeering yesterday when he was found guilty of extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from applicants for riverboat casino licenses.

Yesterday's judgment marked the culmination of nearly four decades of federal investigations of a veteran Cajun politician who had boasted he was more than a match for his prosecutors. His son, Stephen, was also found guilty for his participation. The two men solicited bribes in return for promises to influence the issuing of gambling permits.

The trial became a big source of scandal and entertainment in Baton Rouge, where the courtroom was usually full of local people fascinated by the former governor's larger-than-life personality, and his cocky manner in court.

At one point in the proceedings he was asked if he was perjuring himself. "No," he replied. "And if I were, you've got to assume I wouldn't be telling you."

Sentencing had not been decided by late yesterday evening, but legal analysts said the former governor, 72, could face a long prison term. As the guilty verdict was being read out, Edwards registered no emotion and continued taking notes on the trial. But his 35-year-old wife, Candy, broke down in tears and he hugged her.

"I regret that it ended this way, but that is the system," he said outside the court. "I have lived 72 years in the system and I will live the rest of my life in the system."

True to his reputation for producing verbal flourishes, he quoted a Chinese proverb. "If you sit by a river long enough, the dead bodies of your enemies will float by you," he said. "I suppose the feds [FBI agents] sat by the river long enough and here comes my body." Prosecutors, who had attempted to get Edwards convicted for corruption in two earlier trials, made no comment but left the Baton Rouge courthouse smiling.

Edwards had been charged in the 1980s with embezzling healthcare funds but that trial ended in a hung jury. He was acquitted in a retrial a year later. He was proud of his tenacity, claiming to have been the target of nearly two dozen state or federal investigations dating back to the 1960s when he was a congressman.

This time, the prosecution case was built on wiretaps of the former governor in which he advised a local businessman on the best way of concealing the large bribes he had paid for a gambling licence. He recommended the businessman hire a river tugboat at inflated prices.

Prosecutors also produced three former friends who gave devastating testimony against the silver-haired politician. Eddie Bartolo, who used to own the San Francisco 49ers football team, told the court that Edwards had picked up a $400,000 (£263,000) payoff in $100 notes at a secret meeting near San Francisco airport. He stuffed the cash into a money belt under his shirt, Mr Bartolo said.

Edwards said the money was received for legitimate "consulting work", and explained the large amount of cash he appeared to carry on him by saying he liked to keep between $250,000 and $500,000 in a piggy-bank.

Lawyers for Edwards said they would appeal against the verdict.

fields.headline: The big picture
fields.standfirst: Today, the trailer for Jim Carrey's next movie is released on the internet. Hardly big news - or so you might have thought. But online film promotion has become a very serious business.
fields.trailText: Today, the trailer for Jim Carrey's next movie is released on the internet. Hardly big news - or so you might have thought. But online film promotion has become a very serious business.
fields.body:
There are two events on today's cinematic calendar. One is the opening of the 53rd Cannes Festival. The other? The internet launch of the trailer for How The Grinch Stole Christmas, the live-action adaptation of the Dr Seuss classic starring Jim Carrey which is due out in November. In terms of traditional news values, there's no comparison between the world's most famous film festival and, well, a trailer. And if we are talking about cinema as an artform, those are the correct priorities. But in terms of the movie business, far more attention will paid to the number of times The Grinch trailer gets downloaded than stories of addled hacks and PRs schmoozing along the Croisette, or earnest assessments of the political significance of Bread And Roses, Ken Loach's first LA-set effort.

When in doubt, blame George Lucas. Remember what happened when the first trailer for the woeful Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace appeared in November 1998? It turned out that crowds were paying the full $10 entrance to The Siege or Meet Joe Black, and then rushing out before the main feature began (understandable, naturally, in the case of Meet Joe Black). Lucas decided to premiere the second trailer on the internet. Within the first five days, it had been downloaded 3.5 million times. That record was demolished by the first teaser for Lord Of The Rings - the first in the trilogy isn't even released until next year - which was downloaded 1.7 million times in its first day.

Which might just seem like a gauge of perversity. With a typical home internet connection in the UK, it can take around 45 minutes to load a two-minute trailer with a picture that's either very small or very distorted but a half-decent size. Neither will give you much of a sense of movies as overwhelmingly visual as Lord Of The Rings (and as for watching a whole feature film on the net, it might now be possible, but is it worth any sane person's time?). Sure, connections are quicker and cheaper in the States, but not that much. Normally, you'd be better off waiting to see the trailer in the cinema, but Lord Of The Rings is an internet exclusive.

It's easy to see what the studios are getting so excited about. This is hype whose efficacy you can quantify. With ads and other marketing, they have to rely on unreliable research for clues to whether it's working or not. Even tracking internet site hits gives ambiguous information: the same few obsessives could be visiting seven times a day each. But if 3.5 million people download the trailer, that's a minimum number of people desperate to see the film. Which should give the accountants a head start on predicting next year's company results.

But what do the people downloading the trailers get, apart from hefty phone bills in the UK? There is an answer in traditional media studies theory.

Most early attempts to analyse cinema revolved around treating films as texts - like books, only with moving pictures - full of subtexts, Freudian references or Barthesian signs to be broken down and read. But by the mid-80s, this was considered rather simplistic. In Visible Fictions - first published in 1984 - John Ellis focused on the idea that we experience big movies as a process, of which actually seeing the film is just the final part. It starts when you first hear or read about a film, continues as you hear rumours or see on-set photos, builds through the trailers, magazine covers, interviews with Jonathan Ross until the point when, finally, you pay your money, buy the popcorn and slip in to see the film. Like the best academic theories, it has the merit of sounding like something you always knew, but hadn't quite got around to thinking about.

What has happened since has only reinforced Ellis's ideas. These days, with the IMDB, Ain't It Cool News, Mr Showbiz and darkhorizons.com, punters are absorbing far more film news daily than Wardour Street regulars used to get in a week. That's before even considering the merchandising explosion. Then think of all those people queuing up to see The Phantom Menace in costume before it opened: seeing the the film formed the smallest part of the whole saga. Or remember how much excitement Eyes Wide Shut generated before it was released.

Mat Snow, former editor of the mature gentleman's rock monthly Mojo, once explained how he had fully enjoyed Godzilla without ever having seen the film. For the months of build-up beforehand, he had the pleasure of getting excited about the film, imagining the monster and the movie in his head, getting off on the hype. By the time the film actually came out, he had been reliably informed that it stank. So he didn't go to see it. But he didn't feel cheated - he had had four months of enjoyable anticipation at no cost.

Which explains why I will wait around while my computer undertakes the task of downloading the Grinch trailer, just in case it hints that the film will be as good as the old TV cartoon. And in a strange way, it has the same function as Cannes: getting people excited about films.

Which, despite the existence of Love, Honour And Obey and The Million Dollar Hotel, is still a good thing.

 The official Grinch website is at www.grinched.com
